Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-01 02:35 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIMELBGCAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEMKDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-01 02:35 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/rp_run.ch
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     % Optimized and improved handling of IF [ELSEIF] [ELSE] ENDIF in
Interpreter mode.
     % Optimized and improved handling of DO CASE [CASE] [OTHERWISE]
END[CASE] in Interpreter mode.
     + Added support for FOR [LOOP] [EXIT] NEXT to Interpreter mode.
     + Added support for [DO] WHILE [LOOP] [EXIT] END[DO] to Interpreter
mode.
     + Added support for file statics to Interpreter mode.
     + Added support for Command-Line Parameters to Interpreter mode.
       /* PP "PrgName Param1 ParamN" -r */

   * tests/stripem.prg
     ! Resolved missing Default() and ToChar()

From:           	"Jacek Kaleta" <jacekklt@polbox.com>
Date sent:      	Wed, 25 Apr 2001 00:13:45 +0200


1. Prosze porownac

       test.prg
       --------------------------------------------------------------
       #translate @anything <l> <n1> [<nn>] => format :={<n1>[,<nn>]}

       proc Main()
       @anything "Ok" "Ok"
       return
       ---------------------------------------------------------------

        **** with harbour ********

       > harbour test.prg

       Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
       Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
       Compiling 'test.prg'...

       test.prg(5) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '@'"

       1 error

       No code generated

       ---------------------------------------------------------------

        **** with clipper ********

       > clipper test.prg

       246K available
       Compiling TEST.PRG
       Code size 77, Symbols 64, Constants 3


2. Prosze porownac

       Test1.prg
       --------------------------------------------------------------
       proc Main() s=_&s return
       ---------------------------------------------------------------

        **** with harbour ********

       > harbour test.prg

       Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
       Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
       Compiling 'test.prg'...

       test.prg(2) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '_'"

       1 error

       No code generated

       ---------------------------------------------------------------

        **** with clipper ********

       > clipper test.prg


       246K available
       Compiling TEST2.PRG
       Code size 76, Symbols 64, Constants 4


3.  Zle dziala

    zm1='index1'
    zm2=''
    set index to zm1, zm2

    (open error .ntx)

    Harbour nie przyjmuje pustych zmiennych w "set index to", a
    clipper tak (np. w dbuutil.prg z Clippera linia 142
  (harbour doesn't accept null strings in 'set index to' although it is a valid in Clipper as stated in 
dbuutil.prg in line 142)

         * null strings are acceptable between the commas
     SET INDEX TO &k_1,&k_2,&k_3,&k_4,&k_5,&k_6,&k_7

    )

    W przypadku kompilatora djgpp dodatkowy komunikat
(djgpp also prints on exit)

    Error DBF/1003  Open error: .ntx
    Called from ORDLISTADD(0)
    Called from MAIN(7)
    ----------------------------------------
    Total memory allocated: 34017 bytes (671 blocks)
    WARNING! Memory allocated but not released: 583 bytes (3 blocks)
    fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR Block 1 (size 259) ORDLISTADD(0) fm.c:425:
    HB_TR_ERROR Block 2 (size 288) ORDLISTADD(0) fm.c:425: HB_TR_ERROR
    Block 3 (size 36) ORDLISTADD(0)


------- End of forwarded message -------

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  2 15:43:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed May  2 14:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CVS down ?
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIMELHGCAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
References: <01170200105020449301737018@HARBOUR.ORG> <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIMELHGCAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <200105021839.f42IdCX19290@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Patrick Mast" <harbour@winfakt.com> on Wed, 2
May 2001 08:07:18 +0200

> > Cannot access /cvsroot/Harbour-project/CVSROOT
> > No such file or directory
> I get the same..

By visiting https://sourceforge.net/cvs/?group_id=681 I was able to
figure out what happened. SourceForge renamed the Harbour-project
directory under the /cvsroot/ directory to harbour-project, but didn't
bother to tell anybody.

What you have to do is change your CVSROOT environment variable to use
/cvsroot/harbour-project instead of /cvsroot/Harbour-project and then
visit each and every CVS subdirectory in your entire local repository
and make the same change in each and every Root and Repository file.

Well, either that or delete your local repository and do a new 'cvs
checkout' (which is NOT an option if you have edits to commit).
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  2 15:44:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May  2 14:44:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CVS down ?
In-Reply-To: <200105021817.f42IHcX17026@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOENDDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Apparently,

   @cvs.Harbour-project.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/Harbour-project

need to be changed to :

   @cvs.Harbour-project.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/harbour-project

Note Harbour-project is now harbour-project (after cvsroot/)

1. Change: /cvs/ROOT entry to reflect the above.

2. You might need to change the set CVSROOT= at your batch file too.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  2 15:45:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May  2 14:45:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-02 11:05 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <200105021817.f42IHcX17026@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCENEDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-02 11:05 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * include/hbapi.h
     * Changed HB_NESTED_CLONED to record BaseArray instead of first item.
     * Reverted declaration of hb_arrayClone to use 2nd parameter (
pClonedList ) for future Thread Safety.

   * source/vm/arrays.c
     * Corrected handling of nested (shared) empty arrays in
hb_arrayClone().
     * Reverted definition of hb_arrayClone() to use 2nd parameter (
pClonedList ) for future Thread Safety.

   * source/vm/arrayshb.c
   * source/vm/classes.c
   * source/vm/hvm.c
     * Added required 2nd parameter ( NULL ) to calls to hb_arrayClone()

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  2 16:23:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Wed May  2 15:23:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-02 11:05 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCENEDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <011401c0d33e$412068d0$921a5e18@bh>

Thanks, Ron!  Everybody should note:  This fix to how empty sub-arrays are
handled removes a very significant bug that may explain a lot of previous
erratic behaviors.  We'll be doing more testing, but it's  looking like the
long-standing problem we had of large arrays getting corrupted is fixed, and
this should also clear up some erratic blowups in classes.

Brian Hays

On Wed, May 02, 2001 at 02:41:17PM -0400, David G. Holm wrote:

> What you have to do is change your CVSROOT environment variable to use
> /cvsroot/harbour-project instead of /cvsroot/Harbour-project and then
> visit each and every CVS subdirectory in your entire local repository and
> make the same change in each and every Root and Repository file.

Anyone in a GNU/perl environment might like to try this:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
find -name Root -exec perl -i -pe s/Ha/ha/g '{}' ';'
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

I didn't need to fiddle with my Repository files. If you do you should be
able to simply replace Root with Repository in the above.

>         **** with harbour ********
>
>        > harbour test.prg
>
>        Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
>        Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
>        Compiling 'test.prg'...
>
>        test.prg(5) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '@'"
>
>        1 error
>
>        No code generated

Fixed.

>        Test1.prg
>        --------------------------------------------------------------
>        proc Main() s=_&s return
>        ---------------------------------------------------------------
>
>         **** with harbour ********
>
>        > harbour test.prg
>
>        Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
>        Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
>        Compiling 'test.prg'...
>
>        test.prg(2) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '_'"
>
>        1 error
>
>        No code generated

This works correctly with SimpLex build.

>     zm1='index1'
>     zm2=''
>     set index to zm1, zm2
>
>     (open error .ntx)
>
>   (harbour doesn't accept null strings in 'set index to' although
> it is a valid in Clipper as stated in
> dbuutil.prg in line 142)
>
>          * null strings are acceptable between the commas
>      SET INDEX TO &k_1,&k_2,&k_3,&k_4,&k_5,&k_6,&k_7

Alexander, Brian, Horacio ?

BTW, we still have these when trying to build tests\db_brows:

Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_FIELDTYPE' referenced from
C:\CVS\HARBOUR\TESTS\DB_BROWS.OBJ
Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_FIELDSIZE' referenced from
C:\CVS\HARBOUR\TESTS\DB_BROWS.OBJ

C:\CVS\HARBOUR\TESTS\DB_BROWS.OBJ

Anyone knows why FieldType() FieldSize() and FieldDeci() are missing?

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May  3 03:20:05 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu May  3 02:20:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fwd: Bug report
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIENIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <000e01c0d39a$06c741c0$921a5e18@bh>

Ron:
>>Anyone knows why FieldType() FieldSize() and FieldDeci() are missing?
Since they're all caps in the code, I'd guess they were originally macros
for calls to dbFieldInfo, and the header file got changed or omitted.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May  3 04:37:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Thu May  3 03:37:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Fwd: Bug report
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIENIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIENIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <1766163659.20010503113514@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 03.05.2001 9:01, Ron Pinkas <Ron@Profit-Master.com> wrote:

RP> BTW, we still have these when trying to build tests\db_brows:

RP> Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_FIELDTYPE' referenced from
RP> C:\CVS\HARBOUR\TESTS\DB_BROWS.OBJ
RP> Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_FIELDSIZE' referenced from
RP> C:\CVS\HARBOUR\TESTS\DB_BROWS.OBJ
RP> Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_FIELDDECI' referenced from
RP> C:\CVS\HARBOUR\TESTS\DB_BROWS.OBJ

RP> Anyone knows why FieldType() FieldSize() and FieldDeci() are missing?

 These functions are in contrib/libmisc/dbftools.c ( surely, this file
 should be in contrib/libct ).
 GNU MAKE system build the libmisc.a automatically, with Borland C you
 should build it, using the contrib/libmisc/make_b32.bat and,
 probably, include it to you link script.


Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May  3 06:14:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Thu May  3 05:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Replaceable drivers for SQL DBMS suggestion
In-Reply-To: <3AEB2034.DC4ABD28@libero.it>
References: <1821559594.20010427144108@belacy.belgorod.su>
 <3AE9A0D9.D3F350DD@libero.it> <8813240740.20010427220651@belacy.belgorod.su>
 <3AEB2034.DC4ABD28@libero.it>
Message-ID: <7511969044.20010503131158@belacy.belgorod.su>

 Maurilio,
 
ML> I'm really short on spare time as you can see from the fact that I haven't updated
ML> my contrib\mysql for months, so I cannot say that I will find time to follow (or
ML> help) your project but I see your point in having a middle layer between tmysql.prg
ML> and mysql.c which could free tmysql.prg from its dependance upon a given SQL
ML> server.

 Middle layer between any Harbour level code and mySQL API library,
 not mysql.c - this is the point. Mysql.c should be converted to the
 mysqlrdd.c, which will be the part of that middle layer, as dbfntx
 and dbfcdx are parts of the RDD system.



Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

Fixed. If you still have problem with CVS, just change line 1876 in
pp\ppcore.c, from:

  if( State == STATE_EXPRES || strchr( "({[,$!#=<>^%*/+-", cLastChar ) )

to:

  if( State == STATE_EXPRES || strchr( "({[|,$!#=<>^%*/+-", cLastChar ) )
                                           ^
Ron

Date: Thu May  3 11:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-04-30 13:00 UTC-0400 David G. Holm
In-Reply-To: <3AF0A42C.FAC75275@mail.rosecom.ca>
References: <200104301659.f3UGxew18259@smtp.parrett.net> <3AF0A42C.FAC75275@mail.rosecom.ca>
Message-ID: <200105031529.f43FTuX17054@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from April <awhite@mail.rosecom.ca> on Wed, 02 May
2001 20:19:56 -0400

> David, I have not been following the threads regarding the above.  Do you
> see any necessary changes that should be made to the setkey system?

Quite possibly. But it didn't even occur to me that it might until you
brought it up... You'll need to test it by using SET( _SET_EVENTMASK,
HB_INKEY_EXTENDED ) in some module that uses the setkey system and see
what breaks. You can either look in include/hbinkey.ch or run
tests/inkeytst with the skip and extended command line parameters to see
what key codes the extended mode returns.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

     ! Corrected minor bug with test for valid string prefixes in
getExpReal()
     + Added missing valid string prefix (.) (except macro terminator) in
getExpReal()

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May  4 14:10:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri May  4 13:10:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OO syntax, some clarification sought
Message-ID: <20010504180857.I1231@hagbard.davep.org>

I just had a confusing moment while playing with class creation and method
implementation in harbour.

Given a class like this:

,----
| Create Class Foo
| 
|    Method wibble
| 
| End Class
`----

it seems that I have to implement the class like this:

,----
| Method wibble() Class Foo
| ...
`----

I don't seem to be able to do as I might have done with Class(y):

,----
| Method wibble()
| ...
`----

I take it that this is a deliberate feature (I can see why this might be a
good thing)? If this is the case, how come the second example makes it thru
the compiler? Shouldn't the second way of implementing a method throw a
compiler error? I only realised that I'd got things wrong at link-time and
it wasn't immediately obvious what my problem was.

Also, slightly related, why can't I implement a method that takes no
arguments like this:

,----
| Method wibble Class Foo
| ...
`----

Note the absence of empty parens after the method name. It seems that I have
to supply the empty parens, this is inconsistent with function and procedure
implementation.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May  5 02:34:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sat May  5 01:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OO syntax, some clarification sought
In-Reply-To: <20010504180857.I1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEOEDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> it seems that I have to implement the class like this:
>
> ,----
> | Method wibble() Class Foo
> | ...
> `----
>
> I don't seem to be able to do as I might have done with Class(y):
>
> ,----
> | Method wibble()
> | ...
> `----
>
> I take it that this is a deliberate feature (I can see why this might be a
> good thing)?

This was needed because otherwise it would be impossible to differentiate
between the METHOD Declaration to the METHOD Implementation, since both
would be using the exact same syntax. (PP doesn't have context knowledge).

However I was able (I hope) to overcome this problem, by forcing the context
using some nested PP directives. You should now be able to implement your
method, without having to use the CLASS Clause.

[see more info sample below...]

> Also, slightly related, why can't I implement a method that takes no
> arguments like this:
>
> ,----
> | Method wibble Class Foo
> | ...
> `----
>
> Note the absence of empty parens after the method name. It seems
> that I have
> to supply the empty parens, this is inconsistent with function
> and procedure
> implementation.

Fixed.

------

Please note the added support should work correctly even if multiple classes
are defined in your prg (assuming sequential ordering). For example the
following sample should work as expected:

//------------------------------------//
#include "hbclass.ch"

Procedure Main()
    LOCAL o := TTest():New()

    o:Increment()
    Alert( o:nVar )

    o := TOtherTest():New()
    Alert( o:nVar )
return

CLASS TTest
   VAR nVar
   METHOD New() CONSTRUCTOR
   METHOD Increment()
ENDCLASS

METHOD New //CLASS TTest /* CLASS clause now optional */
   Alert( ProcName() )
   ::nVar := 0
return Self

METHOD Increment CLASS TTest // () No longer required
return (++::nVar)

CLASS TOtherTest
   VAR nVar
   METHOD New() CONSTRUCTOR
ENDCLASS

METHOD New //CLASS TOtherTest /* CLASS clause now optional, even if multiple
classes per prg. */
   Alert( ProcName() )
   ::nVar := 10
return Self
//------------------------------------//

Ron

     + Added support for METHOD implementations without requiring the "()"
if no parameters needed.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May  6 02:59:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun May  6 01:59:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] =?iso-8859-1?Q?Re:_=5BHarbour=5D_The_Filesys.c_using_WinAPI=B4s?=
References: <001301c0d5d1$144c4dc0$4cd4d7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <000f01c0d5f2$89e40d40$921a5e18@bh>

Luiz:
There were a few msgs stating several issues. Some were specifics like
breaking, IIRC, memoline and some other functions, and some trickier issues
that stem from the fact that the api HANDLEs are incompatible with any other
low-level code that may be expecting to use an old-style file handle.  I
believe Horacio offered an idea to embed a flag in a bit of the handles to
attempt to support both types  (excuse me if I over-simplified the
proposal;-).

Anyone wanting to tackle it really should search the archives; there were
probably a dozen meaningful msgs on the topic.  It's a great idea, but it
may not be easy to be completely transparent when porting Clipper code to
Harbour.

Brian

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May  6 17:10:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Paul Tucker)
Date: Sun May  6 16:10:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Parse error Simplex & flex
Message-ID: <01cc01c0d668$3dcc5cc0$b6122a0a@chasechevy>

I pulled this out of someones working app for your perusing pleasure... 


#xtranslate TestValEq(<val>, <v1> [, <vn>])  ;
      => (<val> == <v1> [.OR. <val> == <vn>])

#include "inkey.ch"
proc main
   LOCAL nKey, nRet := 2

   nKey := LastKey()
   DO CASE
   CASE TestValEq( nKey, K_RIGHT, K_LEFT, K_CTRL_RIGHT, K_CTRL_LEFT )
         // ignore
   CASE TestValEq( nKey, K_HOME, K_CTRL_HOME )
   endcase

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 01:11:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Mon May  7 00:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
Message-ID: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh>

Unfortunately, the Set function controls many things that are part of an
RDD.

With ADS (and others) this creates a problem where critical functions cannot
be "hooked" or overridden.
It is imperative that Date Format, Epoch, and other settings be kept
synchronized between the back end and Harbour.  I, for instance, lost a huge
part of the last 2 days chasing impossible bugs because I was sure these
were already set right.  I've created a debugging function for dumping
workarea and setting info from the Server (IOW not going through the rdd) so
programmers can verify them.

Currently we can come close to working right by telling people to use
commands instead of function calls, and overriding the commands in ADS.CH.
This, well, sucks.

Functions that control the behavior of an RDD should always hook into the
RDD!  There are lots of reasons why a programmer may have used the Set()
function directly instead of the command.

Is it possible or feasible to be able to post a codeblock that Set() would
eval, passing along the requested action and any new value?  Is there a
better way to create some kind of "inheritance" with Set()?
I just realized it may be possible to #xtranslate the function to call both
the original and another function.  Is there a recursion problem translating
Set to call Set?

Thanks for any ideas...

Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 05:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon May  7 04:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
Message-ID: <20010507095149.S1231@hagbard.davep.org>

Consider the following code:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
#include "hbclass.ch"

Function Main()

  ? HelloWorld():new():go()

Return( NIL )

Create Class HelloWorld

End Class

Method go

  ? "Hello, World"

Return( self )
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

The code compiles and links without a problem. Only at run-time does it
become apparent that HelloWorld::go wasn't declared in the HelloWorld class
declaration. Given the sophistication of harbour's class declaration code it
strikes me that it would be possible for the compiler to complain when it
sees an undeclared method implemented.

Would that be possible?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 06:08:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May  7 05:08:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <20010507095149.S1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <000a01c0d6d5$04855940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Dave,

I think that is impossible. Specially for a "late-binding"
language as Harbour PRGs language is.

Consider the expression:

   local o := AFunction()

   o:WhatEver()

there is no way to know in advance, by the compiler,
the class of o.

And, more over, if we try to implement such feature
we will be going against the "late-binding" nature of
this language, that such enormous programming power 
provides.

Antonio

> Given the sophistication of harbour's class 
> declaration code it
> strikes me that it would be possible for the compiler to complain when it
> sees an undeclared method implemented.
> 
> Would that be possible?




From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 06:09:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May  7 05:09:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <20010507095149.S1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <000a01c0d6d5$04855940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Dave,

I think that is impossible. Specially for a "late-binding"
language as Harbour PRGs language is.

Consider the expression:

   local o := AFunction()

   o:WhatEver()

there is no way to know in advance, by the compiler,
the class of o.

And, more over, if we try to implement such feature
we will be going against the "late-binding" nature of
this language, that such enormous programming power 
provides.

Antonio

> declaration code it

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 06:10:05 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Mon May  7 05:10:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <20010507095149.S1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <3AF68223.26218.5F8C4D@localhost>

Hi Dave,

Not sure it could be done easely as when we reach the Method 
implementation, we know the (default) Class from wich it belong 
but we don't have a list of declared message fro this class. Also, if 
we use the CLASS specifier at implementation level, we could be 
far long since we declared a specific class and we could even be in 
another prg...  

Perhaps a new game ;-)) for Ron ?

As a side note, this is the same behaviour as in Class(y) and other 
OO implementation.

See you,

integrated into harbour rather than it been an addition (as with Class(y)

Subject: [Harbour] RDD Bug ?
In-Reply-To: <000301c0d6e7$041442c0$92d4d7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <000001c0d6f1$89954f20$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C0D702.4D1E1F20
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

A Harbour and FWH user has reported us a possible bug:

Two consecutive rlock without an unlock for the first one,
and after an append, they perform some extraordinary,
the index file is updated but the DBF is not. It only fails
if the file on share mode.

Here I enclose the sample he has provided us.

Thanks!

Antonio

>>
Dos rlock consecutivos sin unlock para el primero y después de un append
causan algo extraordinario, el archivo indice queda grabado con el dato pero
no así la DBF. !!!! (solo falla en modo SHARED del archivo)
>>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 15:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May  7 14:26:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <3AF68223.26218.5F8C4D@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEOLDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave, J.P.,

> > The code compiles and links without a problem. Only at run-time does
> > it become apparent that HelloWorld::go wasn't declared in the
> > HelloWorld class declaration. Given the sophistication of harbour's
> > class declaration code it strikes me that it would be possible for the
> > compiler to complain when it sees an undeclared method implemented.
> >
> > Would that be possible?
>
> Hi Dave,
>
> Not sure it could be done easely as when we reach the Method
> implementation, we know the (default) Class from wich it belong
> but we don't have a list of declared message fro this class. Also, if
> we use the CLASS specifier at implementation level, we could be
> far long since we declared a specific class and we could even be in
> another prg...
>
> Perhaps a new game ;-)) for Ron ?

Actually Harbour already does that when using -W3 or greater :-).

Please note though that the class[es] must be placed in the prg *before* the
code that uses them. So the provided example would have to be modified as
follows:

//------------------------//
#include "hbclass.ch"
Create Class HelloWorld // Class defined first!
End Class

Method go
  ? "Hello, World"
Return( self )

Function Main()
  ? HelloWorld():new():go() // Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in
class 'HELLOWORLD'
Return( NIL )
//------------------------//

This brings a problem [previously raised], since in the above, the Class
Function (HelloWorld()) will be executed first :-(. As you may remember, I
proposes a new statement, UTILITY (or something like that) so that we could
define the Class Function as:

  UTILITY Function HelloWorld()

And the method[s]:

  UTILITY Static Function Go()

This will allow to skip UTILITY class of Functions/Procedures. In the
alternate we could do something [much] less elegant, like use EXIT Function
..., then we will have to find if the activation was from EXIT and if so do
nothing :-(.

BTW, to see the correct warnings with -W3 as per above, I need to post a
minor fix. I'll try to so ASAP so you can test how it catches the above
error in compile time.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 15:52:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May  7 14:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-07 11:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEOLDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEOMDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 16:42:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Mon May  7 15:42:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEOLDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3AF68223.26218.5F8C4D@localhost>
Message-ID: <200105071940.f47Jes932689@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>

Ron,

>>...
> >
> > Perhaps a new game ;-)) for Ron ?

Oups, that was a joke Ron, you are not obliged to find a solution, 
really. :-)

If I correctly understood, Dave was only annoyed (like me with 
class(y)) with the fact he could write a method GO() without having 
declared it so causing this method to became a missing message 
at RunTime. (The reverse will cause an undefefined function call at 
link time).

> Actually Harbour already does that when using -W3 or greater :-).
> 
> Please note though that the class[es] must be placed in the prg *before*
> the code that uses them. So the provided example would have to be modified
> as follows:

This is not the problem Dave explained and the constraint you 
added to have the -W3 working is (for me) unusable.

Last but not least, your system will declare the New method (as 
the Init one) as missing when they by the fact exist without 
declaring them. This is a direct conclusion of the autoinheritance 
from the class OBJECT. In all case, all inherited method would be 
nearly impossible to trace here.
 
> //------------------------//
> #include "hbclass.ch"
> Create Class HelloWorld // Class defined first!
> End Class
> 
> Method go
>   ? "Hello, World"
> Return( self )
> 
> Function Main()
>   ? HelloWorld():new():go() // Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in
> class 'HELLOWORLD' Return( NIL ) //------------------------//
> 
> This brings a problem [previously raised], since in the above, the Class
> Function (HelloWorld()) will be executed first :-(. As you may remember, I
> proposes a new statement, UTILITY (or something like that) so that we
> could define the Class Function as:
 
>   UTILITY Function HelloWorld()
> 
> And the method[s]:
> 
>   UTILITY Static Function Go()

No, not for me, thanks, I already consider HBCLASS.CH as very 
confusing PP code and I don't think adding more (even internal) 
keyword would help anyone using Harbour.
 
> This will allow to skip UTILITY class of Functions/Procedures. In the
> alternate we could do something [much] less elegant, like use EXIT
> Function ..., then we will have to find if the activation was from EXIT
> and if so do nothing :-(.
> 
> BTW, to see the correct warnings with -W3 as per above, I need to post a
> minor fix. I'll try to so ASAP so you can test how it catches the above
> error in compile time.
>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 17:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon May  7 16:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEOLDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Mon, May 07, 2001 at 11:29:54AM -0700
References: <3AF68223.26218.5F8C4D@localhost> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEOLDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010507210735.B1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, May 07, 2001 at 11:29:54AM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> //------------------------//
> #include "hbclass.ch"
> Create Class HelloWorld // Class defined first!
> End Class
> 
> Method go
>   ? "Hello, World"
> Return( self )
> 
> Function Main()
>   ? HelloWorld():new():go() // Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in
> class 'HELLOWORLD'
> Return( NIL )
> //------------------------//

This sort of misses the issue I was raising. The sort of error (not warning)
I was thinking about would have been raised by the compiler on line five of
the above code (the implementation of the method :go()) because you're
trying to implement a method that wasn't declared.

Warning about messages that haven't been declared would appear to be
problematic if, for example, classes can be extended at runtime (which they
can with Class(y) for example, I've not check how things work with harbour's
class system in this regard).

Put another way, sending a message to an object of a class that doesn't have
a method of that name declared, at compile time, seems like a reasonable
thing to do and it should be handled at run-time if it turns out to be an
error. Throwing a compile error when a method is implemented but not
declared seems like an obvious extension if it's possible as it will catch
an obvious "gotcha" coding error that doesn't have any practical use.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 19:29:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May  7 18:29:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <20010507210735.B1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEONDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> This sort of misses the issue I was raising. The sort of error
> (not warning)
> I was thinking about would have been raised by the compiler on
> line five of
> the above code (the implementation of the method :go()) because you're
> trying to implement a method that wasn't declared.

I see, sorry I got confused. .oO

> Warning about messages that haven't been declared would appear to be
> problematic if, for example, classes can be extended at runtime
> (which they
> can with Class(y) for example, I've not check how things work
> with harbour's
> class system in this regard).

True, but you would _not_ have "hard coded" message invocations, for such
run-time added messages would you? I mean if you knew in compile time of the
message, it would/should have been defined in the first place (?). Messages
added in Run-Time are likely to be invocated be means of macros (?).

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May  7 19:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May  7 18:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <200105071940.f47Jes932689@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEOODLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Hello J.F.,

> If I correctly understood, Dave was only annoyed (like me with
> class(y)) with the fact he could write a method GO() without having
> declared it so causing this method to became a missing message
> at RunTime. (The reverse will cause an undefefined function call at
> link time).

Right, sorry. I misread it the first time.

> This is not the problem Dave explained and the constraint you
> added to have the -W3 working is (for me) unusable.

Just out of curiosity, what constraint does -W3 imposes, that makes it
unusable for you? I'm curious because -W3 should compile _any_ valid code,
without erroneous warnings, even if the code has _no_ strong type
declarations. Did you try it recently, with any normal prg?

> Last but not least, your system will declare the New method (as
> the Init one) as missing when they by the fact exist without
> declaring them. This is a direct conclusion of the autoinheritance
> from the class OBJECT. In all case, all inherited method would be
> nearly impossible to trace here.

Sorry, I forgot of the default methods, I [think I] can easily add them.
Later, I [think I] can also add support for inheritance.

> >   UTILITY Static Function Go()
>
> No, not for me, thanks, I already consider HBCLASS.CH as very
> confusing PP code and I don't think adding more (even internal)
> keyword would help anyone using Harbour.

If we add UTILITY qualifier it would add no complexity to hbclass.ch. It
would just add the UTILITY qualifier to the _translation_, just before the
"[static] function <>". It would add _no_ new #translates, #commands, or
#defines.

BTW, thanks for your great work with classes.c.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 02:57:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue May  8 01:57:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <200105080521.f485LE915525@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEOPDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Hi J.F.,

> Humm, sorry if you though I tryed it. I was just speaking about your
> sample where the class declaration had to be done before the
> class use wich is probably never the case into real program.

This is because of a very simple problem. Clipper can *not* have the class
definition at the top of the prg, because it would become the Main (startup)
procedure. This is the problem I proposed to solve with the UTILITY
qualifier.

> > Sorry, I forgot of the default methods, I [think I] can easily add them.
> > Later, I [think I] can also add support for inheritance.
>
> I'm not sure it is a really needed enhancement as it could finally
> avoid the use of the -W3 switch

Just the opposite, give -W3 a test and see how nice it works, even without
declarations. It is of course even more powerful with declarations. You have
to play with it, to see how well it works.

> ... PS: I remember I worked on the
> ability to add new method/VAR at runtime but don't remember if it
> worked finally. Normally It should work so don't miss the fact we
> could call a method wich would only exist at run time (even if it is
> not really nice)

We have no problem with anyone adding more vars/methods in run-time. When
this is done the normal syntax is not used. Instead one will use macros or
oSend(), etc. So (I think) there is no impact on compile time warnings.

> If you can find a solution for the specific problem Dave explained it
> should be enough for most of the programmers.

I think I have an idea...

> Just one important thing, I'm trying (since month due to a real miss
> of time :-( ) to solve at least the problem of real error tracing trough
> the class tree when an error occur at some inherited method, so if
> you can avoid too much modifications to classes.c as tclass.prg
> that could help me.

Sure! I have no current plans or need to modify classes.c or tclass.prg.

> > If we add UTILITY qualifier it would add no complexity to hbclass.ch. It
> > would just add the UTILITY qualifier to the _translation_, just
> before the
> > "[static] function <>". It would add _no_ new #translates, #commands, or
> > #defines.
>
> Perhaps I misunderstand your goal, Could you just send me a
> resume of what you want to do ? (even by private mail if this tread
> has already been treated)

Ok.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 03:23:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May  8 02:23:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEOODLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Mon, May 07, 2001 at 03:45:30PM -0700
References: <200105071940.f47Jes932689@ev6.be.wanadoo.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEOODLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010508065910.F1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, May 07, 2001 at 03:45:30PM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Hello J.F.,
> 
> > This is not the problem Dave explained and the constraint you
> > added to have the -W3 working is (for me) unusable.
> 
> Just out of curiosity, what constraint does -W3 imposes, that makes it
> unusable for you? I'm curious because -W3 should compile _any_ valid code,
> without erroneous warnings, even if the code has _no_ strong type
> declarations. Did you try it recently, with any normal prg?

I can imagine a situation where it would be unusable (although unusable is
probably too strong a term) and it's the example I've given of a class whose
method list is added to at runtime. If you're the sort of programmer who
treats warnings as errors and if you're the sort of programmer who'd
appreciate the extra pedantic warning level you provided then you'd be
bitten by this warning if you used such a dynamic class.

In such a situation -W3 would be making incorrect claims about the validity
of my code and, unless I'm missing something, there'd be no way of turning
the warning off without loosing all the useful warnings that -W3 can
provide.

--

FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 03:23:10 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May  8 02:23:10 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEONDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Mon, May 07, 2001 at 03:31:07PM -0700
References: <20010507210735.B1231@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEONDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010508065345.E1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, May 07, 2001 at 03:31:07PM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Warning about messages that haven't been declared would appear to be
> > problematic if, for example, classes can be extended at runtime (which
> > they can with Class(y) for example, I've not check how things work with
> > harbour's class system in this regard).
> 
> True, but you would _not_ have "hard coded" message invocations, for such
> run-time added messages would you? I mean if you knew in compile time of
> the message, it would/should have been defined in the first place (?).
> Messages added in Run-Time are likely to be invocated be means of macros
> (?).

There's every chance you would. The classic example is a workarea class
where the class itself doesn't "inherit" field names until you instantiate
an object whereas you probably would have "hard coded" access to instance
variables and message sending.

For example (cooked up off the top of my head and from memory so don't take
it as working code):

,----
| Use People New Exclusive
| 
| // Note that it's in ":new()" that the extra messages are created.
| // Also note that a data dictionary could be working behind the
| // scenes to create virtual fields and the like.
| oPeople := WorkArea():new()
| 
| ...
| 
| oPeople:goTop()
| ? oPeople:surname()
`----

I've seen code like the above before.

--

Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 07:35:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Tue May  8 06:35:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method
 isn't declared?
Message-ID: <200105080633_MC2-D017-7DE8@compuserve.com>

Jean,

> Just one important thing, I'm trying (since month due to a real miss =

> of time :-( ) to solve at least the problem of real error tracing troug=
h =

> the class tree when an error occur at some inherited method

I would _love_ to see that and the related error [1] fixed. :-)  Far
more than any other change in the OOP system. :-)

[1] sometimes a Message Not Found is incorrectly raised; as you know,
the underlying reason is that at runtime the OOP subsystem is not
always 100% able to figure out what is / is not valid. :-(

In C4W32, one effect of the above is that WToolTip immediately throws
an incorrect runtime error.  It's sad not to be able to have tool tips
in the Harbour version of Clip-4-Win...

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 07:35:11 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Tue May  8 06:35:11 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method
 isn't declared?
Message-ID: <200105080633_MC2-D017-7DE6@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> Given the sophistication of harbour's class declaration code it
> strikes me that it would be possible for the compiler to complain when =
it
> sees an undeclared method implemented.

It does look likely (and even desirable), especially (only? [1]) if
it were defined with its class name specified.

OTOH, there are arguably rather higher-priority things yet to do (see
my other msg :-).

[1] one could argue that missing out the class name could mean you
were defining a method of any class needing that method e.g. a class
in a different PRG.  I can't say I'm a fan of being able to split
methods out from the class - at least not without some EXTERNAL/PUBLIC/AN=
OUNCEs
(or whatever), but it's possible to argue for it...

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 09:31:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May  8 08:31:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <200105080633_MC2-D017-7DE6@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Tue, May 08, 2001 at 06:33:21AM -0400
References: <200105080633_MC2-D017-7DE6@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010508130050.O1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 08, 2001 at 06:33:21AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Given the sophistication of harbour's class declaration code it
> > strikes me that it would be possible for the compiler to complain when it
> > sees an undeclared method implemented.
> 
> It does look likely (and even desirable), especially (only? [1]) if it
> were defined with its class name specified.

If I'm seeing things correctly a method implementation that doesn't name the
class is implemented as a method of the last class declared in the same PRG.
I doubt there's any other reasonable method of doing this (either logically
or physically).

Talking of -W3 and harbour's OO support:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.prg
#include "hbclass.ch"

Function Main()

  ? "Totally valid code that should throw a -W3 error"

Return( NIL )

davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour foo -W3
Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
Compiling 'foo.prg'...
hbclass.ch(109) Warning W0025  Class 'TCLASS' not known in declaration of 'NEW'
Lines 9, Functions/Procedures 2
Generating C source output to 'foo.c'... Done.
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

I shouldn't be getting a warning like that should I?

May 2001 15:12:40 -0400

> Hmm - this was just after a fresh checkout, so it's either on cvs that way,

> anything with the captial 'H' in it.

Check the 'Root' and 'Repository' files in each and every 'CVS'
directory in your entire local harbour directory. Start with the root
directory, as identified by your HOME environment variable. Also check
your CVSROOT environment variable.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 16:23:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue May  8 15:23:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
In-Reply-To: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh>
References: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh>
Message-ID: <200105081918.f48JIt526571@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Brian Hays" <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Sun, 6
May 2001 21:17:12 -0700

I fail to understand the problem. There is not supposed to be any
synchronization of SET variables between Harbour and an RDD, because the
RDD should always query Harbour for the current value of any Harbour SET
values. Most of the SET settings are available via the Harbour structure
hb_set (see include/hbset.h) and can be accessed directly from C (e.g.,
strcpy( path_name, hb_set.HB_SET_PATH ). The few SET values that aren't
there (_SET_COLOR, _SET_CURSOR, and _SET_LANGUAGE) use dedicated set
functions (see source/rtl/set.c).
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 16:35:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Sylvain Robert )
Date: Tue May  8 15:35:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Data and Classdata
Message-ID: <3AF80FA2.268.22062A7@localhost>

Good Afternoon,

 I'm searching a way from Harbour to distinguish DATA from 
CLASSDATA ?

    My goal is to be sure that there is no Orphan object created by 
the object that just end. But I don't want to DESTROY object that are 
SHARED by the CLASS itself.
  
  Code Example:

Function CleanObj(oObject)
 Local Adata,x,Valobj
 Adata:=Aodata(oObject) //This one is faster __objGetMsgList(Oobj,.t.)
 for x = 1 to Len(Adata)
   if Valtype(Valobj:=Osend(oObject,adata[x])) =="O"
     if __ObjHasMethod(valobj,"DESTROY")
       Valobj:DESTROY()
     elseif __ObjHasMethod(Valobj,"RELEASE")
       valobj:RELEASE()
     elseif __ObjHasMethod(valobj,"END")
       valobj:END()
     endif
   endif
 Next x

  Thank you,

  Sylvain

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 17:35:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue May  8 16:35:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
References: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh> <200105081918.f48JIt526571@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <000901c0d7ff$4d155590$2400a8c0@local>

David:
Thanks for enquiring.

>> the RDD should always query Harbour

Unfortunately this is not possible!
In the case of the RDD being essentially a wrapper for a server (as in
RDDADS), there are functions happening on the server that cannot query
Harbour.  Case in point is CTOD().  If this function is in a filter
expression, the *server* calls it as it tests records.  That function
responds to the ADS internal setting controlled by AdsSetDateFormat().
There is no opportunity to have any contact with the client (aka Harbour).
So our only hope is to call AdsSetDateFormat() every time
Set(_SET_DATEFORMAT, cFormat) is called to keep the server settings
synchronized with Harbour.

If we don't, data querying is completely unreliable.

Brian

----- Original Message -----
From: David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>
To: <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Sent: Tuesday, May 08, 2001 12:21 PM
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD


> ** Reply to message from "Brian Hays" <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Sun, 6
> May 2001 21:17:12 -0700
>
> I fail to understand the problem. There is not supposed to be any
> synchronization of SET variables between Harbour and an RDD, because the
> RDD should always query Harbour for the current value of any Harbour SET
> values. Most of the SET settings are available via the Harbour structure
> hb_set (see include/hbset.h) and can be accessed directly from C (e.g.,
> strcpy( path_name, hb_set.HB_SET_PATH ). The few SET values that aren't
> there (_SET_COLOR, _SET_CURSOR, and _SET_LANGUAGE) use dedicated set
> functions (see source/rtl/set.c).

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 17:48:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Tue May  8 16:48:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
References: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh> <200105081918.f48JIt526571@smtp.parrett.net> <000901c0d7ff$4d155590$2400a8c0@local>
Message-ID: <002b01c0d7ff$e5dd6ce0$186510ac@jharrier>

Brian,
        this has always been the case on a Client/Server architecture!.
TOPConnect has to send the DELETED status on every database read, as the
server cannot know about it. On Clipper this was a MACRO evaluation every
time, thanks god on Harbour we have direct access to this data.

Regards
Harrier

Should allow anyone to obtain either a full msg list or only the 
class one by the use of the :ClassSel method now wich accept a 
logical param.

2001-05-09 00:02 UTC+1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
   * source/vm/classes.c
    * modified hb_msgclssel() to accept one logical param
      so as it return only ClassMsg
   * source/rtl/objfunc.prg
    * modified ObjGetMsgList() to accept one logical param
      so as it return only ClassMsg

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 19:21:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue May  8 18:21:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-08 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <000901c0d7ff$4d155590$2400a8c0@local>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEPGDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-08 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * include/hbclass.ch
     % Removed numerous redundant rules.
     + Added logic to detect and raise #error on implementation of NON
Declared method.

   * source/rtl/tclass.prg
     + Added logic to dispose of possible "(...)" suffix to Method Name in
AddVirtual(), AddMethod(), and AddClsMethod().

/* J.F., we had many redundant rules like this:

1.
#xcommand MESSAGE <MessageName> [ AS <type> ] METHOD <MethodName> [ <ctor:
CONSTRUCTOR> ] [ <export: EXPORTED, VISIBLE>] [<protect: PROTECTED>]
[<hidde: HIDDEN>] => ;
    _HB_MEMBER <MessageName>([<params>]) [<-ctor-> AS CLASS _CLASS_NAME_]
[ AS <type> ];;
    s_oClass:AddMethod( <(MessageName)>, CLSMETH _CLASS_NAME_
<MethodName>(), HBCLSCHOICE( <.export.>, <.protect.>, <.hidde.> ) + iif(
<.ctor.>, HB_OO_CLSTP_CTOR, 0 ) )

2.
#xcommand MESSAGE <MessageName> [ AS <type> ] METHOD <MethodName>(
[<params,...>] ) [ <ctor: CONSTRUCTOR> ] [ <export: EXPORTED, VISIBLE>]
[<protect: PROTECTED>] [<hidde: HIDDEN>] => ;
    _HB_MEMBER <MessageName>([<params>]) [<-ctor-> AS CLASS _CLASS_NAME_]
[ AS <type> ];;
    s_oClass:AddMethod( <(MessageName)>, CLSMETH _CLASS_NAME_
<MethodName>(), HBCLSCHOICE( <.export.>, <.protect.>, <.hidde.> ) + iif(
<.ctor.>, HB_OO_CLSTP_CTOR, 0 ) )

3.
#xcommand MESSAGE <MessageName>( [<params,...>] ) [ AS <type> ] METHOD
<MethodName> [ <ctor: CONSTRUCTOR> ] [ <export: EXPORTED, VISIBLE>]
[<protect: PROTECTED>] [<hidde: HIDDEN>] => ;
    _HB_MEMBER <MessageName>([<params>]) [<-ctor-> AS CLASS _CLASS_NAME_]
[ AS <type> ];;
    s_oClass:AddMethod( <(MessageName)>, CLSMETH _CLASS_NAME_
<MethodName>(), HBCLSCHOICE( <.export.>, <.protect.>, <.hidde.> ) + iif(
<.ctor.>, HB_OO_CLSTP_CTOR, 0 ) )

4.
#xcommand MESSAGE <MessageName>( [<params,...>] ) [ AS <type> ] METHOD
<MethodName>( [<dummy,...>] ) [ <ctor: CONSTRUCTOR> ] [ <export: EXPORTED,
VISIBLE>] [<protect: PROTECTED>] [<hidde: HIDDEN>] => ;
    _HB_MEMBER <MessageName>([<params>]) [<-ctor-> AS CLASS _CLASS_NAME_]
[ AS <type> ];;
    s_oClass:AddMethod( <(MessageName)>, CLSMETH _CLASS_NAME_
<MethodName>(), HBCLSCHOICE( <.export.>, <.protect.>, <.hidde.> ) + iif(
<.ctor.>, HB_OO_CLSTP_CTOR, 0 ) )

All these can be matched with just version #1. There were many other
redundancies as well.

Many duplications could be removed without any impact, while others only
impacted AddVirtual(), AddMethod() and AddClsMethod(). I added simple logic
to these to dispose of the extra ([<params,...>] when present.

This way hbclass.ch is much simpler (and faster), could you please review
and let me know if you agree...

Ron
*/



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 19:45:03 2001

In-Reply-To: <20010507210735.B1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEPGDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > //------------------------//
> > #include "hbclass.ch"
> > Create Class HelloWorld // Class defined first!
> > End Class
> >
> > Method go
> >   ? "Hello, World"
> > Return( self )
> >
> > Function Main()
> >   ? HelloWorld():new():go() // Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in
> > class 'HELLOWORLD'
> > Return( NIL )
> > //------------------------//
>
> This sort of misses the issue I was raising. The sort of error
> (not warning)
> I was thinking about would have been raised by the compiler on
> line five of
> the above code (the implementation of the method :go()) because you're
> trying to implement a method that wasn't declared.

After (2001-05-08 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>) you
should now get the desired error reporting.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 20:12:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue May  8 19:12:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
In-Reply-To: <000901c0d7ff$4d155590$2400a8c0@local>
References: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh> <200105081918.f48JIt526571@smtp.parrett.net>
 <000901c0d7ff$4d155590$2400a8c0@local>
Message-ID: <200105082307.f48N7B514873@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Brian Hays" <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Tue, 8
May 2001 13:41:46 -0700

> Unfortunately this is not possible!
> ...

Ah! Now I understand. ADS is a third-party library that has some
internal state values that are similar to some of the Harbour SET values
with no direct way to link the two.

The only thing that I can come up with is to set up some way to
register SET handlers that get called after the Harbour SET function
changes the value of a registered SET value. We could probably borrow
the registration scheme from April's SETKEY handler. Perhaps call it
SETLISTEN and have it take two parameters: 1) The SET to listen for
(null could mean all SETs); 2) The code block to execute when the SET is
changed (null could mean to remove the SET listener). The code block
would take two parameters: 1) The SET that is being changed; 2) The new
value that was just SET.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 21:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (April)
Date: Tue May  8 20:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
References: <000901c0d6ac$99da1860$921a5e18@bh> <200105081918.f48JIt526571@smtp.parrett.net>
 <000901c0d7ff$4d155590$2400a8c0@local> <200105082307.f48N7B514873@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <3AF894E7.10B9B204@mail.rosecom.ca>

"David G. Holm" wrote:

> The only thing that I can come up with is to set up some way to
> register SET handlers that get called after the Harbour SET function
> changes the value of a registered SET value. We could probably borrow
> the registration scheme from April's SETKEY handler. Perhaps call it
> SETLISTEN and have it take two parameters: 1) The SET to listen for
> (null could mean all SETs); 2) The code block to execute when the SET is
> changed (null could mean to remove the SET listener). The code block
> would take two parameters: 1) The SET that is being changed; 2) The new
> value that was just SET.

okay, this is really silly, why not a SET() call itself:
    set monitor|listen SET_DELETED via|with {|| ... }
    set( _SET_MONITOR|_SET_LISTEN, <nSet>, <bBlock> )

I do not know the internals to the set system very much.  Do you think that
multiple 'listen' blocks would be needed against the same event?

ie. if you have ADS & MySQL, you may want two monitors for _SET_DELETED

I ask this because a simply method would be a new element to the hb_set
structure,
but multiple event monitors would not fit this method.

My $0.02 + taxes

April

I just encountered that error message myself. The cause was most
definitely that the CVS/Root and CVS/Repository for my local root
directory hadn't been changed to lower-case. I usually work out of
'Q:/hb/harbour', but my local root is actually 'Q:/hb', which has a CVS
subdirectory.

> > Hmm - this was just after a fresh checkout, so it's either on cvs that way,
> > or I thought possibly an environment varibale on my system, but I can't find
> > anything with the captial 'H' in it.
> 
> Check the 'Root' and 'Repository' files in each and every 'CVS'
> directory in your entire local harbour directory. Start with the root
> directory, as identified by your HOME environment variable. Also check
> your CVSROOT environment variable.

> Do you think that multiple 'listen' blocks would be needed against the same event?

Yes, for the reason you hinted at. ADS is going to require monitors on

RDDs that rely on third-party DLLs might need the same.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May  8 23:36:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue May  8 22:36:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
In-Reply-To: <200105090136.f491aS526643@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEPIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > Do you think that multiple 'listen' blocks would be needed
> against the same event?
> >
> > ie. if you have ADS & MySQL, you may want two monitors for _SET_DELETED
>
> Yes, for the reason you hinted at. ADS is going to require monitors on
> at least _SET_DELETED and _SET_DATEFORMAT and it is possible that other
> RDDs that rely on third-party DLLs might need the same.

I suppose when setting the new listener, we may return the previous listener
if any. Well behaving listener will always call the set listener first
without the block parameter so as to get the current block if any. The Block
they will later set, will execute the block returned as the previous
listener (if any).


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 01:31:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?=)
Date: Wed May  9 00:31:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fwd: Bug report
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIENIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <000801c0d834$af3e5250$f004a8c0@ksoft20000507>

From: "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com>
> >     zm1='index1'
> >     zm2=''
> >     set index to zm1, zm2
> >
> >     (open error .ntx)
> >
> >   (harbour doesn't accept null strings in 'set index to' although
> > it is a valid in Clipper as stated in
> > dbuutil.prg in line 142)
> >
> >          * null strings are acceptable between the commas
> >      SET INDEX TO &k_1,&k_2,&k_3,&k_4,&k_5,&k_6,&k_7
>
> Alexander, Brian, Horacio ?

The set index command should be (as in Clipper):
set index (zm1), (zm2)
In this way the PP generate 'ordListAdd((zm1) )'  instead of
'ordListAdd("zm1" )'.
The older way, with the macro operator should work but in Clipper 5 is not
as good as the other one. Because with the "(zm1)" version there's no macro
evaluation.

I don't know if it was a typo in the mail or or he actually had that in the
program.

I compiled the corrected version with Harbour and I didn't get any runtime
errors.



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 02:14:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?=)
Date: Wed May  9 01:14:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEPIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <001b01c0d837$c28aefa0$f004a8c0@ksoft20000507>

From: "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> I suppose when setting the new listener, we may return the previous
listener
> if any. Well behaving listener will always call the set listener first
> without the block parameter so as to get the current block if any. The
Block
> they will later set, will execute the block returned as the previous
> listener (if any).

I was thinking about that, but I'm not sure it will work.
In the DOS modal way it is ok. My preferred example of this can be the
errorblock in Clipper. When the last subroutine hooked unhooks itself, it
set the previous handler.
But in a non modal situation, what if a middle linked listener wants to
unhook itself?
The reference for it won't be in the SET system but in another routine.

Maybe the SET system could manage the list and return a 'handle' when a
listener is added as a key to remove it later.

regards


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 03:48:02 2001

Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?

Ron,

An what about this situation:

CLASS Hello FROM HelloWorld
   DATA Test
ENDCLASS

function Main()

   ? Hello():New():Go()

return nil

How will you issue a warning there ?

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 04:08:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Wed May  9 03:08:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <001201c0d853$95dc45a0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <001401c0d856$6b02b320$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron,

or even simpler, on Dave's sample:

> function Main()
>
>   local o := HelloWorld()
> 
>    ? o:New():Go()
> 
> return nil

How to issue a warning there ?

There is no way to control that, and we should not
try to control it, or we will turn Harbour into a 
kind of "Force" (rememeber it?), and see where 
"Force" is now...

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 04:15:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Wed May  9 03:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Data and Classdata
In-Reply-To: <3AF80FA2.268.22062A7@localhost>
Message-ID: <3AF90A51.32743.3691668@localhost>

Hi Sylvain,

>  I'm searching a way from Harbour to distinguish DATA from 
> CLASSDATA ?

Could you have a try with the last CVS, I added an optional logical 
param to __objGetMsgList(Oobj, .t. [, lClassMsgOnly] ) so as you 
can retrieve only class DATA. It should help you to check if a 
DATA is a CLASS one or not. 
 
>     My goal is to be sure that there is no Orphan object created by
> the object that just end. But I don't want to DESTROY object that are
> SHARED by the CLASS itself.
> 
>   Code Example:
> 
> Function CleanObj(oObject)
>  Local Adata,x,Valobj
>  Adata:=Aodata(oObject) //This one is faster __objGetMsgList(Oobj,.t.)
>  for x = 1 to Len(Adata)
>    if Valtype(Valobj:=Osend(oObject,adata[x])) =="O"
>      if __ObjHasMethod(valobj,"DESTROY")
>        Valobj:DESTROY()
>      elseif __ObjHasMethod(Valobj,"RELEASE")
>        valobj:RELEASE()
>      elseif __ObjHasMethod(valobj,"END")
>        valobj:END()
>      endif
>    endif
>  Next x
> 
>   Thank you,
> 
>   Sylvain 
> _______________________________________________
> Harbour mailing list
> Harbour@matrixlist.com
> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour
> 
> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
> http://www.Harbour-Project.org
> 
> 



Best regards,

J. Lefebvre <jflefebv@mafact.com>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 04:39:25 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May  9 03:39:25 2001
Subject: [Harbour] EXPORT: in class definition
In-Reply-To: <200105082006.f48K6o911237@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>; from jfl@wanadoo.be on Tue, May 08, 2001 at 10:07:12PM +0200
References: <20010508181852.X1231@hagbard.davep.org> <200105082006.f48K6o911237@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <20010509074912.D1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 08, 2001 at 10:07:12PM +0200, JF Lefebvre wrote:
> Hi Dave
> 
> > Is there a reason why hbclass.ch, when in "Class(y) compatibility mode",
> > supports "EXPORTED:" as a scope directive but doesn't support "EXPORT:"?
> 
> My class(y) version 2.4b also doesn't support it ! Maybe I'm missing
> something.

>From my Class(y) documentation:

,----
|  EXPORT:
|  
|  Synopsis
|  
|          Cause subsequent messages to be exported
|  
|  Syntax
|  
|          EXPORT:
|  
|  Description
|  
|          This command causes subsequent variable, message and method
|          declarations in a class specification to be exported, ie. made
|          accessible to methods and functions outside of the class.
|  
|  See Also
|  
|          HIDDEN:, PROTECTED:
|  
`----

IIRC EXPORTED: is also supported. Now this documentation claims to be for
v2.0a but I'm sure I've got a later version installed. 

*All* of my classes (and I've got lots of classes in my systems) use
 EXPORT:, not EXPORTED:.

Ok, I've double checked things on my WinDos machine:

,----[ foo.txt ]
| D:\home\davep\x> cat foo.prg
| #include "class(y).ch"
| 
| Function Main()
| 
|    TestVersion():new():print()
| 
| Return( NIL )
| 
| /////
| 
| Create Class TestVersion
| 
|    Export:
| 
|       Method print
| 
| End Class
| 
| /////
| 
| Method print
| 
|    ? csyVersion()
| 
| Return( self )
| 
| D:\home\davep\x> foo
| 
| 2.4
`----

As you can see, I've got a 2.4<x> version installed and EXPORT: is supported
as a scope declaration.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 05:31:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May  9 04:31:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] More hbclass.ch and -W3
In-Reply-To: <20010508155432.T1231@hagbard.davep.org>; from davep@davep.org on Tue, May 08, 2001 at 03:54:32PM +0100
References: <20010508155432.T1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <20010509092735.L1231@hagbard.davep.org>

I've just noticed a couple more instances of -W3 giving incorrect warnings
in regard to OO code. Consider this correct and working code:

,----[ foo.prg ]
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Function Main()
| 
|    ? Testing():new():className
| 
| Return( NIL )
| 
`----

Compiling it with -W3 gives the following warning (I've snipped the warnings
about METACLASS and NSCOPE as I've reported them before):

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour foo -n -p -W3
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo.prg' and generating preprocessed output to 'foo.ppo'...
| foo.prg(8) Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in class 'TESTING'
| Lines 13, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'foo.c'... Done.
`----

:new() might not be declared but it is a valid message (hmm, thinking about
it I guess this is just another example of -W3 not being able to cope with
inheritance?).

Also, consider this correct and working code:

,----[ foo.prg ]
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Function Main()
| 
|    ? Testing():className
| 
| Return( NIL )
`----

Compiling that with -W3 (with METACLASS and NSCOPE problems snipped) gives:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour foo -n -p -W3
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo.prg' and generating preprocessed output to 'foo.ppo'...
| foo.prg(8) Warning W0026  Message 'CLASSNAME' not known in class 'TESTING'
| Lines 13, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'foo.c'... Done.
`----

PS: Isn't it about time we updated the year of the copyright message that's
output by the compiler?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 05:31:16 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May  9 04:31:16 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Possible to raise error when implemented method isn't declared?
In-Reply-To: <20010509074036.C1231@hagbard.davep.org>; from davep@davep.org on Wed, May 09, 2001 at 07:40:36AM +0100
References: <20010507210735.B1231@hagbard.davep.org> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEPGDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <20010509074036.C1231@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <20010509091915.K1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, May 09, 2001 at 07:40:36AM +0100, Dave Pearson wrote:
> On Tue, May 08, 2001 at 03:48:10PM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:
>
> > After (2001-05-08 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>) you
> > should now get the desired error reporting.
> 
> Thanks Ron, I'll have a play sometime today.

This works:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.prg
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Method foo
| Return( self )
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour foo -n
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo.prg'...
| foo.prg(6) Error E0010  #error: 'NOT DECLARED METHOD "foo"'
| 1 error
| 
| No code generated
`----

But this doesn't:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.prg
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Method foo Class Testing
| Return( self )
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour foo -n
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo.prg'...
| Lines 9, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'foo.c'... Done.
`----

Can I also suggest a friendlier error message? At the very least one that
doesn't shout (I don't think other compiler errors do) and, if possible one
that gives the name of the class that's involved.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 05:33:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Wed May  9 04:33:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] EXPORT: in class definition
In-Reply-To: <20010509074912.D1231@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <200105082006.f48K6o911237@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>; from jfl@wanadoo.be on Tue, May 08, 2001 at 10:07:12PM +0200
Message-ID: <3AF91C3D.19059.3AF19C1@localhost>

Hi Dave

> On Tue, May 08, 2001 at 10:07:12PM +0200, JF Lefebvre wrote:
> > Hi Dave
> > 
> > > Is there a reason why hbclass.ch, when in "Class(y) compatibility
> > > mode", supports "EXPORTED:" as a scope directive but doesn't
> > > support "EXPORT:"?
> > 
> > My class(y) version 2.4b also doesn't support it ! Maybe I'm missing
> > something.

You are rigth, the doc indicate it as you pointed but I can't find any 
entries within the include files. (I don't do the test you do, but I'm 
nearly sure it should work as indicated by the doc, so I'm surely 
missing something ;-) )
 
I will add it probably tonigh.

Thanks for the info,

> From my Class(y) documentation:
> 
> ,----
> |  EXPORT:
> |  
> |  Synopsis
> |  
> |          Cause subsequent messages to be exported
> |  
> |  Syntax
> |  
> |          EXPORT:
> |  
> |  Description
> |  
> |          This command causes subsequent variable, message and method
> |          declarations in a class specification to be exported, ie.
> made |          accessible to methods and functions outside of the
> class. |  |  See Also |  |          HIDDEN:, PROTECTED: |  `----
> 
> IIRC EXPORTED: is also supported. Now this documentation claims to be
> for v2.0a but I'm sure I've got a later version installed. 
> 
> *All* of my classes (and I've got lots of classes in my systems) use
>  EXPORT:, not EXPORTED:.
> 
> Ok, I've double checked things on my WinDos machine:
> 
> ,----[ foo.txt ]
> | D:\home\davep\x> cat foo.prg
> | #include "class(y).ch"
> | 
> | Function Main()
> | 
> |    TestVersion():new():print()
> | 
> | Return( NIL )
> | 
> | /////
> | 
> | Create Class TestVersion
> | 
> |    Export:
> | 
> |       Method print
> | 
> | End Class
> | 
> | /////
> | 
> | Method print
> | 
> |    ? csyVersion()
> | 
> | Return( self )
> | 
> | D:\home\davep\x> foo
> | 
> | 2.4
> `----
> 
> As you can see, I've got a 2.4<x> version installed and EXPORT: is
> supported as a scope declaration.
> 
> --

> functions. http://www.davep.org/               |     eg - Norton Guide

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 06:10:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May  9 05:10:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Pre-processor incompatibility (Was: EXPORT: in class definition)
In-Reply-To: <3AF91C3D.19059.3AF19C1@localhost>; from jflefebv@mafact.be on Wed, May 09, 2001 at 10:30:21AM +0200
References: <200105082006.f48K6o911237@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>; <20010509074912.D1231@hagbard.davep.org> <3AF91C3D.19059.3AF19C1@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010509100923.M1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, May 09, 2001 at 10:30:21AM +0200, jflefebv@mafact.be wrote:

> You are rigth, the doc indicate it as you pointed but I can't find any
> entries within the include files. (I don't do the test you do, but I'm
> nearly sure it should work as indicated by the doc, so I'm surely missing
> something ;-) )

I don't have an entry for EXPORT: in my Class(y) include files either. This
is because EXPORTED: is done as a #command, not a #xcommand. For example:

,----
| D:\home\davep\x> type foo.prg
| #command EXPORTED: => ? "This would export"
| 
| exported:
| exporte:
| export:
| expor:
| expo:
| 
| D:\home\davep\x> clipper foo /p
| Clipper (R) 5.2e
| Copyright (c) 1985-1995, Computer Associates International, Inc.
| Microsoft C Floating Point Support Routines
| Copyright (c) Microsoft Corp 1984-1987.  All Rights Reserved.
| 330K available
| Compiling FOO.PRG
| Code size 86, Symbols 48, Constants 90
| 
| D:\home\davep\x> type foo.ppo
| 
| 
| QOut( "This would export" )
| QOut( "This would export" )
| QOut( "This would export" )
| QOut( "This would export" )
| QOut( "This would export" )
`----

I'd not thought about it before but the colon is "preserved" in the matching
of a #command. Interesting.

What is even more interesting is that harbour doesn't seem to be able to
cope with the above test at all well:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.prg
| #command EXPORTED: => ? "This would export"
| 
| exported:
| exporte:
| export:
| expor:
| expo:
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ harbour foo
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo.prg'...
| foo.prg(3) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(4) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(5) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(6) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(7) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| 5 errors
| 
| No code generated
`----

Pre-processor bug? The PPO output would suggest it is:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.ppo
| 
| 
| exported:
| exporte:
| export:
| expor:
| expo:
`----

I note that EXPORTED: is done as an #xtranslate in hbclass.ch (unlike
Class(y).ch doing it as a #command). Even then, #translate in harbour
doesn't seem to cope very well at all:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.prg
| #translate EXPORTED: => ? "This would export"
| 
| exported:
| exporte:
| export:
| expor:
| expo:
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ harbour foo -p
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'foo.prg' and generating preprocessed output to 'foo.ppo'...
| foo.prg(4) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(5) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(6) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| foo.prg(7) Error E0030  Syntax error: "parse error at '<eol>'"
| 4 errors
| 
| No code generated
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.ppo
| 
| 
| QOut("This would export" )
| exporte:
| export:
| expor:
| expo:
`----

This seems like a pretty significant incompatibility with CA-Clipper's
pre-processor.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

Subject: [Harbour] Changelog 2001-05-06 12:00
