Dave,

> Check the 'Root' and 'Repository' files in each and every 'CVS'
> directory in your entire local harbour directory. Start with the root
> directory, as identified by your HOME environment variable. Also check
> your CVSROOT environment variable.

Is this in the FAQ yet?

Also, the .cvspass (or whatever it's called).

If you could add a suggested way for a "typical" [1] Clipper user to
make the changes it would be really useful I suspect.

[1] someone who edits in a DOS box on Windows, and may well have an
editor which doesn't handle long file names.  Assume they do not have
access to (POSIX?) tools such as "find" -- any "find" they have will
be the DOS one. :-(

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 14:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Sylvain Robert )
Date: Wed May  9 13:02:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Data and Classdata
In-Reply-To: <3AF90A51.32743.3691668@localhost>
References: <3AF80FA2.268.22062A7@localhost>
Message-ID: <3AF93D88.24606.20B14B@localhost>

Jean,
> Could you have a try with the last CVS, I added an optional logical 
> param to __objGetMsgList(Oobj, .t. [, lClassMsgOnly] ) so as you 
> can retrieve only class DATA. It should help you to check if a 
> DATA is a CLASS one or not. 

__ObjGetMsgList(Oobt,.t.,.t.) give the CLASSDATA Message !. So 
I have to compare the result of each call (one to FALSE and one to 
TRUE) to know wich DATA is owned by the Object !

  Just my opinion, but if lClassMsgOnly was lObjectMsgOnly it will be
  more Helpfull or we can replace .T. or .F. with:

            1 == Object Msg   (default)
            2 == Classes Msg
            3 == Both Msg

  What do you think ?

  Sylvain

Dave,

Either there were reasons or no reasons, I would say that it is no
sin for us to follow the current configuration. Figuring out that
SourceForge is a structure and we are only one amongst its thousand
members I would say that it would not be too nice if we are going to
stick to something [1]. Following the current configuration, in my part
is a-no-problem now. So, searching for reasons would not be 
reasonable (IMHO) [2], considering that there has been no more complaint
from the list members with regards to the changes.

Andi

[1] Go back to the previous CVS params before now.
[2] Better go searching reasons why Harbour is yet to be a beta.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 15:15:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed May  9 14:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEPIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200105090136.f491aS526643@smtp.parrett.net> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEPIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <200105091810.f49IAZ501539@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Tue, 8
May 2001 19:39:10 -0700

> I suppose when setting the new listener, we may return the previous listener
> if any. Well behaving listener will always call the set listener first
> without the block parameter so as to get the current block if any. The Block
> they will later set, will execute the block returned as the previous
> listener (if any).

Why would you want to design SET listener handling in such a way that
all RDDs that use it must reply on all other RDD's that use it having
properly implemented SET listener chaining? If the SET listener is
designed in such a way that it's behaviour is compromised by a sloppy
RDD, then it is of no use. The SET listener handler must allow for
multiple listeners to be registered.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 15:17:02 2001

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May  9 16:01:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May  9 15:01:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Changelog 2001-05-06 12:00
In-Reply-To: <0118620010510004159251948@ANDIJAHJA.ORG>; from andijahja@cbn.net.id on Thu, May 10, 2001 at 12:42:03AM +0700
References: <20010509173422.Q1231@hagbard.davep.org> <0118620010510004159251948@ANDIJAHJA.ORG>
Message-ID: <20010509200019.S1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 12:42:03AM +0700, Andi Jahja wrote:
> Reply message to Dave Pearson:
> 
> >Phil, did you get any reason for the change out of SourceForge?
> 
> Dave,
> 
> Either there were reasons or no reasons, I would say that it is no sin for
> us to follow the current configuration.

The fact that I voted to stay with the change should give you a hint that I
agree. The reason I ask isn't because I desire any course of action but
because, as a developer and a system admin, I'm curious as to the reason for
such a flag-day change to the environment provided to us my SourceForge.

Remember, a directory on a case-sensitive file system was change with no
warning. Was that change made on purpose by SourceForge admins? Was it made
by accident? Was it part of a wider policy? Did their communication systems
break down which means that we didn't get told about it? If a directory was
renamed what about files elsewhere on the server (Makefile and makefile are,
as you know, two different files).

>                                                 Figuring out that
> SourceForge is a structure and we are only one amongst its thousand
> members I would say that it would not be too nice if we are going to stick
> to something [1]. Following the current configuration, in my part is
> a-no-problem now. So, searching for reasons would not be reasonable (IMHO)
> [2], considering that there has been no more complaint from the list
> members with regards to the changes.

SourceForge itself is a free software project and is a community backed
project. Failure to contact the SourceForge admins to find out the cause for
the change is a failure to support free software in general.

--

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 06:15:04 2001

References: <3AFA418D.4243@synel.co.il>

http://sourceforge.net/docman/display_doc.php?docid=2352&group_id=1

(2001-04-23)   On 2001-05-01, all symlinks for
               mixed-case versions of project names will be
               removed. If you were formerly accessing your project
               CVS repository at /cvsroot/ProjectName, it will now
               be necessary to access the repository at
               /cvsroot/projectname. Note that this only affects the
               CVSROOT path and will not affect any of the
               repository contents themselves.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 15:12:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu May 10 14:12:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Set() and the RDD
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEPIDLAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <001b01c0d837$c28aefa0$f004a8c0@ksoft20000507> <200105091812.f49ICi501727@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <012101c0d97d$a0caf990$921a5e18@bh>

I agree.  Getting a handle back would allow removal of the hook without
dependence on other processes.

But the modal/modeless aka event-driven environment observation goes a bit
further: dependence upon a global setting for things like SET DELETED
becomes more and more unbearable--I don't see any way multiple threads would
be reliable if they alter this setting.
I believe it was Ryszard who proposed allowing an RDD- or Table-specific
setting for SET DELETED. Perhaps this would be a 3-way switch to default to
the global setting if not explicitly set.

Meanwhile, posting a "monitor" codeblock to Set() and being able to remove
it would be a great enhancement.

Brian

----- Original Message -----
> Maybe the SET system could manage the list and return a 'handle' when a
> listener is added as a key to remove it later.

Good idea!
--
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 15:46:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu May 10 14:46:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Warning!!! Latest hbclass.ch changes
In-Reply-To: <001501c0d97e$e671d3a0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Thu, May 10, 2001 at 08:27:42PM +0200
References: <20010510192151.Q1231@hagbard.davep.org> <001501c0d97e$e671d3a0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010510194545.R1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 08:27:42PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > That's what you get for using alpha quality software, it can change at any
> > moment. ;>
> 
> Well... I have a different point of view...
> 
> The first rule of software development:
> "If something works ok, then leave it as it is..." :-)

Then your point of view isn't any different from mine. However, harbour is
still under development. A free software project that is still in the alpha
stages of development shouldn't start acting conservative in case it breaks
existing code out there because the people who wrote that existing code
wrote it with full knowledge and understand of the state of that item of
free software.

If harbour can be improved but that improvement requires that some software
gets broken in the short term (note that I'm talking about non CA-Clipper
derived features here) then hopefully the authors of that software will see
the value in this and adjust their software accordingly.

Double the above paragraph when the software that's making use of the free
software is non-free.

IOW, the rule you state is anti-initial-development. It only works for
stable software. Harbour is far from stable.

--

to CVS, it should be "in-deep" __TESTED__ (Ron!!!).

the false impression that CVS code is still unmatured.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 17:52:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu May 10 16:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Warning!!! Latest hbclass.ch changes
In-Reply-To: <001801c0d98c$75bc56e0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Thu, May 10, 2001 at 10:04:46PM +0200
References: <20010510194545.R1231@hagbard.davep.org> <001801c0d98c$75bc56e0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010510211534.S1231@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 10:04:46PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > However, harbour is still under development. 
> 
> Harbour will be always under development.

But there's a big difference between initial development and onward
development. There's a zero in the major version number position of the last
release of harbour for good reason. They'll be a zero there come the next
release too (I hope).

> > Harbour is far from stable.
> 
> That's just your opinion. I don't agree with you.
> 
> Our tests here shows Harbour is working really fine.

This isn't my opinion, it's a fact, and a documented fact at that. 

The latter sentence suggests you think I'm talking about the actual
technical stability of harbour, I'm not. I'm talking about the status of
harbour. Anyone using harbour at the moment should treat it as unstable
software. If it acts stable that's a bonus.

As for talking about the "real world", I wonder where you think I live and
work...

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 18:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu May 10 17:02:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Warning!!! Latest hbclass.ch changes
In-Reply-To: <001901c0d98e$59fe5f00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Thu, May 10, 2001 at 10:18:18PM +0200
References: <001801c0d98c$75bc56e0$0f2aa8c0@antonio> <001901c0d98e$59fe5f00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010510220126.A851@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 10:18:18PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> As far as I see it, before an "in-deep" change it is uploaded to CVS, it
> should be "in-deep" __TESTED__ (Ron!!!).

I agree that changes should be tested to the best of the ability of the
author of that change. I doubt that anyone would disagree. But, mistakes
happen from time to time <shrug>.

That's off the track of what I was really getting at and that is if
something changed, for the better, that in the short term broke a load of
code, that's to be expected as harbour is still being designed and honed.

Anyone writing code that relies on harbour must be able to cope with this
and must be willing to put up with the aggravation because harbour is still
unstable (to emphasise: unstable in a tectonic sense, not a "ability to run
for a short time" sense, IOW it is potentially a moving target in regards to
features that aren't handed down from CA-Clipper).

> Because if not, then it will break many people code, giving the false
> impression that CVS code is still unmatured.

Bugs happen <shrug>. Anyone getting a "false impression" from CVS isn't
really mentally equipped to be pulling code from CVS and shouldn't probably
stop doing so right away. Everyone else will either be looking to fix the
problem themselves and donate the fix back or they'll know that a fix will
be forthcoming after they've reported the problem (not to mention the fact
that they can roll back to a previous version of the broken file).

> We have been working here on Harbour, so hard, to give users a false
> impression.

Anyone getting this sort of false impression is probably looking for an
excuse to see harbour in a bad light anyway. Anyone else will have read the
web page, read the FAQ, read the documentation and will know that harbour is
software that is under development and that anonymous CVS access is granted
to those people on the understanding that they demonstrate that they have a
clue.

Anyone likely to get a false impression should be using the binary
distributions of the "stable" snapshots, AKA "releases".

Anyone left after all of that will have me giving them a hard time if they
start to winge and complain about the quality of harbour, thus demonstrating
that they don't deserve to have you guys developing free software on their
behalf.

[I've deleted the smiley at the end of that last paragraph 'cos I'm not
 really joking, I don't have time for people who can't take free software at
 face value and won't accept the responsibility thats handed to them when
 they are allowed the privilege of anonymous CVS access to the sources.]

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 18:11:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Thu May 10 17:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Alaska XBase++ devcon 2001
Message-ID: <3AFB03BD.4B41C22@libero.it>

Guys,

I've been to Alaska DevCon2001 which was held in Casale Monferrato
(north of Italy, near Turin) last week and I'd like to try to tell you
what I've seen and to which conclusions I've come.

1) They're trying to reposition XBase++ as a full fledged compiler (like
VB or Delphi) and to this end they're asking everyone to leave the old
RDD api and to move to ODBC (they say ODBC 3.x is really fast and
stable) or DAC (Data Access Chain) upon which XBase++ RDD api is built.

2) They will have Visual XBase++ ready at the end of this year (or the
beginning of next). In Casale they showed a very alpha level
VisualEditor which resembles Delphi's one. Visual XBase++ will have an
editor which shares its window with compiler and debugger so that it
compiles code as you type it and debugs it at the same time.

3) They won't port Xbase++ to linux because, at this time, there is not
customer demand. If there will be such a demand they say they can port
it in a six to nine months time frame (this is, in my opinion and as a
long time OS/2 user, a really too many times heard answer :-(( ). I
think that the fact that harbour is really multi platform (and available
under linux) is our _only_ strength compared to XBase++.

4) There are 11,000 users of XBase++ or better  they sold so many copies
of XBase++

All in all they're trying to move out of a clipper compatible tool to
port old code from dos to windows and into a fully general purpose
language with strong data handling capabilities.

I think we really need to finish our RDD api (and now, I'd say, to
enhance ODBC and have a compatible DAC layer) and have threads and a
portable gui library or else we won't be able to attract users. XBase++
is really growing with each new version and is, all in all, a good
product.


regards.

Maurilio.


PS. They won't update OS/2 version of XBase++ anymore :-(((


--

 __________
|  |  | |__| md2520@mclink.it
|_|_|_|____| Team OS/2 Italia



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 18:23:02 2001

References: <3AFB03BD.4B41C22@libero.it>
Message-ID: <3AFB068D.9B0C1DCD@libero.it>

Oh, I like to repeat it one more time:

these are _my conclusions_ based upon what _I_'ve understood of devcon's
sessions.

In _no way_ they should be considered as Alaska's confirmed plans or
commitments to any particular product or service.

Ok, this is my fine printing :-)))

regards.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 22:37:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu May 10 21:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Cygwin DLL 1.3.1
Message-ID: <200105110132.f4B1We528232@smtp.parrett.net>

Is anybody successfully compiling Harbour with GTWIN using a full-blown
Cygwin installation with Cygwin DLL version 1.3.1 and building from the
bash shell? I ask because I have no problem if I start the build from an
NT command line, but if I start the build from the bash shell, then GTWIN
won't build, starting with a parse error on line 107, which is the first
use of the typedef HANDLE in gtwin.c. Following are the contents of my
build.sh script:

export CVSROOT=:ext:dholm@cvs.harbour-project.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/harbour-project
export CVS_RSH=ssh
export HOME=/cygdrive/q/hb/
export HOMEDRIVE=/cygdrive/q
export HOMEPATH=/hb/
export HARBOURDIR=Q:/hb/harbour
export HB_ARCHITECTURE=w32
export HB_COMPILER=gcc
export HB_GT_LIB=gtwin
export BISON_SIMPLE=/cygdrive/q/hb/bison.simple
export HB_BIN_INSTALL=/cygdrive/q/COMMON/WEBSITE/Harbour/w32/gcc
export HB_LIB_INSTALL=/cygdrive/q/COMMON/WEBSITE/Harbour/w32/gcc
export HB_INC_INSTALL=NUL
make -r
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 10 23:33:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu May 10 22:33:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-10 14:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3AFB068D.9B0C1DCD@libero.it>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAJDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-10 14:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * include/hbclass.ch
     - Removed 1 #translate that caused conflicts discovered with FWH.
     + Refined logic detecting undeclared method and improved messages.
     + Added logic for STRICT (#ifdef STRICT_OO) validation (all parameters
must match too)
     + Added logic for normal (default) validation (parameters are ignored).

   * source/compiler/harbour.sly
   * source/compiler/harbour.y
     + Added support for dummy parameters to function pointer ( @SomeFun(
DummyParam ) )

   * source/vm/hvm.c
   * source/compiler/hbpcode.c
     ! Corrected 1 compiler warning.

   * source/pp/ppcore.c
     + Added support for #defines in #error messages.

   * source/debug/debugger.prg
     - Remmed orphan method (discovered by new compiler error)
CaseSensitive() which is apparently superceded by ToggleCaseSensitive().
   * utils/hbdoc/ffile1.prg
     - Remmed orphan method (discovered by new compiler error) GetBuff()
which is routed to GetBuffer() in class declaration
     - Remmed orphan method (discovered by new compiler error) fClose()
which is not declared and default to Super in class declaration.

   /* These were discovered with the default LOOSE mode. When using
/dSTRICT_OO many more inconsistencies are discovered! */


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 03:31:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Martin Vogel)

Message-ID: <008301c0d9e4$87622160$decbce81@martinvogel>

>But i think ( some times ;-) ... and have an idea... the algoritm for a zip
>cannot be used too in that function to compress an string ?.. so, the zip,
>compress a file, but i think that, to compress a file, should read the file
>by blocks and compress each block, then, manage a simple string like a
block
>of file....


Indeed, I also think that the algorithms used in charpack() and the zip
program are quite similar. But my goal is to provide a 100% compatible
charpack() function so that people can use their packed data in Harbour !

P.S.: Crazy ideas are sometimes the most innovative ones !



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 03:31:13 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Martin Vogel)
Date: Fri May 11 02:31:13 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Alaska XBase++ devcon 2001
Message-ID: <008401c0d9e4$885de680$decbce81@martinvogel>

Maurilio,

I think no one doubts that Xbase++ is a good product (I have seen many many
software products that were much worse - can't name them because I forget
the bad products :-)) If it's growing and makes its users happy - that's
great for them but also for us. Why ? Because the Xbase language dialects
are regaining some "territory" (acceptance, reputation etc.) that they have
lost in the last years. And because it gives us new ideas what to implement
in Harbour (like you suggested).

Do you really think we are in a competitional situation with Alaska/Xbase++
? Maybe _they_ think we are. So what ? That's not our problem. We shouldn't
think that we have to compete with Alaska. We don't have to. We are writing
a free open-source cross-platform clipper/xbase language compiler. "Free"
and "open source", that means that _you_ can add those features to the
language you need. Cross-platform: Need Harbour on XYZ's platform ? Port it
or ask someone for help. With a little luck you get it within days. Don't
have to wait for companies or depend on their strategic decisions (what if I
have to write a linux application with XBase++ _now_ ? I am lost, am I ?).
You see those advantages, I know that. So let's start from there and make
Harbour the tool _we_ want to have. And, there is enough space for two xbase
compilers in town :-)))

Yes, Harbour will have threads. Not because Xbase++ has them, but because
they are useful. Yes, after finishing the RDDs we can/shold think about a
new abstract data manipulation layer for ODBC, DAO, DAC and how all these
"store data, manipulate data, retrieve data" systems are called (I sometimes
wonder if there really is a big _technical_ progress not just a change of
names, sigh !)

And if you need an online editor/syntax checker/compiler, go ahead, write
it. Sell it or release it under the GPL (thereas the latter may be Dave's
preferred wish :-)).

Harbour is great, and wíll be even greater in the future. Watch it growing
and be sure that there will never be a company that will stop Harbour from
existing. Can't be better.

My 2 cents.

Regards

Martin

isn't the only free software or open source licence out there (see today's
slashdot for a reminder about this).

References: <3AFB068D.9B0C1DCD@libero.it> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEAJDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010511092945.E851@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 07:37:09PM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> 2001-05-10 14:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>

Would I be right in assuming that this change should, in part, address the
issues I raised in <20010509091915.K1231@hagbard.davep.org>? 

[In this regard can I suggest that when people fix problems that are
 reported via the list it might be an idea to reply to that report to say
 that the latest changes should address the problem? Or, failing that, have
 the ChangeLog announcement make it clear that any change addresses a
 problem reported by "J. Random Bug-Reporter" so that he/she knows that they
 can re-test and report their findings and that doing so won't be an
 exercise in generating extra bug reports that aren't necessary.]

As it is, those changes do seem to address the main bug that I reported in
<20010509091915.K1231@hagbard.davep.org>, so there's just the question of
the error reporting that I asked. I see that the error no longer shouts but
the question about the error being informative still stands. Given this:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat realworld1.prg
| // Compile with -W3, it should moan that `foo' isn't declared as part of
| // `Testing'.
| 
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Method foo
| Return( self )
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour realworld1 -n -W3
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'realworld1.prg'...
| realworld1.prg(9) Error E0010  'Not declared method: foo '
| realworld1.prg(9) Warning W0003  Variable: 'METACLASS' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(6)'
| realworld1.prg(9) Warning W0003  Variable: 'NSCOPE' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(6)'
| 1 error
| 
| No code generated
`----

is it possible to have that E0010 error actually give the name of the class
involved? Perhaps something like:

,----
| realword1.prg(9} Error E0010 'Method foo is not declared as a member of class Testing'
`----

Is that possible?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 06:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Martin Vogel)
Date: Fri May 11 05:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Alaska XBase++ devcon 2001
References: <008401c0d9e4$885de680$decbce81@martinvogel> <3AFB8CF5.70BAAA05@libero.it>
Message-ID: <3AFBB694.2617211A@urz.uni-heidelberg.de>

Maurilio,

> I agree with you on a lot of your points, but I do think that we and Alaska are
> in competition and competition is not a bad thing. We are competing for the

Yes, you are right, in some situations, competition is not a bad thing.
As I mentioned, the xbase language itself can profit from the existence
of more than one compiler. People can then trust that the language they
use will survive with higher probability (and with Harbour this is
nearly guaranteed since it's open software - as long as anyone (even a
single person) wants harbour to exist and to grow, it will!).

But I think it is dangerous if we believe we are in a war or struggle
position: Alaska on one side, we on the other. This is destructive
because this may lead to a showing off and not to good software. Harbour
is an alternative (and not an exclusive one), a second (or first, how
you like it) option, but a different one since its free software and
thus has a totally different architecture. I contribute to Harbour but
may also use Xbase++ in the future. No reason why not. If Xbase++ suits
for a specific project ? This is a great freedom for me!
As we can profit from Alaska, they can profit from Harbour (don't know
if they have realized that). Exchange of ideas. Innovating the xbase
language. Giving the whole xbase community the feeling that the xbase
horse is the right one to bet on.

> clipper language "market". If every one who needs a clipper compiler uses
> XBase++ then nobody will contribute to the harbour project.

Do you believe that this will happen ? Consider that the people
contributing to Harbour are doing that _although_ XBase++ exists. At
least these people will use Harbour. We might get some newbies and their
experience from the free software or LINUX communities (do they now the
clipper language and its power at all ? The existence of a free compiler
might attract some people !). Some XBase++ users might "change", some
may use both. Some Harbour users will change to XBase++ because they
will get the feature "QWERT" there. This again might be an inspiration
for us to implement this feature or even a better one. Not because we
want annoy Alaska, but because we feel that this is a good feature for
Harbour, too.

> I was reporting what I saw at devcon and not saying that they're better
> (cleverer, smarter) than us :-))

It's good that you reported that to us because this gives us
inspirations, e.g. I like the idea of an editor with online compiler. 
But I had the feeling that you were in the same mood I am when I am
coming back from a conference, having the idea that all the others are
so good and I am so bad. Well, this is rubbish and you know it. Everyone
can cook with water only (as we say in Germany).

Harbour will live very long!

Regards

Martin

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 10:19:14 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri May 11 09:19:14 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Alaska XBase++ devcon 2001
In-Reply-To: <003e01c0da12$72ebdae0$93dad7c8@luizguim>; from culik@nh.conex.com.br on Fri, May 11, 2001 at 08:16:08AM -0300
References: <008401c0d9e4$885de680$decbce81@martinvogel> <20010511074019.C851@hagbard.davep.org> <3AFBA0D9.A1D46E6B@urz.uni-heidelberg.de> <003e01c0da12$72ebdae0$93dad7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <20010511134139.A8945@hagbard.davep.org>

[I think we're heading into harbour-talk territory here]

On Fri, May 11, 2001 at 08:16:08AM -0300, Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes wrote:

> If you both can access, give an look on the local.fivewin.portuguese forum
> of the news.fivetech.com.
> For an thread with Subject  "Quantos Somos?"

Given that I don't speak Portuguese it's unlikely that it'll make any sense
to me.

> They say that harbour+fwh will only be stable when harbour can access
> oracle,mysql, and other database relational forms, and harbour also has an
> IDE for development.

"They" seem to be mistaken. What they're talking about here isn't stability,
they're talking about applicability for their problems. That's a very
different thing. They also need to learn to separate Harbour from a non-free
third party product too. Harbour shouldn't reflect on that product and that
product shouldn't reflect on harbour.

Moreover, the whole point of harbour is that if it doesn't do what someone
wants it to do they should either a) make it do it or b) make someone an
attractive offer to make harbour do it for them.

Presumably these people are people who see "free software" and think the
free means "no cost".

As for an IDE, why would a compiler, VM and RTL need an IDE? How strange.

. o O ( Just what the world needs. Another IDE. )

--

FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

   * include/hbclass.ch
     + Added logic for NO Checking of OO Syntax (#ifdef NO_OO_ERR) - Use
/dNO_OO_ERR to disable OO Syntax Checking.

   * source/pp/ppcore.c
     * Temporarily disabled support of #define expansion in #error
directive.


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 11:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri May 11 10:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch keeps failing (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000201c0da25$d0d46740$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, May 11, 2001 at 04:22:31PM +0200

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 12:05:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri May 11 11:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch keeps failing (Ron)

Dave,

> For the benefit of those of use who don't use FiveWin: is the method in
> question actually declared as a member of the associated class?

Yes, it is:

   ERROR HANDLER OnError( cMsg, nError )

...

   METHOD OnError( uParam1 ) CLASS TDataBase

(the missing nError param here is a Harbour missing feature
we already reported).

Antonio

> > question actually declared as a member of the associated class?

> Yes, it is:

> 
> ...

Ahh, right. presumably Ron's changes don't accept an error handler
declaration as a method declaration.

Ron, if you're reading this, testing that here, with -W3, it shows up
another problem with -W3 and classes:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat realworld3.prg
| // Compile with -W3, it should moan that `foo' isn't declared as part of
| // `Testing'.
| 
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| 
|    Error Handler onError( cMsg, nError )
| 
| End Class
| 
| Method onError
| Return( self )
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour realworld3 -n -W3
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'realworld3.prg'...
| realworld3.prg(8) Warning W0026  Message 'SETONERROR' not known in class 'TCLASS'
| realworld3.prg(12) Error E0010  'Not declared method: onError '
| realworld3.prg(12) Warning W0003  Variable: 'METACLASS' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(6)'
| realworld3.prg(12) Warning W0003  Variable: 'NSCOPE' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(6)'
| 1 error
| 
| No code generated
`----

that warning about SETONERROR probably should be there.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 13:44:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 11 12:44:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-11 09:00 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEANDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEAODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-11 09:00 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * include/hbclass.ch
     ! Fixed declaration support for OnError() METHODS
     ! Fixed support for Methods having space prefixing the "( ... )" in the
method implementation.
     + Refined #error messages to report the Class Name.

   * source/pp/ppcore.c
     * Removed recently added but not required support of #define expansion
in #error directive.

Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-10 14:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <20010511092945.E851@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEBCDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> > 2001-05-10 14:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
>
> Would I be right in assuming that this change should, in part, address the
> issues I raised in <20010509091915.K1231@hagbard.davep.org>?

Yes.

> [In this regard can I suggest that when people fix problems that are
>  reported via the list it might be an idea to reply to that report to say
>  that the latest changes should address the problem? Or, failing
> that, have
>  the ChangeLog announcement make it clear that any change addresses a
>  problem reported by "J. Random Bug-Reporter" so that he/she
> knows that they
>  can re-test and report their findings and that doing so won't be an
>  exercise in generating extra bug reports that aren't necessary.]

Sure. I attempted to do so (as I normally do), but I'm having enormous
problems with _sending_ email. My ISP changed their SMTP configuration, and
I still get very intermittent performance. As you can see, my attempts to
post the ChangeLog notices appeared many hours after I actually posted them.
Every time my mailer attempted to a send a message it was chocking for
hours. As a result I only tried to send the ChangeLog notices.

> As it is, those changes do seem to address the main bug that I reported in
> <20010509091915.K1231@hagbard.davep.org>, so there's just the question of
> the error reporting that I asked. I see that the error no longer
> shouts but
> the question about the error being informative still stands.

Done.

Here is a brief description of the new #error messages. Given this sample:

//-------------------------------------------------------//
#include "hbclass.ch"

Create Class HelloWorld // Class defined first!
   Method DecGo
   Method DecGo2()
End Class

Method DecGo(n) CLASS HelloWorld // Note: Parameter N was not declared.
   ? "Hello, World"
Return( self )

Method Go() // Not declared.
   ? "Hello, World"
Return( self )

Method DecGo2() // CLASS Clause is now optional.
   ? "Hello, World"
Return( self )

Method Go2(N) CLASS HelloWorld // Not declared.
   ? "Hello, World"
Return( self )

Method Other CLASS NoClass // Class NoClass never created!
   ? "Hello, World"
Return( self )
//-------------------------------------------------------//

1. Normal compilation will produce the following:

   test.prg(12) Error E0010  'Not declared "Go()" in class: HelloWorld '
   test.prg(20) Error E0010  'Not declared "Go2(N)" in class: HelloWorld '
   test.prg(24) Error E0010  'Not declared class "NoClass" for method: Other
'

2. using /dNO_OO_ERR will produce the following:

   test.prg(24) Error E0010  'Not declared class "NoClass" for method: Other
'

   /* This error must always be produced (I think?). */

3. using /dSTRICT_OO will produce the following:

   test.prg(8) Error E0010  'Not declared "DecGo(n)" or declaration mismatch
in class: HelloWorld '
   test.prg(12) Error E0010  'Not declared "Go()" or declaration mismatch in
class: HelloWorld '
   test.prg(20) Error E0010  'Not declared "Go2(N)" or declaration mismatch
in class: HelloWorld '
   test.prg(24) Error E0010  'Not declared class "NoClass" for method: Other
'

Hope this explains these new features.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 19:49:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Great Team)
Date: Fri May 11 18:49:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FWH Errors!!!
Message-ID: <F38SkFTJM4Ak2jwuQ9g00006be5@hotmail.com>

Antonio,

Here is a copy of my earlier post ...

-----------------------------------------------------------
Antonio,

Antonio, you have to fix Windows.prg as follows:

Line # 2797 change #ifndef __CLIPPER__ to #ifdef __XPP__

Add lines:

#2914 <space>
#2915 #endif

2919 #ifndef __CLIPPER
#2920 <space>

This is because

METHOD HandleEvent( nMsg, nWParam, nLParam ) CLASS TWindow

Is not part of Harbour Application, note this declaration:

   #ifdef __HARBOUR__
      METHOD HandleEvent( nMsg, nWParam, nLParam ) EXTERN ;
                          WndHandleEvent( Self, nMsg, nWParam, nLParam )
   #endif

!!!

BTW, Antonio you never responded to 2nd proposal for fixing FW[H] reserved
words in dll.ch - Why ???
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 11 23:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Great Team)

Subject: [Harbour] FWH Errors!!!
Message-ID: <F473yZty1sh4AsK6ExU00006aef@hotmail.com>

Antonio,

>Ron,
>
>You are 100% right!!!!!!! :-)
>
>That was the problem and now is working FINE AGAIN!!!!!!!!!! :-)

Now, if you only paid attention to my _first_ message... (read this thread 
again and see just how funny/sad it is).

You would have saved yourself a lot of time & trouble, and you wouldn't be 
giving many here false impression about the stability of Harbour.

You are right, we are working too hard, to give people a false impression. 
If I were you, I would apologize to Harbour users, for casting such harsh, 
irresponsible doubts.

You see, now you yourself admit that this new feature had discovered at 
least 2 problems in FWH. One would have definitely caused a GPF in R/T, if 
not discovered by the compiler. The other made a critical wrong function, 
available for possible (crazy) damage.

Please consider that irresponsible remarks like you made, may be far more 
damaging then uploading code that is not 100% tested. You see the change you 
described as "in-deep" was nothing more than few line in a CH file. This can 
never be dangerous, because you can always revert (if needed), without even 
recompiling Harbour!!!

More over, I _first_ received a report of a problem yesterday morning. The 
very next morning (today), everything seemed stable (not bad for a "__deep__ 
change"). Don't you think it's premature to cry foul, so quickly? Don't I 
(and Harbour) deserve more understanding (and support)?

You can't expect me to test every minor change I make against all your prg 
files.

If I took the same time you take, for posting a __minute__, __perfectly__ 
working solution (and 100% compatible!!!) like I posted for your DLL.CH 
reserved words problem many weeks ago, Harbour would have never seen the 
light of day!!!

Harbour is not a released product. In any case, one could use intermediate 
published releases, if demanding any level of stability (not the cvs!!!). 
This is a developer's lists, not a users list. Here I would expect you to 
post calm messages focusing on facts not emotions.

Ron

> heavily in order to get a working harbour compiler under cygwin.
> Unfortunately, I still have problems, many of which are no doubt the
> result of a bad guess.

If you're trying to get a working harbour and you're failing and the
documentation is failing you (remember that the FAQ isn't a guide to
building harbour, the harbour documentation is) then it's probably a good
idea to ask questions about your problems and, if your particular tool
combination isn't already supported and documented - support it and document
it.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 12 03:46:38 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Sat May 12 02:46:38 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch keeps failing (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000001c0da5f$751f2ea0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, May 11, 2001 at 11:15:08PM +0200
References: <20010511173625.N851@hagbard.davep.org> <000001c0da5f$751f2ea0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010512065120.Q851@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, May 11, 2001 at 11:15:08PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > | realworld3.prg(8) Warning W0026  Message 'SETONERROR' not known 
> > in class 'TCLASS'
> > 
> > that warning about SETONERROR probably should be there.

Typo. s/should/shouldn't/.

> I don't agree. SetOnError() is a TClass method.

We both agree, the problem is that I can't type. ;>

> I wonder what may happen with ClassH(), ClassName() and ClassSel()
> messages too.

className() works for objects, it's easy enough to test the other two with a
quick real-world example:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat realworld4.prg
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Function Main()
| 
|    ? Testing():new():className()
|    ? Testing():new():classH()
|    ? Testing():new():classSel()
| 
| Return( NIL )
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour realworld4 -n -W3
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'realworld4.prg'...
| realworld4.prg(6) Warning W0003  Variable: 'METACLASS' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(3)'
| realworld4.prg(6) Warning W0003  Variable: 'NSCOPE' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(3)'
| realworld4.prg(8) Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in class 'TESTING'
| realworld4.prg(9) Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in class 'TESTING'
| realworld4.prg(10) Warning W0026  Message 'NEW' not known in class 'TESTING'
| Lines 14, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'realworld4.c'... Done.
`----

No mention of any of them, only incorrect warnings that have already been
documented as a problem. In <20010509092735.L1231@hagbard.davep.org> I've
already reported that :className() throws an incorrect warning when applied
to a class object, perhaps the other's are the same too. Let's try a
real-world test of that:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat realworld4.prg
| #include "hbclass.ch"
| 
| Create Class Testing
| End Class
| 
| Function Main()
| 
|    ? Testing():className()
|    ? Testing():classH()
|    ? Testing():classSel()
| 
| Return( NIL )
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gharbour realworld4 -n -W3
| Harbour Compiler 0.36  (Build 36) (2001.02.20) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2000, http://www.harbour-project.org
| Compiling 'realworld4.prg'...
| realworld4.prg(6) Warning W0003  Variable: 'METACLASS' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(3)'
| realworld4.prg(6) Warning W0003  Variable: 'NSCOPE' declared but not used in function: 'TESTING(3)'
| realworld4.prg(8) Warning W0026  Message 'CLASSNAME' not known in class 'TESTING'
| realworld4.prg(9) Warning W0026  Message 'CLASSH' not known in class 'TESTING'
| realworld4.prg(10) Warning W0026  Message 'CLASSSEL' not known in class 'TESTING'
| Lines 14, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'realworld4.c'... Done.
`----

Yes, they're a problem for class objects.

> I insist on it: Before uploading important changes to CVS, those changes
> should be extensively tested.

The CVS server provides the bleeding edge of harbour, you must *expect*
harbour to break at any moment, it's alpha software. If you want stability
you should stay away from CVS, or, at least, have two local copies of the
source, one that is of a known state of stability that you're happy with and
one that is the very latest so *you* can *help* *test* harbour.

Ron, or any developer for that matter, can't test everything. I can remember
a time, pre-CVS, when a certain developer was making code available that had
plenty of bugs in and needed testing by other people in other interesting
environments and in interesting ways. Harbour grew because people wanted to
test, enhance and fix that code. It should be no different now.

If you're development environment that makes use of harbour is breaking
every so often that's no harbour developer's fault, that's your fault. Make
your development environment fault-tolerant and you won't have a problem.

Anyway, on top of all of this, the bugs we're talking about above aren't
show-stoppers, they're simply gaps in the work that Ron has been doing to
make level three warnings as useful as possible. I don't expect him to get
it all working at once, nobody else should either. There is an argument that
says that radical changes to harbour should be done in a CVS branch (I'd
agree) but the current enhancements aren't really that radical, they're
simply resulting in a short period of instability, which is to be expected
for a body of source that can't be considered stable anyway.

Be more selective in how you pull source from CVS, or have more than one
local copy of harbour (I've got three: last stable release, last known good
snapshot of CVS, bleeding edge snapshot of CVS) and you shouldn't suffer any
of these problems.

In the mean time everyone else can help Ron test his changes.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 12 05:01:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Sat May 12 04:01:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Great Team
In-Reply-To: <F473yZty1sh4AsK6ExU00006aef@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <000401c0dab9$5da3e180$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron,

> You see the change you described as "in-deep" was nothing more 
> than few line in a CH file. 

Just compare the actual hbclass.ch with the previous one...

> You can't expect me to test every minor change I make against all 
> your prg files.

No, you should test every minor change against all your prg files.
That is what I do here for mines.

> Here I would expect you to post calm messages focusing on facts 
> not emotions.

The fact is that a beta Harbour may be quite far away if some people
keep trying to build a "perfect" Harbour.

That attitude may frustrate many Clipper users that will migrate to
other software development tools tired of waiting...

And at the end, we will have a "perfect" Harbour, but there will be
no users...

Instead of that, we should focus on completing Harbour missing parts,
instead of wasting such an enormous amount of time and energy looking
for perfection, or trying to show others how "perfect" some feel inside...

Antonio

> instead of wasting such an enormous amount of time and energy looking for
> perfection, or trying to show others how "perfect" some feel inside...

Ron's current work is far from an exercise in academic perfection. What
Ron's currently doing is adding something very useful. Witness your own
apology to Ron for incorrectly blaming his work for an error when, in fact,
his work had exposed a bug in your code.

As for writing missing parts, if you feel harbour is missing something vital
all you've got to do is write it and submit it. In the mean time I'd hope
that you'd allow the likes of Ron to write useful stuff that helps you do
useful stuff (I'm assuming that exposing errors in your own code is
considered to be useful stuff).

As for "users" going "elsewhere". That's probably for the best, harbour
wasn't for them. If harbour was for them they'd be pitching in and helping
make it into what they need.

On Sat, May 12, 2001 at 10:16:07AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > If you want stability you should stay away from CVS, or, at least, have
> > two local copies of the source, one that is of a known state of
> > stability that you're happy with and one that is the very latest so
> > *you* can *help* *test* harbour.
> 
> That is exactly what we do here, Dave. And nobody can negate that FWH is
> helping enormously to test Harbour.

I didn't comment on FWH, I commented on how you speak as if you only had one
copy of harbour and that any minor breakage is the end of the world. Keep
two copies of harbour: one that's the latest from CVS and one that's the
last one that built FWH and a FWH app with no known problems. That way you
get the best of both worlds. You get a degree of stability *and* you get to
help everyone by testing the bleeding edge.

> > a time, pre-CVS, when a certain developer was making code available that
> > had plenty of bugs in and needed testing
> 
> That developer spent several years of his life studying compilers
> construction and was able to bring a very early working model of a pcode
> compiler that opened the doors to Harbour.

Did I suggest otherwise? Concentrate less on the programmer and more on the
parallel of writing code and having other people help out and test.
Concentrate more on the stuff you've written about yourself in
comp.lang.clipper regarding the importance of open source (I'm thinking here
of <9cjev8$m9n$1@m2wpersoisp01.wanadoo.es>). What Ron's doing at the moment
is no different from what you were doing in the early days pre and post-CVS.

> > Make your development environment fault-tolerant and you won't have a
> > problem.
> 
> Just remove a wheel of your car, and try to use it...

A car is a physical entity. I'd hope that the developer you speak about in
such glowing terms above can see that you can easily copy a body of source,
you can't easily copy a car.

If I could copy my car as easily as I could copy source code I'd simply use
the copy of my car that still had four wheels. As it is, I've still got a
spare car should my car of choice be unavailable. Even then, although the
rural bus service round here isn't brilliant, there's public transport at my
disposal.

Point being: don't have a single point of failure. Always have a backup. Not
that I should need to document this obvious fact.

> > simply resulting in a short period of instability, which is to be
> > expected for a body of source that can't be considered stable anyway.
> 
> It works stable here on very complex apps. But if you keep saying it is
> not stable, then be sure, soon there will be no one interested in using
> it.

I've already said what I mean about stable/unstable. If anyone is put off by
my words then they're pretty stupid and don't seem to understand some of the
fundamental terms of software development. Harbour will be better off
without them as a user.

> > Be more selective in how you pull source from CVS, or have more than one
> > local copy of harbour (I've got three: last stable release, last known
> > good snapshot of CVS, bleeding edge snapshot of CVS) and you shouldn't
> > suffer any of these problems.
> 
> Thanks God we have the British Empire here to bring the light to the
> world...

Typical. I offer some advice based around how I do things and you retort
with xenophobic argument ad-hominem (and not for the first time).

Subject: [Harbour] RH 7.1 linker warnings
Message-ID: <001801c0dad7$b9beffe0$81b472c3@map>

Hi,

    Linking Harbour programs on RedHat 7.1 with librtl.a (with gcc 2.96-81)
gives these warnings :

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
gcc -o testgtk.exe testgtk.o -lhbgtk -L. -L/root/harbnorm/lib -L/usr/lib
-L/usr/X11R6/lib -lgtk -lgdk -rdynamic -lgmodule -lglib -ldl -lXi -lXext
-lX11 -lm -lvm -lrtl -llang -lrdd -lgtsln -lslang -lrtl -lvm -lmacro -lpp
-ldbfntx -ldbfcdx -lcommon

/root/harbnorm/lib/librtl.a(fstemp.o): In function `hb_fsTempName':
/sav/src/Harb0222/source/rtl/linux/gcc/../../fstemp.c:55: the use of `tmpnam'
is dangerous, better use `mkstemp'
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

This suggests security problems with creating temporary files.

Best regards
Marek Paliwoda

On Sat, May 12, 2001 at 10:52:32AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Ron's current work is far from an exercise in academic perfection.
> 
> Are you sure ?
> 
> He has written a lexer (when Harbour already was using one),
> He has written a preprocessor (when Harbour already had one),
> He has written a dot environment (when there are some around for years...)
> 
> Of course, he is free to do whatever he may want with his time and
> energy...

Which part of "current work" don't you understand?

> > As for writing missing parts, if you feel harbour is missing something
> > vital all you've got to do is write it and submit it.
> 
> You are also welcome to help coding, Dave.

I'm well aware of the rights and freedoms afforded to me by free software,
But you knew that anyway.

> > As for "users" going "elsewhere". That's probably for the best, harbour
> > wasn't for them. If harbour was for them they'd be pitching in and
> > helping make it into what they need.
> 
> There are many programmers wishing to help but they don't have the
> oportunity to do research and development on Harbour. But if you insist on
> saying it is not stable, then they will get scared to start using it.

I think you're underestimating and insulting them. Perhaps you could take
the time to actually learn and understand the difference between a stable
code base and an unstable code base. Think of the Linux kernel's even and
odd releases. The former are stable, the latter are unstable. Nobody with
half a clue seems to have a problem with that idea. It's the same with
harbour. The 0.36 snapshot is a stable snapshot, CVS from a few moments ago
is unstable.

This is pretty much how every single software project works, the code that
is being worked on is in an unstable state. Code that is "released" is
stable.

> Do you develop code for living Dave ? I guess no. This is why you don't
> have a "real world" point of view.

You guessed wrong. Actually, I don't think you guessed wrong, I think you're
just trying to be insulting again. Emphasis on trying.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 12 13:50:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Great Team)
Date: Sat May 12 12:50:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Real World
Message-ID: <F17tYP35uDsj4Z4r86L0000771c@hotmail.com>

Antonio,

>Do you develop code for living Dave ? I guess no. This is why you
>don't have a "real world" point of view.

I think it takes more then "develop code" to have a "real world" point of 
view.

Someone who develops tools, (apparently) has a hard time understanding the 
needs of those who develop and publish ***End-User Applications*** for a 
living.

Obviously you don't appreciate just how frustrating it is to burn thousands 
of CDs, to later find it has a small problem, that your tools 
(compiler/linker/etc.), could and *should* have found, in compile/link 
time!!!

Take this last issue for example, note the timeline in ChangeLog:

   2001-05-08 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com> *** First 
started work ***
      * include/hbclass.ch
        % Removed numerous redundant rules.
        + Added logic to detect and raise #error on implementation of NON 
Declared method.

   2001-05-11 14:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com> *** Last 
correction ***
      * include/hbclass.ch
        + Added syntax declaration support for METHOD ... OPERATOR ...

Total time that CVS was "unstable", as result of work in progress: almost 3 
days.
Total files anyone had to restore if having a problem: 1.

Do you really want to convince those of us that code applications for a 
living, that having this type of Compile-Time error detection is not worth 3 
days of CVS having a "work in progress" status?

Do you really doubt, how much, time, energy, trouble, and money, this kind 
of feature may save for those using Harbour?

I'm sorry if you think I'm wasting *my* time for some theoretical, academic 
like, playing around. I'm even more sorry that you think, I'm slowing 
Harbour development down, just to "show others how 'perfect'" I feel 
inside...

I invest (not waste) my time in Harbour, on subjects that either interest 
me, and or, benefit my software publishing business. What I don't understand 
is, how can you blame me for slowing Harbour development down, because I 
*do* something that *you* might not consider needed?

>He has written a lexer (when Harbour already was using one),
>He has written a preprocessor (when Harbour already had one),
>He has written a dot environment (when there are some around for years...)

How did my lexer slow Harbour development?
How did my preprocessor slow Harbour development?
How did my dot environment slow Harbour development?

Do you allow me to finish my Clipper/Harbour Interpreter, since this was 
never done before (that I'm aware of)?

I don't believe, that you really think this last feature is not needed. I 
know you'll thank Harbour many times in the future, when it finds the kind 
of errors this feature does find (as you already did in 2 recent messages).

I suspect, that you do consider it useful, and I suspect you do agree that 3 
days of CVS representing a work in progress, is not too expensive for this 
feature. Maybe you should post one more message...

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 10:34:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Sun May 13 09:34:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Strong typing bug (RON)
Message-ID: <000f01c0dbb1$536cafa0$59dad7c8@luizguim>

Ron

I´ve found an small bug on the Strong type feature
when compiling the code bellow:
func main()
public aFiles as array of array ,x as numeric

set date ital
set cent on
aFiles:=directory('*.prg')
for x:=1 to len(afiles)
? afiles[x,1]
next
return nil

I recieve the follow wornings
.\test.prg (6) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "AFILES"
.\test.prg (7) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "X"
.\test.prg (7) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "X"
.\test.prg (7) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "AFILES"
.\test.prg (8) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "AFILES"
.\test.prg (8) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "X"
.\test.prg (9) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "X"
.\test.prg (9) Warning  W001  Ambiguous reference: "X"

If I declare this variable as local, this warning are not show

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 11:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun May 13 10:02:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Visibility and life time of public variables defined in C
In-Reply-To: <000701c0dbac$c63cb8e0$59dad7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <3AFEB13F.24114.9F76578@localhost>

On 13 May 2001, at 9:55, Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes wrote:

> I´ve also tryed to declare the variable as static, but it changes also i=
t
> value to the first paramter of the other functions ex: if the first
> parameter is char, the type is set to 1024
>      if the first parameter is int, the type is set to 8

  You are coping a pointer to an item placed on the eval stack instead of 
the whole item's value probably.
  Please check if you are using hb_itemParam() in your code (don't use 
hb_param() for values that need to survive after the function exit)

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 11:42:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun May 13 10:42:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Strong typing bug (RON)
In-Reply-To: <000f01c0dbb1$536cafa0$59dad7c8@luizguim>
References: <000f01c0dbb1$536cafa0$59dad7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <23130788904.20010513074846@abacuslaw.com>

Luiz:

You forgot the MEMVAR declaration for the Publics. Strong typing
doesn't remove the need for that--the variable itself is still
ambiguous, only its content's *type* has been declared.

Brian

LRCG> Ron

LRCG> I´ve found an small bug on the Strong type feature
LRCG> when compiling the code bellow:
LRCG> func main()
LRCG> public aFiles as array of array ,x as numeric

LRCG> set date ital
LRCG> set cent on
LRCG> aFiles:=directory('*.prg')
LRCG> for x:=1 to len(afiles)
LRCG> ? afiles[x,1]
LRCG> next
LRCG> return nil

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 11:57:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Sun May 13 10:57:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] New HBZLib available
In-Reply-To: <23130788904.20010513074846@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIIEDHGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Hi,

A new HBZLib is available from http://www.FiveWin.Be.kz.
Thanks to Luiz Rafael Culik!

HBZLib contains folowing functions:

lZipped:=HB_ZipFile( <cFile>,;
                     <cFileToCompress> | <aFiles> ,;
                     <nLevel>,;
                     <bBlock>,;
                     <lOverWrite>,;
                     <cPassword>,;
                     <lWithPath>)

lUzipped:=HB_UnzipFile( <cFile>,;
                        <bBlock>,;
                        <lWithPath>,;
                        <cPassWord>,;
                        <cPath>,;
                        [<cFile>|<aFile>])


nFiles:=HB_GetUnzipFile( <cFile>)

lZipped:=HB_ZipFileByTDSpan(<cFile>,;
                            <cFileToCompress> | <aFiles>,;
                            <nLevel>,;
                            <bBlock>,;
                            <lOverWrite>,;
                            <cPassword>,;
                            <iSize>,;
                            <lWithPath>)

lZipped:=HB_ZipFileByPKSpan( <cFile>,;
                             <cFileToCompress> | <aFiles>,;
                             <nLevel>,;
                             <bBlock>,;
                             <lOverWrite>,;
                             <cPassword>,;
                             <lWithPath>)

HB_SetDiskZip(<bBlock>)

lDeleted:=HB_ZipDeleteFiles(<cFile>,;
                            <cFiletoDelete>|<aFiles>)

nReturnCode:=HB_ZipTestPK(<cFile>)

Regards,

Patrick Mast
http://www.Patrick.Be.kz
http://www.FiveWin.Be.kz
http://www.Harbour-Project.org


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 12:25:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Sun May 13 11:25:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Visibility and life time of public variables defined in C
References: <3AFEB13F.24114.9F76578@localhost>
Message-ID: <001301c0dbc0$ef5fa340$9bdad7c8@luizguim>

Ryszard
> On 13 May 2001, at 9:55, Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes wrote:
>
> > I´ve also tryed to declare the variable as static, but it changes also
it
> > value to the first paramter of the other functions ex: if the first
> > parameter is char, the type is set to 1024
> >      if the first parameter is int, the type is set to 8
>
>   You are coping a pointer to an item placed on the eval stack instead of
> the whole item's value probably.
>   Please check if you are using hb_itemParam() in your code (don't use
> hb_param() for values that need to survive after the function exit)

Thanks for the answer. I´m really recieving the parameter by hb_param(),
How can i fixit, since the parameter is an Code Block

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 13:21:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun May 13 12:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Visibility and life time of public variables defined in C
In-Reply-To: <001301c0dbc0$ef5fa340$9bdad7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <3AFED1B1.27745.A762145@localhost>

On 13 May 2001, at 12:14, Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes wrote:

> Thanks for the answer. I m really recieving the parameter by hb_param(),
> How can i fixit, since the parameter is an Code Block

  Just replace hb_param() with hb_itemParam(). hb_itemParam() will create 
the item and it will copy the value from the eval stack so it can be used 
safely later. You will have to use hb_itemRelease() when this value will 
be no longer needed.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 13:50:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Great Team)
Date: Sun May 13 12:50:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-13 09:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
Message-ID: <F59wjHNuQuN6tdqVvPd000085a3@hotmail.com>

2001-05-13 09:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * include/hbclass.ch
     % Removed many redundant rules (recently added for OO integrity 
checks).

     /* Found the PP problem that stopped me from implementing this 
optimized form before.
        It seems the PP has a problem with "[" follwing a an identifier 
without a space prefix like:
        #command TEST[([<param,...>])]

        It seems to work OK like this:
        #command TEST [([<param,...>])]
     */

/* Antonio, can you please recompile your FWH classes and report any compile 
problems. */

> Patrick, Luiz,
>
> Can you please explain:
>
> HB_ZipFileByTDSpan()  ---> Create a ziparchive on HD, You can also set the
size of the span archive(you can make files an low an 100Kb , or ziparchives
for backup data on CD´s (650Mb)

> HB_ZipFileByPKSpan()   ---> create an spanning zip archive on removable
media(Floppy disk,Zip drives) (same as pkzip -&)

> HB_SetDiskZip() --->  Set an code block that will be evaluated every time
that an disk change is required. Also this function only must be called when
creating/extracting files from removable media

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 13 23:58:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun May 13 22:58:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-05-13 07:55 UTC-0800
Message-ID: <86174947631.20010513200444@abacuslaw.com>

2001-05-13 07:55 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

   * source/rdd/dbcmd.c
      * dbAppend: set NetErr to True if SELF_APPEND fails

   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads.ch
      * added SET EPOCH TO and SET DATE FORMAT

   * contrib/rdd_ads/adsfunc.c
      + added AdsGetTableAlias() to confirm ADS's idea of the alias
      + added AdsSetEpoch() and AdsSetDateFormat()
         Done as get/set functions (returns previous setting)
      + added AdsCloseAllTables()
      * changed ShowPercentage for Indexing CallBacks to return
         the value from the codeblock to the Server.
         Pass 0 to continue, 1 (non-zero) to abort

   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads1.c
      * Fixed adsOpen() to pass along the correct alias to ADS
      * added DumpArea()  for debugging: call this to dump ads server
         settings to HB_TRACE. Currently in a quick-and-dirty state...

   * source/vm/arrayshb.c
      * added HB_ArrayID()
         Useful for debugging: returns the array's "address" so dual 
         references to same array can be seen */

   * source/vm/arrays.c
      * in hb_arrayFromStack added missing ";" needed for debug build



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 14 00:19:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Great Team)
Date: Sun May 13 23:19:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Error while compiling with VC_Slex.bat any Idea ?
Message-ID: <F22wdUTaGmvSVMum03y000073ba@hotmail.com>

J.F.,

>utils\hbmake\ffile1.prg(365) Error E0010  'Not declared "FCLOSE()" in 
>class: FileBase '
>utils\hbmake\ffile1.prg(412) Error E0010  'Not declared "Buffget(lForward 
>)" in class: FileBase '

You must have an old CVS because these methods have been removed in:

   2001-05-10 14:40 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   ...
   * source/debug/debugger.prg
     - Removed orphan method (discovered by new compiler error) 
CaseSensitive() which is apparantly superceded by ToggleCaseSensitive().
   * utils/hbdoc/ffile1.prg
     - Removed orphan method (discovered by new compiler error) GetBuff() 
which is routed to GetBuffer() in class declaration
     - Removed orphan method (discovered by new compiler error) fClose() 
which is not declared and default to Super in class declaration.

Ron

On Fri, May 11, 2001 at 09:47:15AM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:

>      + Refined #error messages to report the Class Name.

Ron, I think I've mentioned this one before, might it be possible to improve
the language of this error? At the moment it doesn't quite sound right.
Instead of the current text:

,----
| Not declared "foo" in class: Testing
`----

I was thinking of something more like:

,----
| Method <m> is not declared as a member of class <c>
`----

they've got a spare moment?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 14 14:28:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 14 13:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-11 09:00 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <20010514173634.L851@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAECKDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dave,

> >      + Refined #error messages to report the Class Name.
>
> Ron, I think I've mentioned this one before, might it be possible
> to improve
> the language of this error? At the moment it doesn't quite sound right.
> Instead of the current text:
>
> ,----
> | Not declared "foo" in class: Testing
> `----
>
> I was thinking of something more like:
>
> ,----
> | Method <m> is not declared as a member of class <c>
> `----

I chose the earlier (shorter form) because, when class name and method name
are inserted (along with the error number) the line is likely to overlap to
a 2nd line making the later (longer form) less readable.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 14 17:48:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Mon May 14 16:48:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Cygwin DLL 1.3.1
References: <200105110132.f4B1We528232@smtp.parrett.net>
 <002501c0db88$cc284400$79b372c3@map>
Message-ID: <003401c0dcb7$3aba7d00$01b372c3@map>

Marek Paliwoda wrote :

> I can succesfully compile harbour with gtwin as well as gtcrs under CygWin 
> environment on my Win98 box, using following versions of CygWin packages :
> 
> Cygwin1.dll version 1.8.2-2

Sorry, should be Cygwin1.dll version 1.1.8-2

> gcc version 2.95.2 19991024 (release)
> GNU Make version 3.79.1
> BASH_VERSION='2.04.7(2)-release'
> winLibs and winAPIs from Cygwin B20.1
> ncurses version 5.2-4
> 
> I am using a modified version of make_gnu.sh to match my configuration.


David,

Currently I moved to Cygwin 1.3.1 and gcc 2.95.3-2 and I can confirm
that I can succesfully compile Harbour with gtwin with no problems.

Probably Your problem was that a current default mode for building programs
with new versions of Cygwin gcc is unix (-Dunix according to a specs file 
from usr/lib/gcc-lib/i686-pc-cygwin/2.95.3-2/specs for my gcc).

Try adding -mwin32 switch to CC rule and LD rule in config/w32/gcc.cf file.

CC=gcc -mwin32
LD=gcc -mwin32


Regards 
Marek Paliwoda





From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 14 18:26:02 2001

2001-05-14 02:09 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

   * source/rdd/dbcmd.c
      * replaced lpdbOrdCondInfo->fScoped with fUseCurrent
         to clear "USECURRENT" property for subsequent indexes

   * contrib/rdd_ads/make_b32.bat
      * added CLEAN parameter handling

   * include/hbapirdd.h
      - removed fScoped member from DBORDERCONDINFO

   * contrib/rdd_ads/adsfunc.c
      * fixed retrieval of codeblock return value
         for aborting indexing.


 Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 14 18:55:04 2001

Subject: [Harbour] member ?
In-Reply-To: <001c01c0dc9e$2eee8160$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Mon, May 14, 2001 at 07:49:11PM +0200
References: <20010514181632.O851@hagbard.davep.org> <001c01c0dc9e$2eee8160$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010514211257.Q851@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, May 14, 2001 at 07:49:11PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave, Ron,
> 
> > >   Method <m> is not declared for class <c>
> 
> Thinking about it... 
> 
> I guess that the error could be also generated when accessing a DATA of
> the object, so in that case we can not talk about "method" only... and we
> should keep Ron msg.

This is a very different thing, I think Ron's been slowly address that with
-W3. Remember, the "<m> isn't part of <c> but you're attempting to implement
it" error is an error because you're trying to do something totally wrong.
Attempting to send a message or access an instance variable that hasn't been
declared might actually be valid code and even having a warning about it
might be wrong (think meta-classes).

In-Reply-To: <003401c0dcb7$3aba7d00$01b372c3@map>
References: <200105110132.f4B1We528232@smtp.parrett.net> <002501c0db88$cc284400$79b372c3@map>

Message-ID: <200105142247.f4EMlTn03418@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from Marek Paliwoda <paliwoda@inetia.pl> on Mon, 14
May 2001 22:44:52 +0200

> Probably Your problem was that a current default mode for building programs
> with new versions of Cygwin gcc is unix (-Dunix according to a specs file 
> from usr/lib/gcc-lib/i686-pc-cygwin/2.95.3-2/specs for my gcc).

That was indeed the problem, which I discovered after switching to
gtcrs and getting link-time errors for nanosleep(). I solved the problem
by adding the following two lines to my build.sh script instead of
modifying files in my CVS repository:

export C_USR=-D_WIN32
export L_USR=-D_WIN32

I'm going to try again using gtwin and -mwin32 instead of -D_WIN32.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 00:27:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Mon May 14 23:27:02 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Visibility and life time of public variables defined in C
In-Reply-To: <3AFEB13F.24114.9F76578@localhost>
