Ryszard:

If a function uses hb_itemParam() to get an item and store a pointer
to it, is there still a need to use hb_gcGripGet() on that pointer?
If not, when do you use hb_gcGripGet() ?

Brian

RG>   You are coping a pointer to an item placed on the eval stack instead of
RG> the whole item's value probably.
RG>   Please check if you are using hb_itemParam() in your code (don't use
RG> hb_param() for values that need to survive after the function exit)

RG> Regards, Ryszard



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 03:15:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Chen Kedem)
Date: Tue May 15 02:15:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: 2001-05-13 22:10 UTC+1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
Message-ID: <3B00C8FA.221F@synel.co.il>

JF,

Whould you please review the following __objGetMsgList() doc
to ensure it is Ok, since I'm not exactly sure what DATA and
CLASSDATA are :) are those the data and methods that define
inside a class and the other type is for inherited data and methods ??

I think that in source/vm/classes.c line#1943 would be better
changed from:
USHORT nParam=0;
into:
USHORT nParam=HB_MSGLISTALL;

and line#1978 would be better changed from:
if (  (! nParam) ||
into:
if (  (nParam == HB_MSGLISTALL) ||

this way HB_MSGLISTALL is not hardwired as 0



   Chen.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
/*  $DOC$
 *  $FUNCNAME$
 *      __objGetMsgList()
 *  $CATEGORY$
 *      Object manipulation
 *  $ONELINER$
 *      Return names of all DATA or METHOD for a given object
 *  $SYNTAX$
 *      __objGetMsgList( <oObject>, [<lData>], [nClassType] ) --> aNames
 *  $ARGUMENTS$
 *      <oObject> is an object to scan.
 *
 *      <lData> is an optional logical value that specifies the information
 *      to return. A value of .T. instruct the function to return list of
 *      all DATA names, .F. return list of all METHOD names. Default value
 *      is .T.
 *
 *      <nClassType> is on optional numeric code for selecting which class
 *      type to return. Default value is HB_MSGLISTALL, returning the whole
 *      list.
 *  $RETURNS$
 *      __objGetMsgList() return an array of character stings with all DATA
 *      names or all METHOD names for a given object. __objGetMsgList()
 *      would return an empty array {} if the given object does not contain
 *      the requested information.
 *  $DESCRIPTION$
 *      __objGetMsgList() is a low level class support function that let you
 *      find all instance variable or class functions names for a given
 *      object.
 *
 *      If specified, the following table shoes the values for <nClassType>
 *      that allow you to distinguish between DATA and CLASSDATA:
 *
 *     <table>
 *      hboo.ch          Value  Meaning
 *
 *      HB_MSGLISTALL    0      All types
 *      HB_MSGLISTCLASS  1      CLASSDATA only
 *      HB_MSGLISTPURE   2      DATA only
 *     </table>
 *  $EXAMPLES$
 *      // show information about TBrowse class
 *      oB := TBrowseNew( 0, 0, 24, 79 )
 *      aData      := __objGetMsgList( oB, .T. )
 *      aClassData := __objGetMsgList( oB, .T., HB_MSGLISTCLASS )
 *      aMethod    := __objGetMsgList( oB, .F. )
 *      FOR i = 1 to len ( aData )
 *          ? "DATA name:", aData[ i ]
 *      NEXT
 *      FOR i = 1 to len ( aClassData )
 *          ? "CLASSDATA name:", aClassData[ i ]
 *      NEXT
 *      FOR i = 1 to len ( aMethod )
 *          ? "METHOD name:", aMethod[ i ]
 *      NEXT
 *  </fixed>
 *  $STATUS$
 *      R
 *  $COMPLIANCE$
 *      __objGetMsgList() is a Harbour extension.
 *  $FILES$
 *      Header file is hboo.ch
 *      Library is rtl
 *  $SEEALSO$
 *      __ObjGetMethodList(),__ObjGetValueList(),__objHasData(),__objHasMethod()
 *  $END$
 */
----------------------------------------------------------------------

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 03:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Tue May 15 02:30:03 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Visibility and life time of public variables defined in C
In-Reply-To: <171263090414.20010514203347@abacuslaw.com>
References: <3AFEB13F.24114.9F76578@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B00EA35.22471.2B7DBE@localhost>

On 14 May 2001, at 20:33, Brian Hays wrote:

> If a function uses hb_itemParam() to get an item and store a pointer
> to it, is there still a need to use hb_gcGripGet() on that pointer?
> If not, when do you use hb_gcGripGet() ?

  hb_gcGetGrip() is called from hb_itemNew() only (and hb_itemNew() is 
called from hb_itemParam()). There are no reasons to use hb_gcGripGet() 
directly - it will be called from old code only which is using 
_getgrip/_dropGrip Clipper functions.

  Please notice that hb_gcGripGet() is allocating a memory for the item 
and eventually makes a copy of passed item's value. This means that if an 
item is allocated with hb_itemNew() then there is no need to call 
hb_gcGripGet() with a pointer returned from hb_itemNew() (unless you 
really want to have two copies of an item - although hb_itemNew() should 
be used since it is a documented EXTEND api function).

  Notice also that:

pItem = hb_gcGripGet( hb_itemNew() );

will create two items however only one of them will be accessible since 
pointer returned by hb_itemNew() will be lost.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 05:21:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Tue May 15 04:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: 2001-05-13 22:10 UTC+1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B00C8FA.221F@synel.co.il>
Message-ID: <3B0102A7.22253.56C1747@localhost>

Hi Chen,

First of all, thanks very much to maintain and update the Harbour 
DOC (a job I personally hate to do :-(((( ). 

> Whould you please review the following __objGetMsgList() doc
> to ensure it is Ok, since I'm not exactly sure what DATA and
> CLASSDATA are :) are those the data and methods that define
> inside a class and the other type is for inherited data and methods ??

DATA are instance VAR usable within each object from the Class 
and each Object has its own DATAs.
CLASSDATA are shared by all objects from a Class. (So the 
changed value within object1 will be reflected when accessing the 
CLASSDATA from object2)

To be sure you will be completely lost (;-)) ) there is also two kind 
of CLASSDATA.

CLASSDATA SHARED and NOT SHARED (here the word 
SHARED is refering the CLASS, not the instancied objects).

This option exist only when using Classy and TopClass syntax 
CLASS VAR in lieu of CLASSDATA.

CLASS VAR SHARED allow not only the value to be shared by 
objects from the current Class, but also by all object from inherited 
Classes (this is the standart way for CLASSDATA (FWOO)).

CLASS VAR restrict the value to be shared only by objects from 
the same Class.


Concerning the doc, I would just change 'Class function' by 
'Methods names' as below.
 
*  $DESCRIPTION$
 *      __objGetMsgList() is a low level class support function that 
let you
 *      find all instance variable or methods names for a given
 *      object.

See you,

Best regards,

J. Lefebvre <jflefebv@mafact.com>
Mafact SA/NV
Belgium
(See us at http://www.mafact.com)
jflefebv@mafact.com


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 06:37:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Jacek Kaleta)
Date: Tue May 15 05:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] TEditor.prg: text2Array(), getText() Error
Message-ID: <003b01c0dd22$c110bca0$c8c060d9@t4z7y4>

See example:  (DJGPP, Win98) :
----------------------------------------------------------------------
proc main
clear screen

@ 20,0 say 'Error in Memoedit (TEditor.prg: Text2Array, GetText) '



Str = 'OK'
@ 2,0 say "Str = 'OK' "
@ 3,0 say 'Before: '
@ 3,30 say Str
@ 4,0  say 'MemoEdit (Press ALT-W) '

Str = MemoEdit(Str, 4,30,5,79)

@ 7,0  say 'After'
@ 7,30 say Str
@ 8,0 say '------------------------'


Str = chr(13)+chr(10)+'OK'
@ 10, 0  say "Str = chr(13)+chr(10)+'OK ' "
@ 11, 0  say 'Before: '
@ 11,30  say Str
@ 12, 0  say 'MemoEdit (Press ALT-W) '

Str = MemoEdit(Str, 12,30,13,79)
@ 14, 0  say 'After'
@ 14,30 say Str


@ 23,0 say 'Press any key ... (DJGPP, Win98) '
inkey(0)

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Best regards
Jacek Kaleta

>
> Str = 'OK'
> @ 2,0 say "Str = 'OK' "
> @ 3,0 say 'Before: '
> @ 3,30 say Str
> @ 4,0  say 'MemoEdit (Press ALT-W) '
>
> Str = MemoEdit(Str, 4,30,5,79)
>
> @ 7,0  say 'After'
> @ 7,30 say Str
> @ 8,0 say '------------------------'
>
> Str = chr(13)+chr(10)+'OK'
> @ 10, 0  say "Str = chr(13)+chr(10)+'OK ' "
> @ 11, 0  say 'Before: '
> @ 11,30  say Str
> @ 12, 0  say 'MemoEdit (Press ALT-W) '
>
> Str = MemoEdit(Str, 12,30,13,79)
> @ 14, 0  say 'After'
> @ 14,30 say Str
>
> @ 23,0 say 'Press any key ... (DJGPP, Win98) '

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 13:41:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian)
Date: Tue May 15 12:41:01 2001
Subject: Re[4]: [Harbour] Visibility and life time of public variables defined in C
In-Reply-To: <3B00EA35.22471.2B7DBE@localhost>
References: <3AFEB13F.24114.9F76578@localhost> <3B00EA35.22471.2B7DBE@localhost>
Message-ID: <4881986690.20010515094752@abacuslaw.com>

Ryszard,

Thanks for the clarification!  Should we have a #define somewhere for
_getgrip/_dropGrip? Or do we not expect hb_gcGripGet() to be a literal
replacement to actually compile the old code unchanged?
In my case, I was working with some code for a Windows Tree control
that not only used _getgrip, it was also doing
     _bcopy( (LPBYTE) _eval, (LPBYTE) p, sizeof(CLIPVAR) );
which didn't look like something we wanted happening in Harbour, so I
rewrote the routines to use hb_itemParam and hb_itemReturn, and it
seems to work great (although there are other problems getting that
control to work right...)

Brian

RG>   hb_gcGetGrip() is called from hb_itemNew() only (and hb_itemNew() is
RG> called from hb_itemParam()). There are no reasons to use hb_gcGripGet() 
RG> directly - it will be called from old code only which is using 
RG> _getgrip/_dropGrip Clipper functions.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 15 22:43:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian)
Date: Tue May 15 21:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ADS index callbacks
Message-ID: <110114508404.20010515184954@abacuslaw.com>

I'm back trying to finish up the callback issues with ADS indexing.
Current code works great with a console app or when using the Remote
server. But if using the LOCAL SERVER in a GUI app (using FWH), the
callbacks don't get processed because the primary thread is used to do
the indexing.  IOW, we *need* a second thread.

Folks at Extended Systems say the Indexing should be done by a second
thread, and let the primary thread handle the callbacks, and that's
what they do in their Delphi example.  It might work the other way around.

Is there any chance of it working to start a thread in the C code for
the call to adsCreateIndex?  Or to start a thread beforehand that can
let the callback eval a codeblock to refresh a meter?  I know Harbour
is not thread-safe, but can we squeeze a second one in with some
limitations on what it will do?

 Brian

> RP> Anyone knows why FieldType() FieldSize() and FieldDeci() are missing?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 16 12:05:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May 16 11:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] M doesn't appear to be a reserved workarea, unlike CA-Clipper
Message-ID: <20010516160422.S7900@hagbard.davep.org>

There's the once-yearly "why can't I have an alias called 'A'?" type of
thread in <URL:news:comp.lang.clipper> right now. While composing a post to
it I thought it might be interesting to see how harbour copes. Here's the
test program:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
Function Main()
Local i

   errorblock( {|o| break( o ) } )

   For i := asc( "A" ) To asc( "Z" )

      Begin Sequence
        ? chr( i ) + " " 
        select( chr( i ) )
      Recover
        ?? "Not "
      End Sequence

      ?? "Reserved"

   Next

Return( NIL )
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

The output is:

,----
| A Reserved
| B Reserved
| C Reserved
| D Reserved
| E Reserved
| F Reserved
| G Reserved
| H Reserved
| I Reserved
| J Reserved
| K Reserved
| L Not Reserved
| M Not Reserved
| N Not Reserved
| O Not Reserved
| P Not Reserved
| Q Not Reserved
| R Not Reserved
| S Not Reserved
| T Not Reserved
| U Not Reserved
| V Not Reserved
| W Not Reserved
| X Not Reserved
| Y Not Reserved
| Z Not Reserved
`----

That differs from CA-Clipper in that M is not "reserved". Is this a bug in
harbour or is it a deliberate design decision?

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 16 16:16:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Wed May 16 15:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <9914808304.20010516224831@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <000901c0de3c$3ac580c0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron, Dave,

I may be missing something but this code does not work:
(it refuses to link). Could MESSAGE ... METHOD be broken ?

I appreciate your comments,

Thanks

#include "hbclass.ch"

function Main()

   local o := Test()

   Alert( "ok" )

return nil

CLASS Test

   DATA nPos

   MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()

   METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos

ENDCLASS




From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 16 16:44:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May 16 15:44:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000901c0de3c$3ac580c0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Wed, May 16, 2001 at 09:13:03PM +0200
References: <9914808304.20010516224831@belacy.belgorod.su> <000901c0de3c$3ac580c0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010516203923.W7900@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, May 16, 2001 at 09:13:03PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> CLASS Test
> 
>    DATA nPos
> 
>    MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()
> 
>    METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos
> 
> ENDCLASS

I'm guessing that it's never worked in harbour (that is, pointing a message
at an inline method). At least, looking at the reason it fails (see the .PPO
file), I'd be surprised to find that it used to work but that it's broken
now.

One way of fixing the code above would be this:

,----
| Class Test
| 
|    Data nPos
| 
|    Method nPosition InLine ::getPos()
|    Method getPos()  InLine ::nPos
| 
| EndClass
`----

But, of course, that can be further reduced to:

,----
| Class Test
| 
|    Data nPos
| 
|    Method nPosition InLine ::nPos
|    Method getPos()  InLine ::nPos
| 
| EndClass
`----

Obviously none of this fixes the real problem. 

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 16 16:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Wed May 16 15:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <20010516203923.W7900@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <000b01c0de41$95521940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Dave,

> I'm guessing that it's never worked in harbour

Probably. I didn't test it before.

> But, of course, that can be further reduced to:

The idea is: 

CLASS Test

   DATA nPos

   MESSAGE _nPosition METHOD SetPos( nValue )

   MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()  

ENDCLASS

...

So later on, we can do:

  local o := Test()

  o:nPosition = 5

  ? o:nPosition

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 16 17:03:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Wed May 16 16:03:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000b01c0de41$95521940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <000d01c0de42$d74c8d20$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Dave,

A little more elaborated,

CLASS Test

   DATA nPos

   METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos

   METHOD SetPos( nValue )

   MESSAGE _nPosition METHOD SetPos( nValue )

   MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()  

ENDCLASS


METHOD SetPos( nValue ) CLASS Test

  // do here whatever checkings we may want to do
  // and finally we may do:

  ::nPos = nValue

return nil


Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 16 18:16:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed May 16 17:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000b01c0de41$95521940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Wed, May 16, 2001 at 09:51:22PM +0200
References: <20010516203923.W7900@hagbard.davep.org> <000b01c0de41$95521940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010516220929.Y7900@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, May 16, 2001 at 09:51:22PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> The idea is: 
> 
> CLASS Test
> 
>    DATA nPos
> 
>    MESSAGE _nPosition METHOD SetPos( nValue )
> 
>    MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()  
> 
> ENDCLASS

Looking at the above, and as an aside, wouldn't it be cleaner and read
better to have a proper get/set declaration syntax to abstract the mechanism
involved?

Kind of like:

,----
| Data nPosition Set SetPos( nValue ) Get GetPos()
`----

or something there about (I've got this funny feeling that the above is
mixing a declarative style with an inline/implementation style but I'm sure
that can be sorted).

--

John:


JS> Is there some reason why the first way doesn't look the best one?
JS> John.
It seemed less invasive to the normal flow of things to "externally"
have a window handle a progress meter, but let the RDD do exactly what
it's doing now.

-===-
 Brian

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 03:05:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)

Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD
In-Reply-To: <20010516220929.Y7900@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <000b01c0de41$95521940$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Wed, May 16, 2001 at 09:51:22PM +0200
Message-ID: <3B038608.19167.9439B@localhost>

Hi Dave

> On Wed, May 16, 2001 at 09:51:22PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> 
> > The idea is: 
> > 
> > CLASS Test
> > 
> >    DATA nPos
> > 
> >    MESSAGE _nPosition METHOD SetPos( nValue )
> > 
> >    MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()  
> > 
> > ENDCLASS


Normally this should be a job for the ACCESS and ASSIGN 
commands, like ;

ASSIGN nPosition METHOD SetPos( nValue )
ASSIGN nPosition METHOD GetPos() 
 
I've not tested if it actually work (will do it tonigh) but it should.


> Looking at the above, and as an aside, wouldn't it be cleaner and read
> better to have a proper get/set declaration syntax to abstract the
> mechanism involved?
> 
> Kind of like:
> 
> ,----
> | Data nPosition Set SetPos( nValue ) Get GetPos()
> `----

Hummm, it feel like something know for me. I think I implemented 
some GETSET or SETGET kind of Data (or tryied to do it). Ok 
another job for tonigh. :-)) 
 
> or something there about (I've got this funny feeling that the above
> is mixing a declarative style with an inline/implementation style but
> I'm sure that can be sorted).
> 
> -- 
> The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler

there was no formal FREEZE/RELEASE on CVS; Major component like the low
level file access functions (W32), was included without proper testing,
resulting in major tests failing, including HBTEST itself! Can anyone
volunteer to coordinate, and test the release before, OKing it for
distribution builds?

Ron

file IO stuff, what is the state of that now?).

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 08:59:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Thu May 17 07:59:06 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] ADS index callbacks
References: <3B037B2F.30528.A659D0@localhost>
Message-ID: <001101c0dec8$d2c7aa60$a1d4d7c8@luizguim>

Sylvain


> Luiz,
>
>   When I do my review of source code to add Codebase, I see a lot
> of mention about not Thread safe operation that have to be fixe !
If I remember, Codebase an an library for access database files, Am I
correct.

>   Am I wrong ?
As i know, correct me if i´m wrong,  the source code can be Thread safe when
compiled and tested. An. example , that i give is the new hbzlib.
I use an library called ziparchive, where i´ve create Harbour C wrappers to
access the zip archive library.
The zip archive code is Thread safe as my friend Tadeusz, who is the author
, said to me.

The code blocks i need to pass to libraty do perform disk changes are pure
Harbour function as {|x| alert('please insert disk no'+str(x,3)}This code
block is evaluated inside the call back function, with the disk number is
get directly from the ziparchive library.

Thats is why i say , that i´d love to see an FWH version compiled with the
multithread option on(ANTONIO). then we can see if harbour is thread safe or
not

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik

Sylvain, Luiz,

I'm nearly sure we cannot compile Harbour with MultiThreading at 
least simply due to the fact we use a static Pointer to handles the 
Class Methods. I'm not the initiator of classes.c but the warning at 
the begining seem correct in my point of view. This is in my TODO 
list :-(((. I'm not an expert in multi threading so any idea of 
improvement will be welcome here.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 10:09:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Martin Vogel)
Date: Thu May 17 09:09:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
References: <001101c0dec8$d2c7aa60$a1d4d7c8@luizguim> <3B03E318.16532.110950A@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B03CD7E.8EFBFC4@urz.uni-heidelberg.de>

Hi all,

jflefebv@mafact.be schrieb:
> I'm nearly sure we cannot compile Harbour with MultiThreading at
> least simply due to the fact we use a static Pointer to handles the
> Class Methods. I'm not the initiator of classes.c but the warning at

It's the very same in all modules that use non-constant statics.
Making Harbour multithreading can be done, but this will result in many
code changes in _all_ these modules. Let's move that to a point of time
after the next release (or, as some have suggested) even after the
release of Harbour 1.0.

Regards
Martin

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 10:17:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Thu May 17 09:17:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <3B03E318.16532.110950A@localhost>
References: <3B038770.30480.D6384B@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B03EB1E.11523.12FEBB0@localhost>

Sylvain, Luiz,

> I'm nearly sure we cannot compile Harbour with MultiThreading at least
> simply due to the fact we use a static Pointer to handles the Class
> Methods. I'm not the initiator of classes.c but the warning at the
> begining seem correct in my point of view. This is in my TODO list
> :-(((. I'm not an expert in multi threading so any idea of improvement
> will be welcome here. 

As I say, I was not the initiator of classes.c but I would be tempted 
to simply suppress the static Pointer and replace it with a local 
one each time we need it. The actual pointer is stored within the 
s_pClasses[uiCls].pMethod so I think we don't need this static 
pointer anymore. The only backSide I could see is that I will have 
to retrieve the methods pointer where it is actually directly 
accessible from some internal function pointer.

I will have a try tonigh :-)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 10:59:23 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Chen Kedem)
Date: Thu May 17 09:59:23 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
Message-ID: <3B03D8A2.50AE@synel.co.il>

Luiz,

> Interesting point of View. Why does it work on my side,with
> multithread option of bcc32 compiler switch set.

when saying that Harbour is not Thread-Safe it is not about
Harbour not compiling under multithread option of your C compiler,
but the results later can be unpredictable!

so a small simple program can work just fine, but a program more
complex that deliberately try to use more than one thread can crash
itself in many many ways.

just to say it is not SAFE to work with threads but you could
actually do it if you'll use only thread-safe Harbour functions/modules
in your program.

  Chen.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 11:06:02 2001

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 11:11:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu May 17 10:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <200105162013.f4GKDR602320@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <001f01c0deda$c96bdce0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

JF,

Very good! The below sample is working properly now.

(Now I am going to rebuild FWH entirely and see if the
changes have any side effects)

Thanks a lot!

Antonio

#include "hbclass.ch"

function Main()

   local o := Test():New()

   Alert( o:nPosition )

return nil

CLASS Test

   DATA nPos

   METHOD New()

   MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()

   METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos

ENDCLASS

METHOD New()

   ::nPos = 5

return Self

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 11:44:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu May 17 10:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (JF, Ron)
In-Reply-To: <002001c0dedb$73d33700$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <002101c0dedf$82ff0c00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

> See what I get when I try to compile FWH control.prg:

What we have in control.prg is:

MESSAGE HelpTopic METHOD __HelpTopic()
MESSAGE SetFocus METHOD _SetFocus()

...
METHOD __HelpTopic() CLASS TControl
...
METHOD _SetFocus() CLASS TControl
...

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 12:08:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Juan Agustin Barriga)
Date: Thu May 17 11:08:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
References: <3B03D8A2.50AE@synel.co.il>
Message-ID: <005d01c0dee2$dd8b6850$c06410ac@jharrier>

Having programmed a multithreaded Server for the past five years, and for
what I've seen of Harbour code (mainly the RDD), well, my opinion is that
only a really BIG change can make it thread safe. My own software is written
in C++ and so it can express directly  the classes  that are otherwise
"implied" on a C app (for example the WorkArea with all the virtual table
and macro mess). Even so, multithread has been a nightmare. After a few
years we realized why Unix server software mostly favored spawning process
(they execute on a different memory) than managing multithread. This does
not mean that it cannot be done, but a remainder that it will not be an easy
task. The errors produced when several threads are running are quite tricky
to spot, debug & fix. The environment that Harbour will run in will not be
as hard as one with 100-200 threads interacting, but just a few of them can
screw things up!

Go for it, but AFTER there is a singlethread Harbour... Even I can help.

Regards
Harrier

> > BTW, last couple releases were not very well coordinated (IMO). i.e. in
> > 0.36 there was no formal FREEZE/RELEASE on CVS; Major component like the
> > low level file access functions (W32), was included without proper
> > testing, resulting in major tests failing, including HBTEST itself! Can
> > anyone volunteer to coordinate, and test the release before, OKing it for
> > distribution builds?
> 
> Agreed an pretty much all points. What I would point out is that plenty of
> people are already testing harbour anyway. I think the SNAFU with 0.36 came
> down to the fact that the once proposed go/nogo check didn't happen. Phil
> might also want to think about declaring a feature freeze and then jumping
> up and down if someone adds something very new (like the re-worked Win32
> file IO stuff, what is the state of that now?).
> 
> BTW. I take it you have a record of the -W3 class issues I posted? If not
> shout and I'll forward you a copy of the emails in question.

A feature freeze is therefore called for.

>From now until the release, please do not add ANY new features.

This is a time to work out bugs.

When we all agree that as many bugs as possible are killed and 
we are all in agreement that we are in a stable state, we release.

Thanks.


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 12:25:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu May 17 11:25:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (JF, Ron)
In-Reply-To: <002101c0dedf$82ff0c00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEFKDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > See what I get when I try to compile FWH control.prg:
>
> What we have in control.prg is:
>
> MESSAGE HelpTopic METHOD __HelpTopic()
> MESSAGE SetFocus METHOD _SetFocus()
>
> ...
> METHOD __HelpTopic() CLASS TControl
> ...
> METHOD _SetFocus() CLASS TControl
> ...
>
> Antonio

This must be added to all the message ... method ... segments:

    #xcommand METHOD <MethodName> [([<anyParams,...>])] [DECLCLASS
_CLASS_NAME_] _CLASS_IMPLEMENTATION_ => DECLARED METHOD _CLASS_NAME_
<MethodName>([<anyParams>]);;

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 12:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Jacek Potempa)
Date: Thu May 17 11:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <005d01c0dee2$dd8b6850$c06410ac@jharrier>
Message-ID: <NOEPIKLDCODGGHOPAHEEKEGLCGAA.Jacek.Potempa@otc.pl>

> -----Original Message-----
> From: harbour-admin@matrixlist.com
> [mailto:harbour-admin@matrixlist.com]On Behalf Of Juan Agustin Barriga
> Sent: Thursday, May 17, 2001 5:06 PM
> To: harbour@matrixlist.com
> Subject: Re: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
>
>
> Having programmed a multithreaded Server for the past five years, and for
> what I've seen of Harbour code (mainly the RDD), well, my opinion is that
> only a really BIG change can make it thread safe. My own software
> is written
> in C++ and so it can express directly  the classes  that are otherwise
> "implied" on a C app (for example the WorkArea with all the virtual table
> and macro mess). Even so, multithread has been a nightmare. After a few
> years we realized why Unix server software mostly favored spawning process
> (they execute on a different memory) than managing multithread. This does
> not mean that it cannot be done, but a remainder that it will not
> be an easy
> task. The errors produced when several threads are running are
> quite tricky
> to spot, debug & fix. The environment that Harbour will run in will not be
> as hard as one with 100-200 threads interacting, but just a few
> of them can
> screw things up!
>
> Go for it, but AFTER there is a singlethread Harbour... Even I can help.
>
> Regards
> Harrier

I have similar experiences and do completely agree with Harrier.
There is, however, one thing that can be done quickly and safely.
Official versions of Harbour libraries could be compiled with the
multithreading option (/MT for VC++, -tWM for BC++ 5.5).
While it will no make Harbour thread-safe, it will make Harbour
applications thread-capable.
There are plenty of reasons why application programmer may need
to use multithreading with his own synchronization methods, probably in
functions which do not even touch Harbour code, but need to be
linked with Harbour libraries. At the moment it is not possible to build
multithreaded applications using official Harbour libraries.

Regards,
Jacek

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 14:32:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Thu May 17 13:32:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Ron)
Message-ID: <200105171331_MC2-D15D-F771@compuserve.com>

In this:

CLASS Test

   DATA nPos

   MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()

   METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos

ENDCLASS

The MESSAGE XXX METHOD YYY syntax has usually (always?) been used
as a way to provide a new name YYY for the XXX, typically because
the XXX is a reserved Clipper name, and in addition the YYY had to be
a METHOD defined _outside_ the CLASS...ENDCLASS.

I'm not sure the syntax was particularly well thought-out, as it seems
countless people (not those here, I'm sure :-) have needed to be told
it was there mainly (only?) to allow message renaming.

I think Class(y) uses IS in the case where the method (YYY) is
_inside_ the CLASS...ENDCLASS.  Warning: I'm not a Class(y) user, so I
may well be wrong. :-(

TopClass uses INLINE  in the case where the method (YYY) is inside the
CLASS...ENDCLASS:
   MESSAGE nPosition INLINE ::GetPos()
actually, it would use:
   ACCESS nPosition INLINE ::GetPos()
in this specific case. :-)

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 15:02:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Thu May 17 14:02:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Antonio, Ron)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEFKDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <002101c0dedf$82ff0c00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <200105171800.f4HI0n614429@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>

Ron, Antonio, 

That's not a simple problem :-(, let me explain.

here is a case wich mixes the previous problem and the actual one

CLASS Test

   DATA nPos

   MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()

   METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos

   MESSAGE Hello METHOD cHello()

ENDCLASS

Method cHello()
Return "Hello"

Ok, Message nPosition must be an inline to not generate one 
missing external on Test_GetPos() (Wich doesn't exist as it is an 
inline method).

But now (with the modified hbClass.ch), the message Hello react 
the same, doing an inline call to ::cHello() wich is not defined 
because of the first modification !!!!!!!!!!!

Thank for your advice Ron, but it only suppress the error message 
at compile time, not the fact that the class do not know any 
method named ::cHello.

I think we should keep some list of METHODs associated with 
MESSAGEs and add the missing one as method when reaching 
ENDCLASS. (All METHODs INLINEs should be removed from the 
list as soon as the PP encounter it)

The bad news Ron, is that it is out of my current knowledge of your 
Job with the PP. Sorry :-( 

The current hbclass.ch 1.57 from the CVS is safe but do not allow 
messages associated to inline methods and I will not update it with 
my current one.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 15:34:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu May 17 14:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] MESSAGE ... METHOD (Antonio, Ron)
In-Reply-To: <200105171800.f4HI0n614429@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEFMDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

J.F.,

I simply don't understand why would anyone use a message for an inline
method??? The message is supposed to be a friendlier alias when you simply
can't use the readable name in itself, because of possible conflicts with
other symbols.

This was much more of an isssue, with Clipper than with Harbour, because in
Harbour (non 10 char mode) the Class name is APPENDED to the Method Name!!!
This in iteslf should probably remove the need for the MESSAGE ... METHOD
... syntax to begin with!

I think that when routing a message the syntax should be:

MESSAGE ... FUNCTION ...

This should make it clearer that a message should not be routed to an inline
method.

Ron

> Ron, Antonio,
>
> That's not a simple problem :-(, let me explain.
>

> ENDCLASS

> Return "Hello"
>

> inline method).

Sylvain:

I don't think the existence of that second thread is the problem,
since normal termination ends fine.
There is definitely a problem with the error handling in Harbour
going through FWH: Both GPF and
some Errorsys-handled errors that Quit often leave a process running,
sometimes in a loop eating cpu cycles. This may be difficult to trace;
I was waiting until resource and memory release issues were fixed
before chasing it.

SR>   If your not using harbour compiler that came with FWH can you 
SR> send me your HARBOUR.EXE and LIB I'll compile my little test with 
SR> your file, to see if it's a problem just on my side !.
SR>   I'm really concern about that problem because sometime even if I
SR> quit the application normally it remain in memory with 1 thread !

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 19:05:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian)
Date: Thu May 17 18:05:04 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <NOEPIKLDCODGGHOPAHEEKEGLCGAA.Jacek.Potempa@otc.pl>
References: <NOEPIKLDCODGGHOPAHEEKEGLCGAA.Jacek.Potempa@otc.pl>
Message-ID: <6421132076.20010517151203@abacuslaw.com>

Martin, Harrier, Jacek, Sylvain et al:

This is finally getting back to the origin of this, eh, thread ;-)
Clearly it is too big a change to try to make Harbour truly
Multi-threaded (MT) at this point, and I agree that any attempt for
that should wait for v.1.

 *** BUT *** there are some features many of us are hoping for (NEED)
 that fail if we cannot devise partial support for a second thread.
 Progress callbacks are dead using ADS.
 ALSO: in FWH, we had an animation working off a windows timer during
 a COPY FILE call (I forget exactly which function we used to copy the
 file). The animation/timer execution was DISABLED until the function
 call finished.  IOW, even Windows timers fail if the primary thread
 is busy!!  This is worse than 16 bit was!!
 ALSO: APP screen painting is dead during data server activity
 (waiting for a query to find a first record, or during indexing) so
 that switching to another app and back again fails, and minimizing or
 moving the other app yields a white screen until the operation finishes.

 Anybody using a GUI *really* needs these issues addressed!
 
 Brian

>> -----Original Message-----
>> Subject: Re: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
>>
>>
>> Having programmed a multithreaded Server for the past five years, and for
>> what I've seen of Harbour code (mainly the RDD), well, my opinion is that
>> only a really BIG change can make it thread safe. My own software
>> is written
>> in C++ and so it can express directly  the classes  that are otherwise
>> "implied" on a C app (for example the WorkArea with all the virtual table
>> and macro mess). Even so, multithread has been a nightmare. After a few
>> years we realized why Unix server software mostly favored spawning process
>> (they execute on a different memory) than managing multithread. This does
>> not mean that it cannot be done, but a remainder that it will not
>> be an easy
>> task. The errors produced when several threads are running are
>> quite tricky
>> to spot, debug & fix. The environment that Harbour will run in will not be
>> as hard as one with 100-200 threads interacting, but just a few
>> of them can
>> screw things up!
>>
>> Go for it, but AFTER there is a singlethread Harbour... Even I can help.
>>
>> Regards
>> Harrier

JP> I have similar experiences and do completely agree with Harrier.
JP> There is, however, one thing that can be done quickly and safely.
JP> Official versions of Harbour libraries could be compiled with the
JP> multithreading option (/MT for VC++, -tWM for BC++ 5.5).
JP> While it will no make Harbour thread-safe, it will make Harbour
JP> applications thread-capable.
JP> There are plenty of reasons why application programmer may need
JP> to use multithreading with his own synchronization methods, probably in
JP> functions which do not even touch Harbour code, but need to be
JP> linked with Harbour libraries. At the moment it is not possible to build
JP> multithreaded applications using official Harbour libraries.

JP> Regards,
JP> Jacek

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 17 23:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Robert Haley)
Date: Thu May 17 22:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Get System, Get object display, after loosing focus
Message-ID: <002701c0df44$b0dcbb80$c07161ce@thinkpad390x>

Greetings Harbour Developers,

While testing code using an extended SETCOLOR() setting, the Get System left
the Get object in the (ENHANCED) color setting upon object exit. ( Behavior
should be to redisplay the Get object in (UNSELECTED) color upon exit /
when navigating to another Get object in the getlist array. )

Fix: appears to be to force ::Display( .T. ), following the Get object
losing focus in the KillFocus() method:

Program:  \harbour\source\rtl\tget.prg :

//--------------------------------------------------------------------------
-//

METHOD KillFocus() CLASS Get

   ::Assign()
   ::Display()

   ::buffer   := ::PutMask()
   ::hasfocus := .f.
   ::pos      := NIL

   ::Display( .T. )         // new: (re)display current get in
                                 //   (UNSELECTED) color

return Self

//--------------------------------------------------------------------------
-//

Net change:  addition of ::Display( .T. ) prior to return, method
KillFocus(), TGET.PRG.

I have tested the change with the latest CVS, BCC 5.5sp2 / Flex / Win98, if
the above could be tested under the other applicable targets / committed to
CVS it would be appreciated, thanks in advance.

Regards,
Bob

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 02:57:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Fri May 18 01:57:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Changelog 2001-05-18 09:50 GMT+3
Message-ID: <1233910667.20010518095213@belacy.belgorod.su>

2001-05-18 09:50 GMT+3 Alexander Kresin <alex@belacy.belgorod.su>
   * source/rdd/dbfntx/dbfntx1.c
     * indexes now are opened with FO_READWRITE regardless of
       readonly mode on/off to allow locking.
       They are opened with FO_READ mode only if exclusive and readonly are set.
       ( Before index file couldn't be locked while moving through it
       in shared readonly mode ).

Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

With a "native" rdd, indexing is interrupted while control moves to
the "EVAL..EVERY" Codeblock.  Yes, a msg loop may or may not be needed,
depending on implementation.

rather not put it aside ;-)
The issue also exists for other
activities, as I described in an earlier msg....

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 06:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 18 05:04:02 2001
Subject: Re[6]: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <1728981835.20010517235356@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGBDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Brian,

(As I suspected) I'm happy to report that the ADS Indexing Callback Function
appears to works correctly, even within a GUI application, with just 1
thread.

The following is a FWH application that will index and report progress as
expected.

Build it using your standard FWH buildh.bat.

Just start it with a command line parameter of some existing DBF file (and
allow few seconds for the file to be copied enough times to have 300,000
records.

//---------------------------------
TestAds.prg ------------------------------//
#include "FiveWin.ch"

Function Main( cDbf )

   local oDlg

   DEFINE DIALOG oDlg FROM 6, 6 TO 20, 60 TITLE "Test ADS CallBack"

   @ 4, 2 BUTTON "&Start" OF oDlg ;
      ACTION ( TestAds( cDbf ), Alert( "Done" ) )

   ACTIVATE DIALOG oDlg ;

return nil

PROCEDURE TestAds( cDBF )

  LOCAL cField

  RddRegister( "ADS", 1 )
  RddSetDefault( "ADS" )
  AdsSetServerType( 1 )
  AdsSetFileType( 2 )

  USE ( cDBF ) EXCLUSIVE

  IF ! File( "ADSTEST.DBF" )
    COPY STRUCTURE TO ADSTEST
  ENDIF

  USE ADSTEST

  DO WHILE RecCount() < 300000
     APPEND ALL FROM TEST
  ENDDO

  cField := FieldName(1)

  Register_CallBack( {|n| IIF( n < 100, Alert(n), ) } )
  INDEX ON &cField TO (cField)
  UnRegister_CallBack()

RETURN

#pragma BEGINDUMP

#include <windows.h>
#include "ace.h"
#include "hbapi.h"
#include "hbvm.h"
#include "hbapiitm.h"

unsigned long __stdcall ShowPercentage( UNSIGNED16 usPercentDone );

static PHB_ITEM pBlock;

HB_FUNC( REGISTER_CALLBACK )
{
   pBlock = hb_itemParam( 1 );
   AdsRegisterProgressCallback( ShowPercentage );
}

HB_FUNC( UNREGISTER_CALLBACK )
{
   AdsClearProgressCallback();

   if( pBlock )
   {
      hb_itemRelease( pBlock );
   }
}

unsigned long __stdcall ShowPercentage( UNSIGNED16 usPercentDone )
{
   PHB_ITEM pPercent = hb_itemPutNI( NULL, usPercentDone );

   if( pPercent )
   {
      hb_vmEvalBlockV( pBlock, 1, pPercent );
      hb_itemRelease( pPercent );
   }

   return 0;
}

#pragma STOPDUMP

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 09:58:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)

Subject: [Harbour] Harbour filesys and Win32 File API
Message-ID: <000901c0df9a$2f83d360$69d4d7c8@luizguim>

Dear Friends

I Can fix the filesys.c for the Win32 file API,
I´ve done some tests and research and i found the problem.

Normaly the current filesys.c compiled with X__WIN32__ return as errno 5,
which mean ACCESS DENIED.

With my Changes , I now recieve errno 6, which is INVALID HANDLE.

If their is no problem ,i can fix both filesys.c and hbapifs.h

Luiz Rafael Culik



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 10:24:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri May 18 09:24:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Time for a release?
In-Reply-To: <3B04D910.27517.6855705@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Fri, May 18, 2001 at 08:10:56AM -0400
References: <3B046B60.23530.4D8DD25@localhost>; <20010518082300.S7900@hagbard.davep.org> <3B04D910.27517.6855705@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010518142341.B17658@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, May 18, 2001 at 08:10:56AM -0400, Phil Barnett wrote:
> On 18 May 2001, at 8:23, Dave Pearson wrote:
> 
> > There shouldn't be any harm in adding to contrib should there? CT is in
> > contrib isn't it?
> 
> You want new untested stuff in there at release time?

Personally I'm not fussed either way as I don't use any of it. What I was
wondering is that contrib is just that, user contributions. They just happen
to be made available with harbour but they're not part of harbour as such.

Kind of like my harbour-glibc library except I keep it separate from harbour
rather than having something else in the contrib directory.

An impending release of harbour wouldn't stop me from updating harbour-glibc
but, of course, it not actually being in the contrib directory (even though
it is a user contribution to the harbour effort) makes this a slight
different case.

Anyway, you're call. It seemed to be that the contrib stuff wasn't as
critical as harbour itself so we might not need to be so careful about
adding new stuff there.

[Personally I think contrib should be a separate project in its own right
 anyway.]

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 14:01:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 18 13:01:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000401c0dfb8$d36286c0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGEDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> With JF changes, MESSAGEs could be routed to INLINE methods
> (as FW objects does) with no problems,
> 
> but now, with current CVS hbclass.ch, it does not work :-(
> 
> so we may be missing something,

I'm, afraid you are wrong. Try this with FW Objects:

   #INCLUDE "FIVEWIN.CH"

   CLASS MyClass
      DATA nVar
      METHOD  GetVal inline ::nvar
      MESSAGE Other method GetVal
   END CLASS

I get:

   BLINKER : 1115 : TEST.OBJ(TEST) : 'GETVAL' : unresolved external

If you look at the PPO you can easily see that it can NOT work!

Why do you think it does work with FW Objects?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 14:07:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri May 18 13:07:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGEDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <000601c0dfbc$8e21cf40$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron,

Have a look at SOURCE\CLASSES\TProgress.prg and you will see:

   MESSAGE SetPos( nPos ) METHOD _SetPos( nPos )

   METHOD GetPos() INLINE ::nPos

   #ifdef __CLIPPER__
      MESSAGE _nPosition( nPos ) METHOD _SetPos( nPos )
      MESSAGE nPosition METHOD GetPos()
   #endif

It compiles and runs fine,

Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 14:20:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 18 13:20:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000601c0dfbc$8e21cf40$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEGFDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Antonio,

***Where*** in TProgres.prg do you see a message routed to an INLINE
Method???

Here is the class:

CLASS TProgress FROM TControl

   DATA   nMin, nMax, nPos, nStep  AS NUMERIC

   METHOD New( nTop, nLeft, oWnd, nPos, nClrFore,;
               nClrBack, lPixel, lDesign, nWidth, nHeight,;
               cMsg ) CONSTRUCTOR

   METHOD ReDefine( nId, oWnd ) CONSTRUCTOR

   METHOD DeltaPos( nIncrement ) INLINE ;
          SendMessage( ::hWnd, PBM_DELTAPOS, nIncrement )

   MESSAGE SetPos( nPos ) METHOD _SetPos( nPos )

   METHOD SetRange( nMin, nMax ) INLINE ;
          SendMessage( ::hWnd, PBM_SETRANGE, 0, nMakeLong( nMin, nMax ) ),;
          ::nMin := nMin, ::nMax := nMax

   #ifndef __XPP__
      MESSAGE _nPosition( nPos ) METHOD _SetPos( nPos )
      MESSAGE nPosition ALIAS OF nPos
   #endif

   METHOD SetStep( nStepInc ) INLINE ;
          SendMessage( ::hWnd, PBM_SETSTEP, ::nStep := nStepInc )

   METHOD StepIt() INLINE SendMessage( ::hWnd, PBM_STEPIT )

ENDCLASS


Why don't *you* *try* this small sample PLEASE:

   #INCLUDE "FIVEWIN.CH"

   CLASS MyClass
      DATA nVar
      METHOD  GetVal inline ::nvar
      MESSAGE Other method GetVal
   ENDCLASS

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 14:59:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri May 18 13:59:02 2001
Subject: Re[8]: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGBDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGBDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <4349282915.20010518110537@abacuslaw.com>

Ron:

(As I suspected ;-)  the test doesn't test a real scenario.

Popping up an alert box is not a reasonable progress display.
Try something as simple as passing in the oDlg and setting its text in
the callback:
  Register_CallBack( {|n| oDlg:SetText(str(n)) } )
Not only do you not get a change in the title until the INDEX is
finished, the window won't paint at all while it's going (drag another
window over it while it's running, and see the flat gray window).
This makes your app look like "beginning windows programming 101".
You can add a sysrefresh msg pump after the setText, but it doesn't
help.  The real test of course would put a meter on the dialog, which
I will do with your test as well, but if nothing will paint and I
can't change the title bar I doubt a meter will do anything more....


Brian
P.S. I'm using Win2000; let me know if it's any different on your
system.

RP> Brian,

RP> (As I suspected) I'm happy to report that the ADS Indexing Callback Function
RP> appears to works correctly, even within a GUI application, with just 1
RP> thread.

RP> The following is a FWH application that will index and report progress as
RP> expected.

RP> Build it using your standard FWH buildh.bat.

RP> Just start it with a command line parameter of some existing DBF file (and
RP> allow few seconds for the file to be copied enough times to have 300,000
RP> records.

RP> //---------------------------------
RP> TestAds.prg ------------------------------//
RP> #include "FiveWin.ch"

RP> Function Main( cDbf )

RP>    local oDlg

RP>    DEFINE DIALOG oDlg FROM 6, 6 TO 20, 60 TITLE "Test ADS CallBack"

RP>    @ 4, 2 BUTTON "&Start" OF oDlg ;
RP>       ACTION ( TestAds( cDbf ), Alert( "Done" ) )

RP>    ACTIVATE DIALOG oDlg ;

RP> return nil

RP> PROCEDURE TestAds( cDBF )

RP>   LOCAL cField

RP>   RddRegister( "ADS", 1 )
RP>   RddSetDefault( "ADS" )
RP>   AdsSetServerType( 1 )
RP>   AdsSetFileType( 2 )

RP>   USE ( cDBF ) EXCLUSIVE

RP>   IF ! File( "ADSTEST.DBF" )
RP>     COPY STRUCTURE TO ADSTEST
RP>   ENDIF

RP>   USE ADSTEST

RP>   DO WHILE RecCount() < 300000
RP>      APPEND ALL FROM TEST
RP>   ENDDO

RP>   cField := FieldName(1)

RP>   Register_CallBack( {|n| IIF( n < 100, Alert(n), ) } )
RP>   INDEX ON &cField TO (cField)
RP>   UnRegister_CallBack()

RP> RETURN

RP> #pragma BEGINDUMP

RP> #include <windows.h>
RP> #include "ace.h"
RP> #include "hbapi.h"
RP> #include "hbvm.h"
RP> #include "hbapiitm.h"

RP> unsigned long __stdcall ShowPercentage( UNSIGNED16 usPercentDone );

RP> static PHB_ITEM pBlock;

RP> HB_FUNC( REGISTER_CALLBACK )
RP> {
RP>    pBlock = hb_itemParam( 1 );
RP>    AdsRegisterProgressCallback( ShowPercentage );
RP> }

RP> HB_FUNC( UNREGISTER_CALLBACK )
RP> {
RP>    AdsClearProgressCallback();

RP>    if( pBlock )
RP>    {
RP>       hb_itemRelease( pBlock );
RP>    }
RP> }

RP> unsigned long __stdcall ShowPercentage( UNSIGNED16 usPercentDone )
RP> {
RP>    PHB_ITEM pPercent = hb_itemPutNI( NULL, usPercentDone );

RP>    if( pPercent )
RP>    {
RP>       hb_vmEvalBlockV( pBlock, 1, pPercent );
RP>       hb_itemRelease( pPercent );
RP>    }

RP>    return 0;
RP> }

RP> #pragma STOPDUMP

RP> _______________________________________________
RP> Harbour mailing list
RP> Harbour@matrixlist.com
RP> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour

RP> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
RP> http://www.Harbour-Project.org



 ---====---
 Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 15:05:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 18 14:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000501c0dfb9$7fc90c40$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEGGDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > > > That's because MESSAGEs can NOT be routed to INLINE
> > > > Methods.
> > >
> > > Why not ?
> >
> > Because it was never designed to do that!
>
> I can not understand such restriction...
>
> > Why does it NOT work with Objects?
>
> I may be wrong, but it does work with Objetcs.
>
> Anyhow, we should be able to implement such a logical
> and needed feature in Harbour.

You probably want to use MESSAGE <Msg> ALIAS OF <Mtd> instead. This works
with FW Objects:

//-------------------------------//
#INCLUDE "FIVEWIN.CH"

Procedure Main

   local o := MyClass():New(7)

   Alert( Str( o:GetVal() ) )

   Alert( Str( o:Other ) )

return

CLASS MyClass
   VAR nVar
   Method New Constructor
   METHOD  GetVal inline ::nvar
   MESSAGE Other alias of GetVal
END CLASS

Method New(n) Class MyClass

  ::nVar := n

return Self
//-------------------------------//

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 16:11:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri May 18 15:11:02 2001
Subject: Re[10]: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <4253594064.20010518121728@abacuslaw.com>

Ron:

RP> The fact that the CallBack *is* being indeed called, and the block
RP> *evaluated*, suggests the problem is elsewhere!!!
Where?

RP> How is it different than trying to update the Dialog from any other Harbour
RP> code???
Because it is.

RP> If The code executes the Alert(), why would it not be able to perform
RP> anything else?
Because it doesn't.

This is a well-documented problem with Windows and the fact that the
Local server DLL keeps indexing with the primary thread, but apparently spawns a second thread
to do the callback. Years ago they handled it for Delphi programmers
by showing how to do the indexing with a second thread.
Apparently the Alert creation is entirely direct-called functions (no
relying on Windows msgs to appear??) OR since the dlg is created by
that thread its DialogProc is accessible.
But for an existing window (and the app window) messages are not
processed until the Index is finished. Even SetWindowText becomes a
SendMessage call, so it fails.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 22:19:02 2001

Subject: [Harbour] APPEND FROM buglet
Message-ID: <2475685029.20010518182539@abacuslaw.com>

Harrier:

APPEND FROM should be able to append from a non-matching structure,
ignoring any unknown fields and populating any fields with matching names.
Now, it blows up with a Data type error if the source has "bad"
fields.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 18 22:41:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?=)
Date: Fri May 18 21:41:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour filesys and Win32 File API
References: <000901c0df9a$2f83d360$69d4d7c8@luizguim><000b01c0dfb5$eda8a120$31d4d7c8@luizguim> <7748239554.20010518104813@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <00a201c0e004$b26af960$f004a8c0@ksoft20000507>

Luiz,

Please check that I have corrected that error and completed many other
functions that did not have support for W32 in filesys.c.
I checked the broken samples supplied and they worked.

I posted some time ago to the list for volunteers to test it.

The missing point was that some functions called from gtxxx.c used the
normal file handles and could not work with the Win32 HANDLE.
Because of that (there were some messages against that) I did not cvs'ed it.

If you want I can CVS it disabled with the _XWIN32_, in order for testing
before resolving this problem.

The pending question is what to do with normal handles that the code may
have around.

I was thinking of put a flag in Harbour "handle" but the size of it is the
same of the size of Win32 handle (no spare bits!). Maybe if the Harbour
handle can be expanded, the filesys.c functions can be expanded to be
compatible with both flavors.

regards
Horacio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 19 14:35:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sat May 19 13:35:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] hbclass.ch (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <200105191207.f4JC7J626409@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGLDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

J.F., Antonio, All,

> No, it is no actually implemented into hbclass.ch.
>
> What I can do easely is to allow this syntax to alias Method inline
> _but_ the conterpart will be that it will _only_ be allowed to alias
> inline method !!!
>
> What do you think ?

Just to clarify, this is *not* a Harbour limitation, but rather a given! The
same syntax can *not* cover both INLINE and normal (*not* declared) Methods.
This is the reason Antonio has different Syntax in FW Objects too.

   MESSAGE <Msg> METHOD <Mtd> // Only good for normal (function) Methods.

   MESSAGE <Msg> ALIAS OF <Property> // Only good for properties, inlined,
or declared Methods.

The only way the same syntax could be used is if Methods that have a MESSAGE
alias, *must* be declared themselves. This will create a minor compatibility
issue, but I consider this a FIX for a *not* well thought implementation!

Here is a sample of how this syntax could/should work:

   CLASS MyClass
      VAR nVal
      METHOD GetVal() INLINE ::nVal
      MSSAGE Val METHOD GetVal // Will work because GetVal already
*declared* as an INLINE.
      METHOD PutVal( n ) // PutVal declared.
      MESSAGE SetVal(n) METHOD PutVal(n) // Will work too, because PutVal()
is already declared.
   ENDCLASS

???

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 19 14:44:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat May 19 13:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
Message-ID: <1134769368.20010519105023@abacuslaw.com>

Bill:

>>This will be fixed in Advantage 6.1 coming out in July.

Any chance it will address the Window refresh issues for other
operations besides indexing?  Can I contact someone about what's
happening with Harbour apps?

 ---====---
 Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 19 14:57:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sat May 19 13:57:02 2001
Subject: Re[8]: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGLDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Hi Bill,

> This will be fixed in Advantage 6.1 coming out in July.

Thanks for the input!

In the meantime I got a chance to read a sample Delphi code you guys provide
to demonstrate usage of MT to overcome this issue, and that [I think]
clarified the problem for me.

It seems the ADS Local Server creates a Secondary Thread to handle the
CALLBACK, while using the Primary Thread to perform the indexing. The
problem with this design, is that the primary thread and the WinProc never
becomes available to handle the Messages sent to it.

In the above sample, ExtSys suggests that the *Developer* should create a
Secondary Thread from which to call the ADS Indexing Routines, thus leaving
the Primary Thread available to handle incoming Messages. As you must have
found out, it would be more sensible, for the ADS Indexing Routines to
either initiate a Secondary Thread for the actual Indexing, and implementing
the CALLBACK in the Primary Thread, or to not use a Secondary Thread at all,
instead just allowing for a Message Handling within the Indexing Routines.

Any chance you could clarify if the above reading is correct, and what is
the intended change, in more details?

TIA,

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 19 18:50:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat May 19 17:50:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: MultiThread (was ADS index callbacks)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGLDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEGLDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <30149541679.20010519145636@abacuslaw.com>

Ron:

RP> It seems the ADS Local Server creates a Secondary Thread to handle the
RP> CALLBACK, while using the Primary Thread to perform the indexing. The
RP> problem with this design, is that the primary thread and the WinProc never
RP> becomes available to handle the Messages sent to it.

RP> In the above sample, ExtSys suggests that the *Developer* should create a
RP> Secondary Thread from which to call the ADS Indexing Routines, thus leaving
RP> the Primary Thread available to handle incoming Messages. As you must have
RP> found out, it would be more sensible, for the ADS Indexing Routines to
RP> either initiate a Secondary Thread for the actual Indexing, and implementing
RP> the CALLBACK in the Primary Thread,

This is what I proposed to ExtSys a couple months back when the issue
first arose.  It looks like they may have taken the request seriously!
Since this is how the Remote Server DLL handles it (there are no
problems at all with the Remote Server and current Harbour code), we
can hope it's an easy fix for them.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

+contrib/hbzlib/hbzip2.h

+contrib/hbzlib/zip.c

    *makefile to make the new hbzlib

    *Docs for the new hbzlib function interface

the file under linux)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 19 20:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Administrador del sistema Anti-Virus)
Date: Sat May 19 19:53:02 2001
Subject: un archivo adjunto de tipo no permitido encontrado en un mensaje para usted con asunto "[Harbour] Set delete on with error on  Harbour"
Message-ID: <20010519235226.29643.qmail@server1.xnetcuyo.com.ar>

Atencion <harbour@matrixlist.com>, "Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes" <culik@nh.conex.com.br> le ha
enviado un mensaje que fue retenido por el sistema antivirus.

Se ha encontrado un archivo adjunto de tipo no permitido en el mensaje destinado a usted. 
El programa antivirus ha interceptado el mensaje completo
y no le llegara. El remitente ya fue avisado de esta situacion
y se envio copia de dicho aviso al "Administrador del sistema Anti-Virus".

Para evitar el ataque de virus de e-mail, se recomienda NO usar 
Outlook ya que es el único cliente de mail vulnerable a estos virus.
El antivirus reporta que el un archivo adjunto de tipo no permitido es: 

Archivo .EXE: No se aceptan ejecutables adjuntos a mensajes porque podrian comprometer la seguridad o contener virus.



Pongase en contacto con el Administrador del sistema Anti-Virus si necesita mas informacion sobre
el mensaje o las politicas de control antivirus implementadas en su sistema.
Su mensaje llego con las siguientes instrucciones:

MAIL FROM: harbour-admin@matrixlist.com
RCPT TO:   anv@xnetcuyo.com.ar 

... y las siguientescabeceras:

De:         "Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes" <culik@nh.conex.com.br>
Para:       <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Asunto:     [Harbour] Set delete on with error on  Harbour
ID-Message: <003e01c0e055$cfa4cd20$14d4d7c8@luizguim>
Fecha:      Sat, 19 May 2001 07:48:13 -0300


El mensaje original ha quedado guardado en:

  server1:/var/spool/qmailscan/viruses

donde el Administrador del sistema Anti-Virus puede verificar su contenido.

El programa antivirus reporto lo siguiente al revisar el mensaje:

--- 

---perlscanner results ---
un archivo adjunto de tipo no permitido 'Archivo .EXE: No se aceptan ejecutables adjuntos a mensajes porque podrian comprometer la seguridad o contener virus.' estaba en /var/spool/qmailscan/server199031632729629/BUGDELE.EXE
---
[Procesado por qmail-scan usando McAfee/NA uvscan en GNU/Linux]

With SET DELETED ON, NO deleted records should be visible.
Can we get more details?
 ---====---
 Brian Hays


LRCG> Dear Friends Alexander and Brian

LRCG> The follow error was sended to me by Jorge Manson Salinas.See translation
LRCG> below

>>El siguiente bug se produce en harbour cuando abro una tabla con indice y
busco >>los registros con un seek y teniendo set delete on igual me muestra
el primer >>registro borrado. Parece que lo mismo pasa usando con el RDD de
LRCG> ADS.

LRCG> The follow bug is produced with harbour when i open an database file wit
LRCG> index, and o search the records with an seek and with Set Deleted On only
LRCG> show me the first record deleted. The same occurs using the RDD ADS

>>FUNCTION MAIN

>>  SET DELETED ON
>>  USE DETREU INDEX DETREU SHARED
>>  SEEK STR(8,10)
>>  IF DELETED()
>>     ? "PERDON POR SALIR ... ESTABA BORRADO :("
>>  ELSE
>>     ? "ESTOY BORRADO NO PUEDO SALIR ... :)"
>>  ENDIF

>>RETURN NIL

LRCG> Regards


LRCG> Luiz Rafael Culik

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 20 10:50:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Sun May 20 09:50:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] New HBZLib available
References: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIIEJJGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <00a301c0d30e$c15d6460$20d4d7c8@luizguim>

Patrick


> Luiz,
>
> > > HB_ZipFileByTDSpan()  ---> Create a ziparchive on HD, You can
> > > also set the size of the span archive(you can make files an low
> > > an 100Kb , or zip archives for backup data on CD´s (650Mb)
>
> What is the meaning of the letters TD in "HB_ZipFileByTDSpan()"

TD -> Disk spaning mode.
This feature was only found on RAR .
on RAR this is set with
rar -v<size>[k,b] create volumes with size =<size>*1000 [*1024,*1]

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 20 18:24:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Sun May 20 17:24:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 2001-05-20 23:15 UTC+1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGLDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200105191207.f4JC7J626409@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <200105202122.f4KLMm623464@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>

2001-05-20 23:15 UTC+1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
   * harbour/source/vm/classes.c
     + hb_objGetRealClsName(object, szmsg )
       Return the real class name regarding the Message called
       So as an inherited method will return it's real class parent
   * harbour/source/vm/proc.c
     * modified PROCNAME() to call the new classes function
   * harbour/include/hbapi.h
     + added hb_objGetRealClsName
   * harbour/include/hbclass.ch
     + added xtranslate to allow MethodName as the same as 
ProcName
       (a la class(y) )


Best regards,

J. Lefebvre,
Bruxelles,
Belgium

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 20 18:25:33 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Sun May 20 17:25:33 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fixed ProcName & added MethodName Alias
Message-ID: <200105202122.f4KLMn623471@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>

Fixed Procname() and added MethodName() alias as I considered 
it as a bug to be fixed before any new release.

Fully tested, should not break anything.

Before this procname returned just the current ClassName even 
when a message was inherited. so you has to be very attentif when 
looking for an error.


Best regards,

J. Lefebvre,
Bruxelles,
Belgium

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 20 21:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun May 20 20:02:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gpf in SET RELATION
Message-ID: <144243858249.20010520170832@abacuslaw.com>

------------1062243115D580C
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Alexander, Ryszard and anyone else:

SET RELATION ADDITIVE is corrupting memory.
There's a delayed Blowup that occurs after setting such relations, then
clearing them, then setting another, perhaps in the opposite
direction.

The attached zip has a small prg and the datafiles it uses.
I can delay the blowup by changing the order in which fields
are displayed with QOut()--for instance, just comment out line 46 :
    ? 2->u_id1
...but in a real app it eventually blows somewhere, usually in the
Recno() function.

The actual error under Win2000 is reported as:
    unknown software exception 0xc00000fd

This is with ADS, but it seems to be an RDD level problem. (DBFCDX
doesn't yet support some of these features, so I can't test it.)

If anyone can help isolate where in the rdd things get whacked, it
would be greatly appreciated.  The problem seems to be that the
Exception is the result of something that misbehaves earlier.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays
------------1062243115D580C
Content-Type: application/x-zip-compressed; name="test.zip"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="test.zip"

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 04:44:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Mon May 21 03:44:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: gpf in SET RELATION
In-Reply-To: <144243858249.20010520170832@abacuslaw.com>
References: <144243858249.20010520170832@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <14411643060.20010521113408@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 21.05.2001 4:08, Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> wrote:

BH> Alexander, Ryszard and anyone else:

BH> SET RELATION ADDITIVE is corrupting memory.
BH> There's a delayed Blowup that occurs after setting such relations, then
BH> clearing them, then setting another, perhaps in the opposite
BH> direction.
BH> ...
BH> This is with ADS, but it seems to be an RDD level problem.

 Probably,  but  they  occurs  while  executing  ADS  functions (
 AdsGetRecordNum(),  AdsGetField() ). And after I comment calls of ADS
 functions  in  adsSetRel()  (  AdsSetRelation() ) and adsClearRel() (
 AdsClearRelation() ), the GPF's disappears ...
 
 It could be useful to write a pure C routine, which do the same as
 your Harbour code sample - opens files, set and clear relations - and
 check it.


Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 04:51:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Jacek Kaleta)
Date: Mon May 21 03:51:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Error in gtapi.c, function hb_gtBoxD
Message-ID: <000501c0e1ca$e9f27bc0$c8c060d9@t4z7y4>

file: gtapi.c
        
function:
USHORT hb_gtBoxD( USHORT uiTop, USHORT uiLeft, USHORT uiBottom, USHORT 

line 218:
hb_gt_VertLine( uiLeft, uiTop, uiBottom, HB_B_DOUBLE_H, ( BYTE ) 

should be:
hb_gt_VertLine( uiLeft, uiTop, uiBottom, HB_B_DOUBLE_V, ( BYTE ) 

line 221:
hb_gt_HorizLine( uiTop, uiLeft, uiRight, HB_B_DOUBLE_V, ( BYTE ) 

should be:
hb_gt_HorizLine( uiTop, uiLeft, uiRight, HB_B_DOUBLE_H, ( BYTE ) 



To check:

@ 10,0 to 10,79 double

/* @ 11,0 to 11,79 */



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 04:58:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon May 21 03:58:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Fixed ProcName & added MethodName Alias
In-Reply-To: <200105202122.f4KLMn623471@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>; from jfl@wanadoo.be on Sun, May 20, 2001 at 11:23:12PM +0200
References: <200105202122.f4KLMn623471@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <20010521082058.I21127@hagbard.davep.org>

On Sun, May 20, 2001 at 11:23:12PM +0200, JF Lefebvre wrote:

> Fixed Procname() and added MethodName() alias as I considered it as a bug
> to be fixed before any new release.

If I'm reading your ChangeLog entry correctly you've added MethodName() as a
translate. That'll make it impossible to use in situations where you're way
past the pre-processor state. Think macro compilation and all forms of
run-time creation of expressions (think a debugger command line too).

--

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 07:05:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May 21 06:05:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX RDD question
In-Reply-To: <3B08E9F6.8903.35D7D1@localhost>
Message-ID: <000001c0e1dd$0e92d620$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

It seems Harbour DBFCDX RDD does not provide
support for memo files.

It GPFs when a memo field is going to be created.

Could someone confirm it ?

Do we have a list of DBFCDX RDD missing or failing features ?

many thanks!

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 07:12:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May 21 06:12:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX RDD question
In-Reply-To: <000001c0e1dd$0e92d620$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <000301c0e1de$04e54ee0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

My previous msg is wrong, sorry. 

It seems DBFCDX RDD does create the DBF, 
CDX and FTP files, but GPFs when trying to 
perform a DbCloseArea(). This is the code:

   if ! File( cPath + "\Scripts.dbf" )
      DbCreate( cPath + "\Scripts.dbf",;
                { { "NAME",     "C",  30, 0 },;
                  { "CATEGORY", "C",  30, 0 },;
                  { "CODE",     "M",  10, 0 },;
                  { "COMMENTS", "C",  45, 0 } } )
   endif

   if ! File( cPath + "\Scripts" + IndexExt() )
      USE ( cPath + "\Scripts.dbf" ) NEW ALIAS Scripts
      INDEX ON Name TAG "Name" ;
         TO ( cPath + "\Scripts" ) FOR ! Scripts->( Deleted() )
      INDEX ON Category + Name TAG "Categories" ;
         TO ( cPath + "\Scripts" ) FOR ! Scripts->( Deleted() )
      USE    <<<<<<<< Here we get a GPF on DbCloseArea() call
   endif

Thanks!

Antonio




From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 07:25:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May 21 06:25:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX RDD question
In-Reply-To: <000301c0e1de$04e54ee0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <000501c0e1df$db9b0460$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0006_01C0E1F0.9F23D460
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

This is the complete sample that GPFs.

Thanks a lot for your help,

Antonio

------=_NextPart_000_0006_01C0E1F0.9F23D460
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;
	name="test2.prg"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="test2.prg"

request DBFCDX

function Main()

  local cPath := "."

  RddSetDefault( "DBFCDX" )

  if ! File( cPath + "\Scripts.dbf" )
      DbCreate( cPath + "\Scripts.dbf",;
                { { "NAME",     "C",  30, 0 },;
                  { "CATEGORY", "C",  30, 0 },;
                  { "CODE",     "M",  10, 0 },;
                  { "COMMENTS", "C",  45, 0 } } )
   endif

   if ! File( cPath + "\Scripts" + IndexExt() )
      USE ( cPath + "\Scripts.dbf" ) NEW ALIAS Scripts
      INDEX ON Name TAG "Name" ;
         TO ( cPath + "\Scripts" ) FOR ! Scripts->( Deleted() )
      INDEX ON Category + Name TAG "Categories" ;
         TO ( cPath + "\Scripts" ) FOR ! Scripts->( Deleted() )
      USE    // <<<<<<<< Here we get a GPF on DbCloseArea() call
   endif

return nil
------=_NextPart_000_0006_01C0E1F0.9F23D460--



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 21 08:19:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Mon May 21 07:19:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: gpf in SET RELATION
In-Reply-To: <14411643060.20010521113408@belacy.belgorod.su>
References: <144243858249.20010520170832@abacuslaw.com>
 <14411643060.20010521113408@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <6724997166.20010521151640@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 21.05.2001 11:34, Alexander S.Kresin <alex@belacy.belgorod.su> wrote:

ASK>  It could be useful to write a pure C routine, which do the same as
ASK>  your Harbour code sample - opens files, set and clear relations - and
ASK>  check it.

 I wrote such routine - and it GPF's, too ! So, it seems to be ADS
 bug.
 Here it is:

#include <windows.h>
#include "ace.h"
#include <stdio.h>

void main( void )
{
   UNSIGNED32  ulRetVal;
   ADSHANDLE   hTable1, hTable2, hTable3;
   ADSHANDLE   hIndex1, hIndex2, hIndex3;
   UNSIGNED32  ulRecNo;

   AdsSetServerType ( 1 );

   ulRetVal = AdsOpenTable( 0, "LAW1.DBF", "NAMES", ADS_CDX,
        ADS_ANSI, ADS_COMPATIBLE_LOCKING, ADS_CHECKRIGHTS, ADS_DEFAULT, &hTable1 );
   printf( "\nOpening Law1: %ld:", ulRetVal );

   ulRetVal = AdsOpenTable( 0, "LAW3.DBF", "MATTERS", ADS_CDX,
        ADS_ANSI, ADS_COMPATIBLE_LOCKING, ADS_CHECKRIGHTS, ADS_DEFAULT, &hTable3 );
   printf( "\nOpening Law3: %ld:", ulRetVal );
   ulRetVal = AdsGetIndexHandle( hTable3, "U_ID", &hIndex3 );
   printf( "\nOrdsetfocus( u_id ): %ld:", ulRetVal );

   ulRetVal = AdsOpenTable( 0, "LAW2.DBF", "EVENTS", ADS_CDX,
        ADS_ANSI, ADS_COMPATIBLE_LOCKING, ADS_CHECKRIGHTS, ADS_DEFAULT, &hTable2 );
   printf( "\nOpening Law2: %ld:", ulRetVal );
   ulRetVal = AdsGetIndexHandle( hTable2, "ID", &hIndex2 );
   printf( "\nOrdsetfocus( id ): %ld:", ulRetVal );

   AdsClearRelation( hTable1 );
   ulRetVal = AdsSetRelation( hTable1, hIndex2, "U_ID" );
   printf( "\nAdsSetRelation: %ld:", ulRetVal );

   AdsGetRecordNum( hTable2, ADS_IGNOREFILTERS, &ulRecNo );

   AdsClearRelation( hTable1 );

   ulRetVal = AdsGetIndexHandle( hTable1, "U_ID", &hIndex1 );
   printf( "\nOrdsetfocus( u_id ): %ld:", ulRetVal );

   ulRetVal = AdsSetRelation( hTable2, hIndex1, "U_ID1" );
   printf( "\nAdsSetRelation: %ld:", ulRetVal );

   ulRetVal = AdsSetRelation( hTable2, hIndex3, "U_ID3" );
   printf( "\nAdsSetRelation: %ld:", ulRetVal );

   AdsGetRecordNum( hTable1, ADS_IGNOREFILTERS, &ulRecNo );
   printf( "\nAdsGetRecordNum(1): %ld:", ulRecNo );
   AdsGetRecordNum( hTable3, ADS_IGNOREFILTERS, &ulRecNo );
   printf( "\nAdsGetRecordNum(3): %ld:", ulRecNo );

   AdsCloseTable( hTable1 );
   AdsCloseTable( hTable2 );
   AdsCloseTable( hTable3 );

}

 It GPF's after last AdsGetRecordNum().
 
 What is interesting, it is Ok, if there is

    AdsGetRecordNum( hTable2, ADS_IGNOREFILTERS, &ulRecNo );

 instead of

    AdsGetRecordNum( hTable3, ADS_IGNOREFILTERS, &ulRecNo );



Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/
