From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 22 00:03:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?=)
Date: Mon May 21 23:03:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour filesys and Win32 File API
Message-ID: <000a01c0e255$f4c08890$f004a8c0@ksoft20000507>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_00C3_01C0E1A8.6120AAA0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

LC>Horacio

LC>Can you send your changes directly to me , to see if match the change i
did.
LC>O my tests , GetLastError() now return an ERROR_INVALID_HANDLE.
LC>this probaly occurs becouse the original handle is trasformed into an int

Have you fixed the error handling? It was reporting errors when there was no
one.

LC> The gwtin.c use the Windows handle support
You're right. I've seen gtstd.c.
But take a look at console.c. It calls:
   s_iFilenoStdout = fileno( stdout );
   s_iFilenoStderr = fileno( stderr );
   hb_fsSetDevMode( s_iFilenoStdout, FD_BINARY );
   hb_fsSetDevMode( s_iFilenoStderr, FD_BINARY );

> The pending question is what to do with normal handles that the code may
> have around.

I mean (as others pointed out) ANSI C handles from xxx.c (maybe 3rd. party
libs). It would be great to have a compatible Harbour FHANDLE with a flag
for the type of handle and the handle itself. In that way the api routines
could be compatible with both handles as long as they respect the Harbour
FHANDLE.

LC>One more things. How are you handling the return value of the WIN32
Handle.
LC>As an answer from an question that ive post on the microsoft.vc group, if
LC>the handle is convert to int it return error 6
I put it in the harbour FHANDLE (int) and it seems to work ok (at least in
my test). Take a look at the error handling.

I forward you the original message with the list of functions that have
Win32 support corrected or added.
The filesys.c attached don't have the last commits from the cvs but it
should work. I should refresh it :-)

regards
Horacio

----- Original Message -----
From: "Horacio Roldán" <horacioroldan@usa.net>
To: <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Sent: Friday, March 30, 2001 9:30 AM
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Unlimited File Handles


> Ron (or/and anyone with spare time )
>
> I fixed the FRead problem (it was actually a FOpen problem), but doing
that
> I discovered other problems with the win32 routines (especially error
> checking).
> I fixed them: (hb_fsClose, hb_fsRead, hb_fsWrite, hb_fsReadLarge,
> hb_fsWriteLarge, hb_fsSeek, hb_fsTell).
>
> Many filesys.c routines works with handles but they didn't had support for
> win32, so they failed as it seems that the "normal" handles (eg: open() )
> are not compatible with the ones from the win32 api (Createfile).
> I added support for: hb_fsEof , hb_fsCommit, hb_fsLock,
convert_seek_flags.
>
> I don't cvs'ed the file because of two reasons:
> - asking for testing (the file is attached)
> - there is still potencial incompatibilities with handles not created with
> hb_fsOpen (I found them in console.c at least)
>
>
> regards
> Horacio
>

	name="filesys.c"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="filesys.c"

/*
 * $Id: filesys.c,v 1.149 2001/02/28 08:11:27 ronpinkas Exp $
 */

/*

 * The FileSys API (C level)

 * and/or the Harbour Virtual Machine (HVM) with other files to produce
 * an executable, this does not by itself cause the resulting executable
 * to be covered by the GNU General Public License. Your use of that
 * executable is in no way restricted on account of linking the HRL
 * and/or HVM code into it.

 * but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 * GNU General Public License for more details.

 * Foundation, Inc., 675 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA (or visit
 * their web site at http://www.gnu.org/).

/*
 * The following parts are Copyright of the individual authors.
 * www - http://www.harbour-project.org
 *
 * Copyright 1999 Victor Szakats <info@szelvesz.hu>
 *    hb_fsSetError()
 *    hb_fsSetDevMode()
 *    hb_fsReadLarge()
 *    hb_fsWriteLarge()
 *    hb_fsCurDirBuff()
 *
 * Copyright 1999 Jose Lalin <dezac@corevia.com>
 *    hb_fsChDrv()
 *    hb_fsCurDrv()
 *    hb_fsIsDrv()
 *    hb_fsIsDevice()
 *
 * Copyright 2000 Luiz Rafael Culik <culik@sl.conex.net>
 *            and David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>
 *    hb_fsEof()
 *
 * Copyright 2001 Jose Gimenez (JFG) <jfgimenez@wanadoo.es>
 *                                   <tecnico.sireinsa@ctv.es>
 *    Added __WIN32__ check for any compiler to use the Win32
 *    API calls to allow openning an unlimited number of files
 *    simultaneously.
 *
 * See doc/license.txt for licensing terms.
 *
 */

/* NOTE: In DOS/DJGPP under WinNT4 hb_fsSeek( fhnd, offset < 0, FS_SET) =
will
         set the file pointer to the passed negative value, and the =
subsequent
         hb_fsWrite() call will fail. In CA-Clipper hb_fsSeek() will =
fail,
         the pointer will not be moved, and thus the hb_fsWrite() call =
will
         successfully write the buffer to the current file position. =
[vszakats]

   This has been corrected by ptucker
 */

#include <ctype.h>

#include "hbapi.h"
#include "hbapifs.h"

#if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(__MINGW32__)
   #include <sys/types.h>
   #include <sys/stat.h>
   #include <unistd.h>
   #include <fcntl.h>
   #include <errno.h>

   #if !defined(OS_UNIX_COMPATIBLE)
      #include <io.h>
   #endif
   #if defined(__DJGPP__)
      #include <dir.h>
      #define _getdrive getdisk
      #define _chdrive  setdisk
   #endif

   #if !defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO)
      #define HAVE_POSIX_IO
   #endif

   extern int rename( const char *, const char * );

#endif

#if defined(__WATCOMC__)
   #include <sys/stat.h>
   #include <share.h>
   #include <fcntl.h>
   #include <io.h>
   #include <direct.h>
   #include <errno.h>
   #include <dos.h>

   #if !defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO)
      #define HAVE_POSIX_IO
   #endif
   #define ftruncate chsize
#endif

#if defined(__BORLANDC__) || defined(__IBMCPP__) || defined(_MSC_VER) || =
defined(__MINGW32__)
   #include <sys\stat.h>
   #include <share.h>
   #include <fcntl.h>
   #include <io.h>
   #include <direct.h>
   #if defined(__BORLANDC__)
      #include <dir.h>
      #include <dos.h>
      #include <windows.h>
   #endif

   #if defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MINGW32__)
      #include <sys\locking.h>
      #define ftruncate _chsize
   #else
      #define ftruncate chsize
      #if !defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO)
         #define HAVE_POSIX_IO
      #endif
   #endif
   #include <errno.h>
#endif

#if defined(__MPW__)
   #include <fcntl.h>
#endif

#if defined(HB_OS_DOS)
   #include <dos.h>
#endif

#ifndef O_BINARY
   #define O_BINARY     0       /* O_BINARY not defined on Linux */
#endif

#ifndef S_IEXEC
   #define S_IEXEC      0x0040  /* owner may execute <directory search> =
*/
#endif

#ifndef S_IRWXU
   #define S_IRWXU      0x01C0  /* RWE permissions mask for owner */
#endif

#ifndef S_IRUSR
   #define S_IRUSR      0x0100  /* owner may read */
#endif

#ifndef S_IWUSR
   #define S_IWUSR      0x0080  /* owner may write */
#endif

#ifndef S_IXUSR
   #define S_IXUSR      0x0040  /* owner may execute <directory search> =
*/
#endif

#ifndef SH_COMPAT
   #define SH_COMPAT    0x00    /* Compatibility */
#endif

#ifndef SH_DENYRW
   #define SH_DENYRW    0x10    /* Deny read/write */
#endif

#ifndef SH_DENYWR
   #define SH_DENYWR    0x20    /* Deny write */
#endif

#ifndef SH_DENYRD
   #define SH_DENYRD    0x30    /* Deny read */
#endif

#ifndef SH_DENYNO
   #define SH_DENYNO    0x40    /* Deny nothing */
#endif

static USHORT s_uiErrorLast =3D 0;

#if defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) || defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MINGW32__)
/* Only compilers with Posix or Posix-like I/O support are supported */
   #define HB_FS_FILE_IO
#endif

#if defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MINGW32__) || defined(__IBMCPP__) || =
defined(__WATCOMC__)
/* These compilers use sopen() rather than open(), because their
   versions of open() do not support combined O_ and SH_ flags */
   #define HB_FS_SOPEN
#endif

#if ( defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) && ( defined(HB_OS_OS2) || =
defined(HB_OS_DOS) || defined(_Windows) || defined(_WIN32) ) && ! =
defined(__CYGWIN__) ) || defined(__MINGW32__)
/* These platforms and/or compilers have common drive letter support */
   #define HB_FS_DRIVE_LETTER
#endif

#if UINT_MAX =3D=3D ULONG_MAX
   #define HB_FS_LARGE_OPTIMIZED
#else
   #define LARGE_MAX ( UINT_MAX - 1L )
#endif

/* Convert HARBOUR flags to IO subsystem flags */

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

static int convert_open_flags( USHORT uiFlags )
{
   /* by default FO_READ + FO_COMPAT is set */
   int result_flags =3D 0;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("convert_open_flags(%hu)", uiFlags));

   result_flags |=3D O_BINARY;
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added O_BINARY\n"));

#if defined(HB_FS_SOPEN)
   if( ( uiFlags & ( FO_WRITE | FO_READWRITE ) ) =3D=3D FO_READ )
   {
      result_flags |=3D O_RDONLY;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added O_RDONLY\n"));
   }
#else

   if( ( uiFlags & ( FO_WRITE | FO_READWRITE ) ) =3D=3D FO_READ )
   {
      result_flags |=3D ( O_RDONLY | SH_COMPAT );
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added O_RDONLY =
SH_COMPAT\n"));
   }
#endif

   /* read & write flags */
   if( uiFlags & FO_WRITE )
   {
      result_flags |=3D O_WRONLY;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added O_WRONLY\n"));
   }

   if( uiFlags & FO_READWRITE )
   {
      result_flags |=3D O_RDWR;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added O_RDWR\n"));
   }

#if ! defined(HB_FS_SOPEN)
   /* shared flags */
   if( ( uiFlags & FO_DENYREAD ) =3D=3D FO_DENYREAD )
   {
      result_flags |=3D SH_DENYRD;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added SH_DENYRD\n"));
   }

   else if( uiFlags & FO_EXCLUSIVE )
   {
      result_flags |=3D SH_DENYRW;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added SH_DENYRW\n"));
   }

   else if( uiFlags & FO_DENYWRITE )
   {
      result_flags |=3D SH_DENYWR;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added SH_DENYWR\n"));
   }

   if( uiFlags & FO_DENYNONE )
   {
      result_flags |=3D SH_DENYNO;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added SH_DENYNO\n"));
   }

   if( uiFlags & FO_SHARED )
   {
      result_flags |=3D SH_DENYNO;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: added SH_DENYNO\n"));
   }
#endif

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_open_flags: result is 0x%04x\n", =
result_flags));

   return result_flags;
}

static int convert_seek_flags( USHORT uiFlags )
{
   /* by default FS_SET is set */
   int result_flags =3D SEEK_SET;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("convert_seek_flags(%hu)", uiFlags));

   #if defined(__WIN32__)

     switch ( uiFlags )
     {
        case FS_SET :
          result_flags =3D FILE_BEGIN;
          break;
        case FS_RELATIVE :
          result_flags =3D FILE_CURRENT;
          break;
        case FS_END :
          result_flags =3D FILE_END;
          break;
     }

   #else
      if( uiFlags & FS_RELATIVE )
         result_flags =3D SEEK_CUR;

      if( uiFlags & FS_END )
         result_flags =3D SEEK_END;
   #endif

   return result_flags;
}

static void convert_create_flags( USHORT uiFlags, int * result_flags, =
unsigned * result_pmode )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("convert_create_flags(%hu, %p, %p)", uiFlags, =
result_flags, result_pmode));

   /* by default FC_NORMAL is set */

   *result_flags =3D O_BINARY | O_CREAT | O_TRUNC | O_RDWR;
   *result_pmode =3D S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR;

   if( uiFlags & FC_READONLY )
   {
      *result_pmode =3D S_IRUSR;
      HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_create_flags: S_IRUSR"));
   }

   if( uiFlags & FC_HIDDEN )
      *result_flags |=3D 0;

   if( uiFlags & FC_SYSTEM )
      *result_flags |=3D 0;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("convert_create_flags: 0x%04x, 0x%04x\n", =
*result_flags, *result_pmode));
}

#endif


/*
 * FILESYS.API FUNCTIONS --
 */

FHANDLE hb_fsOpen( BYTE * pFilename, USHORT uiFlags )
{
   FHANDLE hFileHandle;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsOpen(%p, %hu)", pFilename, uiFlags));

#if defined(__WIN32__)

   {
      DWORD dwFlags =3D 0;
      DWORD dwShare =3D FILE_SHARE_READ | FILE_SHARE_WRITE;

      // read & write flags
      switch ( uiFlags )
      {
         case FO_READ:
            dwFlags =3D GENERIC_READ;
            break;
         case FO_WRITE:
            dwFlags =3D GENERIC_WRITE;
            break;
         case FO_READWRITE:
            dwFlags =3D GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE;
            break;
      }

      // shared flags
      if( ( uiFlags & FO_DENYREAD ) =3D=3D FO_DENYREAD )
         dwShare =3D FILE_SHARE_WRITE;

      else if( uiFlags & FO_DENYWRITE )
         dwShare =3D FILE_SHARE_READ;

      else if( uiFlags & FO_EXCLUSIVE )
         dwShare =3D 0;

      errno =3D 0;

      hFileHandle =3D ( FHANDLE ) CreateFile( ( char * ) pFilename, =
dwFlags,
                dwShare, NULL, OPEN_EXISTING, FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL, =
NULL );

      if( hFileHandle =3D=3D ( FHANDLE ) INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE )
         errno =3D GetLastError();

      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) && ! defined(__IBMCPP__)

   errno =3D 0;
   hFileHandle =3D open( ( char * ) pFilename, convert_open_flags( =
uiFlags ) );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#elif defined(_MSC_VER)

   {
      int iShare =3D _SH_DENYNO;

      if( ( uiFlags & FO_DENYREAD ) =3D=3D FO_DENYREAD )
         iShare =3D _SH_DENYRD;

      else if( uiFlags & FO_EXCLUSIVE )
         iShare =3D _SH_DENYRW;

      else if( uiFlags & FO_DENYWRITE )
         iShare =3D _SH_DENYWR;

      errno =3D 0;
      if( iShare )
         hFileHandle =3D _sopen( ( char * ) pFilename, =
convert_open_flags( uiFlags ), iShare );
      else
         hFileHandle =3D _open( ( char * ) pFilename, =
convert_open_flags( uiFlags ) );
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(__MINGW32__) || defined(__IBMCPP__)

   {
      int iShare =3D SH_DENYNO;

      if( ( uiFlags & FO_DENYREAD ) =3D=3D FO_DENYREAD )
         iShare =3D SH_DENYRD;

      else if( uiFlags & FO_EXCLUSIVE )
         iShare =3D SH_DENYRW;

      else if( uiFlags & FO_DENYWRITE )
         iShare =3D SH_DENYWR;

      errno =3D 0;
      if( iShare )
         hFileHandle =3D sopen( ( char * ) pFilename, =
convert_open_flags( uiFlags ), iShare );
      else
         hFileHandle =3D open( ( char * ) pFilename, convert_open_flags( =
uiFlags ) );
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#else

   hFileHandle =3D FS_ERROR;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return hFileHandle;
}

FHANDLE hb_fsCreate( BYTE * pFilename, USHORT uiFlags )
{
   FHANDLE hFileHandle;
   int oflag;
   unsigned pmode;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsCreate(%p, %hu)", pFilename, uiFlags));

   s_uiErrorLast =3D 0;

#if defined(__WIN32__)

   {
      DWORD dwFlags =3D FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE;

      if( uiFlags & FC_READONLY )
         dwFlags |=3D FILE_ATTRIBUTE_READONLY;

      if( uiFlags & FC_HIDDEN )
         dwFlags |=3D FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN;

      if( uiFlags & FC_SYSTEM )
         dwFlags |=3D FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SYSTEM;

      errno =3D 0;

      hFileHandle =3D ( FHANDLE ) CreateFile( ( char * ) pFilename,
                    GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE, 0, NULL, =
CREATE_ALWAYS,
                    dwFlags, NULL );

      if( hFileHandle =3D=3D ( FHANDLE ) INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE )
         errno =3D GetLastError();

      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;
   convert_create_flags( uiFlags, &oflag, &pmode );
   hFileHandle =3D open( ( char * ) pFilename, oflag, pmode );
   if( hFileHandle =3D=3D -1 )
   {
      /* This if block is required, because errno will be set
         if the file did not exist and had to be created, even
         when the create is successful! */
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#else

   hFileHandle =3D FS_ERROR;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return hFileHandle;
}

void    hb_fsClose( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsClose(%p)", hFileHandle));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;

   #if defined(__WIN32__)
      if ( !CloseHandle( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle ) )
         errno =3D GetLastError();
   #else
      close( hFileHandle );
   #endif

   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   /* Convert 'Invalid Memory Block' to 'Invalid Handle' */
   if( s_uiErrorLast =3D=3D 9 )
      s_uiErrorLast =3D 6;
}

void    hb_fsSetDevMode( FHANDLE hFileHandle, USHORT uiDevMode )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsSetDevMode(%p, %hu)", hFileHandle, =
uiDevMode));

#if defined(__BORLANDC__) || defined(__IBMCPP__) || defined(__DJGPP__) =
|| defined(__CYGWIN__) || defined(__WATCOMC__)

   errno =3D 0;
   switch( uiDevMode )
   {
      case FD_BINARY:
         setmode( hFileHandle, O_BINARY );
         break;

      case FD_TEXT:
         setmode( hFileHandle, O_TEXT );
         break;
   }
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#elif defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MINGW32__)

   errno =3D 0;
   switch( uiDevMode )
   {
      case FD_BINARY:
         _setmode( hFileHandle, _O_BINARY );
         break;

      case FD_TEXT:
         _setmode( hFileHandle, _O_TEXT );
         break;
   }
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

}

void    hb_fsSetDevRaw( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
   hb_fsSetDevMode( hFileHandle, FD_BINARY );
}

void    hb_fsSetDevText( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
   hb_fsSetDevMode( hFileHandle, FD_TEXT );
}

USHORT  hb_fsRead( FHANDLE hFileHandle, BYTE * pBuff, USHORT uiCount )
{
   USHORT uiRead;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsRead(%p, %p, %hu)", hFileHandle, pBuff, =
uiCount));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;

   #if defined(__WIN32__)
      {
         DWORD dwRead =3D 0;

         if ( !ReadFile( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, pBuff, uiCount, =
&dwRead, NULL ) )
            errno =3D GetLastError();
         uiRead =3D ( USHORT ) dwRead;
      }
   #else
      uiRead =3D read( hFileHandle, pBuff, uiCount );
   #endif

   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   if( uiRead =3D=3D ( USHORT ) -1 )
      uiRead =3D 0;

#else

   uiRead =3D 0;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return uiRead;
}

USHORT  hb_fsWrite( FHANDLE hFileHandle, BYTE * pBuff, USHORT uiCount )
{
   USHORT uiWritten;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsWrite(%p, %p, %hu)", hFileHandle, pBuff, =
uiCount));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;

   #if defined(__WIN32__)
      {
         DWORD dwWritten =3D 0;

         if (! WriteFile( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, pBuff, uiCount, =
&dwWritten, NULL ) )
            errno =3D GetLastError();
         uiWritten =3D ( USHORT ) dwWritten;
      }
   #else

      if( uiCount )
      {
         uiWritten =3D write( hFileHandle, pBuff, uiCount );
         if( uiWritten =3D=3D ( USHORT ) -1 )
            uiWritten =3D 0;
      }
      else
      {
         uiWritten =3D 0;
         ftruncate( hFileHandle, lseek( hFileHandle, 0L, SEEK_CUR ) );
      }
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

   #endif

#else

   uiWritten =3D 0;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return uiWritten;
}

ULONG   hb_fsReadLarge( FHANDLE hFileHandle, BYTE * pBuff, ULONG ulCount =
)
{
   ULONG ulRead;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsReadLarge(%p, %p, %lu)", hFileHandle, =
pBuff, ulCount));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;

   #if defined(__WIN32__)
      if ( !ReadFile( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, pBuff, ulCount, &ulRead, =
NULL ) )
        errno =3D GetLastError();
   #elif defined(HB_FS_LARGE_OPTIMIZED)
      ulRead =3D read( hFileHandle, pBuff, ulCount );
   #else
      {
         ULONG ulLeftToRead =3D ulCount;
         USHORT uiToRead;
         USHORT uiRead;
         BYTE * pPtr =3D pBuff;

         ulRead =3D 0;

         while( ulLeftToRead )
         {
            /* Determine how much to read this time */
            if( ulLeftToRead > ( ULONG ) INT_MAX )
            {
               uiToRead =3D INT_MAX;
               ulLeftToRead -=3D ( ULONG ) uiToRead;
            }
            else
            {
               uiToRead =3D ( USHORT ) ulLeftToRead;
               ulLeftToRead =3D 0L;
            }
            uiRead =3D read( hFileHandle, pPtr, uiToRead );
            /* -1 on bad hFileHandle
                0 on disk full
             */
            if( uiRead =3D=3D ( USHORT ) -1 || uiRead =3D=3D 0 )
               break;

            ulRead +=3D ( ULONG ) uiRead;
            pPtr +=3D uiRead;
         }
      }
   #endif
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   ulRead =3D 0;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return ulRead;
}

ULONG   hb_fsWriteLarge( FHANDLE hFileHandle, BYTE * pBuff, ULONG =
ulCount )
{
   ULONG ulWritten;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsWriteLarge(%p, %p, %lu)", hFileHandle, =
pBuff, ulCount));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;

   #if defined(__WIN32__)
      if ( !WriteFile( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, pBuff, ulCount, =
&ulWritten, NULL ) )
        errno =3D GetLastError();
   #else
      if( ulCount )
      #if defined(HB_FS_LARGE_OPTIMIZED)
         ulWritten =3D write( hFileHandle, pBuff, ulCount );
      #else
         {
            ULONG ulLeftToWrite =3D ulCount;
            USHORT uiToWrite;
            USHORT uiWritten;
            BYTE * pPtr =3D pBuff;

            ulWritten =3D 0;

            while( ulLeftToWrite )
            {
               /* Determine how much to write this time */
               if( ulLeftToWrite > ( ULONG ) INT_MAX )
               {
                  uiToWrite =3D INT_MAX;
                  ulLeftToWrite -=3D ( ULONG ) uiToWrite;
               }
               else
               {
                  uiToWrite =3D ( USHORT ) ulLeftToWrite;
                  ulLeftToWrite =3D 0L;
               }
               uiWritten =3D write( hFileHandle, pPtr, uiToWrite );
               /* -1 on bad hFileHandle
                   0 on disk full
                */
               if( uiWritten =3D=3D ( USHORT ) -1 || uiWritten =3D=3D 0 =
)
                  break;

               ulWritten +=3D ( ULONG ) uiWritten;
               pPtr +=3D uiWritten;
            }
         }
      #endif
      else
      {
         ulWritten =3D 0;
         ftruncate( hFileHandle, lseek( hFileHandle, 0L, SEEK_CUR ) );
      }
   #endif

   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   ulWritten =3D 0;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return ulWritten;
}

ULONG   hb_fsSeek( FHANDLE hFileHandle, LONG lOffset, USHORT uiFlags )
{
   ULONG ulPos;
   USHORT Flags;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsSeek(%p, %ld, %hu)", hFileHandle, =
lOffset, uiFlags));

   Flags =3D convert_seek_flags( uiFlags );

   if( lOffset < 0 && Flags =3D=3D SEEK_SET )
   {

   #if defined(HB_OS_OS2)

      {
         APIRET ret =3D DosSetFilePtr( hFileHandle, 0, SEEK_CUR, &ulPos =
);

         if( ret !=3D 0 )
         {
            ulPos =3D 0;
            s_uiErrorLast =3D ( USHORT ) ret;
         }
      }

   #elif defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

      /* get current offset */
      errno =3D 0;
      #if defined(__WIN32__)
         ulPos =3D SetFilePointer( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, 0, NULL, =
FILE_CURRENT );
         if ( ulPos =3D=3D 0xFFFFFFFF)
            errno =3D GetLastError();
      #else
         ulPos =3D lseek( hFileHandle, 0, SEEK_CUR );
      #endif
      if( errno !=3D 0 )
      {
         ulPos =3D 0;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
      }
      else
         s_uiErrorLast =3D 25; /* 'Seek Error' */

   #else

      ulPos =3D 0;
      s_uiErrorLast =3D 25; /* 'Seek Error' */

   #endif

   }
   else
   {

   #if defined(HB_OS_OS2)

      {
         APIRET ret =3D DosSetFilePtr( hFileHandle, lOffset, Flags, =
&ulPos );

         if( ret !=3D 0 )
         {
            ulPos =3D 0;
            s_uiErrorLast =3D ( USHORT ) ret;
         }
      }

   #elif defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

      errno =3D 0;
      #if defined(__WIN32__)
         ulPos =3D SetFilePointer( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, lOffset, =
NULL, Flags );
         if ( ulPos =3D=3D 0xFFFFFFFF)
            errno =3D GetLastError();
      #else
         ulPos =3D lseek( hFileHandle, lOffset, Flags );
      #endif
      if( errno !=3D 0 )
         ulPos =3D 0;
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

   #else

      ulPos =3D 0;
      s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

   #endif

      /* Convert 'Unknown Command' to 'Seek Error' */
      if( s_uiErrorLast =3D=3D 22 )
         s_uiErrorLast =3D 25;
   }

   return ulPos;
}

ULONG   hb_fsTell( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
   ULONG ulPos;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsTell(%p)", hFileHandle));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;
   #if defined(__WIN32__)
      ulPos =3D SetFilePointer( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, 0, NULL, =
FILE_CURRENT );
      if ( ulPos =3D=3D 0xFFFFFFFF)
        errno =3D GetLastError();
   #else
      ulPos =3D lseek( hFileHandle, 0L, SEEK_CUR );
   #endif
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   ulPos =3D 0;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return ulPos;
}

USHORT  hb_fsError( void )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsError()"));

   return s_uiErrorLast;
}

void    hb_fsSetError( USHORT uiError )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsSetError(%hu)", uiError));

   s_uiErrorLast =3D uiError;
}

int     hb_fsDelete( BYTE * pFilename )
{
   int iResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsDelete(%s)", (char*) pFilename));

#if defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO)

   errno =3D 0;
   iResult =3D unlink( ( char * ) pFilename );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#elif defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MINGW32__)

   errno =3D 0;
   iResult =3D remove( ( char * ) pFilename );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   iResult =3D -1;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return iResult;
}

int hb_fsRename( BYTE * pOldName, BYTE * pNewName )
{
   int iResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsRename(%s, %s)", (char*) pOldName, =
(char*) pNewName));

#if defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO)

   errno =3D 0;
   iResult =3D rename( ( char * ) pOldName, ( char * ) pNewName );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   iResult =3D -1;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return iResult;
}

BOOL    hb_fsLock   ( FHANDLE hFileHandle, ULONG ulStart,
                      ULONG ulLength, USHORT uiMode )
{
   int iResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsLock(%p, %lu, %lu, %hu)", hFileHandle, =
ulStart, ulLength, uiMode));

#if defined(__WIN32__)
   errno =3D 0;
   switch( uiMode )
   {
      case FL_LOCK:
         iResult =3D LockFile( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, ulStart, ( =
((long) ulStart) < 0 ? -1 : 0), ulLength, 0 );
         break;

      case FL_UNLOCK:
         iResult =3D UnlockFile( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, ulStart, ( =
((long) ulStart) < 0 ? -1 : 0), ulLength, 0 );
         break;

      default:
         iResult =3D 0;
   }
   if ( ! iResult )
      errno =3D GetLastError();
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
#elif defined(HB_OS_OS2)

   {
      struct _FILELOCK fl, ful;

      errno =3D 0;

      switch( uiMode )
      {
      case FL_LOCK:

         fl.lOffset =3D ulStart;
         fl.lRange =3D ulLength;
         ful.lOffset =3D 0;
         ful.lRange =3D 0;

         /* lock region, 2 seconds timeout, exclusive access - no atomic =
*/
         iResult =3D ( int ) DosSetFileLocks( hFileHandle, &ful, &fl, =
2000L, 0L );
         break;

      case FL_UNLOCK:

         fl.lOffset =3D 0;
         fl.lRange =3D 0;
         ful.lOffset =3D ulStart;
         ful.lRange =3D ulLength;

         /* unlock region, 2 seconds timeout, exclusive access - no =
atomic */
         iResult =3D ( int ) DosSetFileLocks( hFileHandle, &ful, &fl, =
2000L, 0L );
         break;

      default:
         iResult =3D 0;
      }

      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(_MSC_VER)

   {
      ULONG ulOldPos =3D hb_fsSeek( hFileHandle, ulStart, FS_SET );

      errno =3D 0;
      switch( uiMode )
      {
         case FL_LOCK:
            iResult =3D locking( hFileHandle, _LK_LOCK, ulLength );
            break;

         case FL_UNLOCK:
            iResult =3D locking( hFileHandle, _LK_UNLCK, ulLength );
            break;

         default:
            iResult =3D 0;
      }
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

      hb_fsSeek( hFileHandle, ulOldPos, FS_SET );
   }

#elif defined(__MINGW32__)

   {
      ULONG ulOldPos =3D hb_fsSeek( hFileHandle, ulStart, FS_SET );

      errno =3D 0;
      switch( uiMode )
      {
         case FL_LOCK:
            iResult =3D _locking( hFileHandle, _LK_LOCK, ulLength );
            break;

         case FL_UNLOCK:
            iResult =3D _locking( hFileHandle, _LK_UNLOCK, ulLength );
            break;

         default:
            iResult =3D 0;
      }
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

      hb_fsSeek( hFileHandle, ulOldPos, FS_SET );
   }

#elif defined(__GNUC__) && defined(HB_OS_UNIX)

   {
      /* TODO: check for append locks (SEEK_END)
       */
      struct flock lock_info;

      errno =3D 0;

      switch( uiMode )
      {
         case FL_LOCK:
            {
               lock_info.l_type   =3D F_WRLCK;
               lock_info.l_start  =3D ulStart;
               lock_info.l_len    =3D ulLength;
               lock_info.l_whence =3D SEEK_SET;   /* start from the =
beginning of the file */
               lock_info.l_pid    =3D getpid();

               iResult =3D fcntl( hFileHandle, F_SETLK, &lock_info );

               if( iResult < 0 )
                  iResult =3D 1;         /* lock failed */
               else
                  iResult =3D 0;         /* lock was successful */
            }
            break;

         case FL_UNLOCK:
            {
               lock_info.l_type   =3D F_UNLCK;   /* unlock */
               lock_info.l_start  =3D ulStart;
               lock_info.l_len    =3D ulLength;
               lock_info.l_whence =3D SEEK_SET;
               lock_info.l_pid    =3D getpid();

               iResult =3D fcntl( hFileHandle, F_SETLK, &lock_info );

               if( iResult < 0 )
                  iResult =3D 0;      /* lock failed */
            }
            break;

         default:
            iResult =3D 0;
      }

      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) && !defined(__IBMCPP__) && ( =
!defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__DJGPP__) )

   errno =3D 0;
   switch( uiMode )
   {
      case FL_LOCK:
         iResult =3D lock( hFileHandle, ulStart, ulLength );
         break;

      case FL_UNLOCK:
         iResult =3D unlock( hFileHandle, ulStart, ulLength );
         break;

      default:
         iResult =3D 0;
   }
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   iResult =3D 1;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return iResult =3D=3D 0;
}

void    hb_fsCommit( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsCommit(%p)", hFileHandle));

#if defined(__WIN32__)

   errno =3D 0;
   if ( !FlushFileBuffers( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle ) )
      errno =3D GetLastError();
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#elif defined(__WATCOMC__)

   _dos_commit( hFileHandle );

#elif defined(HB_FS_FILE_IO) && !defined(HB_OS_OS2) && =
!defined(HB_OS_UNIX)

   {
      int dup_handle;

      errno =3D 0;

      dup_handle =3D dup( hFileHandle );
      if( dup_handle !=3D -1 )
         close( dup_handle );

      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(HB_OS_OS2)

   {
      errno =3D 0;

      /* TODO: what about error code from DosResetBuffer() call? */
      DosResetBuffer( hFileHandle );

      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined(HB_OS_UNIX)

   /* NOTE: close() functions releases all lock regardles if it is an
    * original or duplicated file handle
   */
   #if defined(_POSIX_SYNCHRONIZED_IO)
      /* faster - flushes data buffers only, without updating directory =
info
      */
      s_uiErrorLast =3D ( fdatasync( hFileHandle ) < -1 ) ? FS_ERROR : =
0;
   #else
      /* slower - flushes all file data buffers and i-node info
      */
      s_uiErrorLast =3D ( fsync( hFileHandle ) < -1 ) ? FS_ERROR : 0;
   #endif

#else

   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif
}

BOOL    hb_fsMkDir( BYTE * pDirname )
{
   int iResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsMkDir(%s)", (char*) pDirname));

#if defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) || defined(__MINGW32__)

   errno =3D 0;

   #if !defined(__WATCOMC__) && !defined(__BORLANDC__) && =
!defined(__IBMCPP__) && !defined(__MINGW32__)
      iResult =3D mkdir( ( char * ) pDirname, S_IWUSR | S_IRUSR );
   #else
      iResult =3D mkdir( ( char * ) pDirname );
   #endif

   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   iResult =3D 1;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return iResult =3D=3D 0;
}

BOOL    hb_fsChDir( BYTE * pDirname )
{
   int iResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsChDir(%s)", (char*) pDirname));

#if defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) || defined(__MINGW32__)

   errno =3D 0;
   iResult =3D chdir( ( char * ) pDirname );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   iResult =3D 1;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return iResult =3D=3D 0;
}

BOOL    hb_fsRmDir( BYTE * pDirname )
{
   int iResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsRmDir(%s)", (char*) pDirname));

#if defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO) || defined(__MINGW32__)

   errno =3D 0;
   iResult =3D rmdir( ( char * ) pDirname );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   iResult =3D 1;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return iResult =3D=3D 0;
}

/* NOTE: This is not thread safe function, it's there for compatibility. =
*/
/* NOTE: 0 =3D current drive, 1 =3D A, 2 =3D B, 3 =3D C, etc. */

BYTE *  hb_fsCurDir( USHORT uiDrive )
{
   static BYTE s_byDirBuffer[ _POSIX_PATH_MAX + 1 ];

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsCurDir(%hu)", uiDrive));

   hb_fsCurDirBuff( uiDrive, s_byDirBuffer, _POSIX_PATH_MAX + 1 );

   return ( BYTE * ) s_byDirBuffer;
}

/* NOTE: Thread safe version of hb_fsCurDir() */
/* NOTE: 0 =3D current drive, 1 =3D A, 2 =3D B, 3 =3D C, etc. */

USHORT  hb_fsCurDirBuff( USHORT uiDrive, BYTE * pbyBuffer, ULONG ulLen )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsCurDirBuff(%hu)", uiDrive));

   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( uiDrive );

   pbyBuffer[ 0 ] =3D '\0';

#if defined(HAVE_POSIX_IO)

   errno =3D 0;
   getcwd( ( char * ) pbyBuffer, ulLen );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#elif defined(__MINGW32__)

   errno =3D 0;
   _getdcwd( uiDrive, pbyBuffer, ulLen );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   /* Strip the leading drive spec, and leading backslash if there's =
one. */

   {
      BYTE * pbyStart =3D pbyBuffer;

      /* NOTE: A trailing underscore is not returned on this platform,
               so we don't need to strip it. [vszakats] */

      if( pbyStart[ 1 ] =3D=3D ':' )
         pbyStart +=3D 2;
      if( strchr( OS_PATH_DELIMITER_LIST, pbyStart[ 0 ] ) )
         pbyStart++;

      if( pbyBuffer !=3D pbyStart )
         memmove( pbyBuffer, pbyStart, ulLen );
   }

   /* Strip the trailing (back)slash if there's one */

   {
      ULONG ulLen =3D strlen( ( char * ) pbyBuffer );

      if( strchr( OS_PATH_DELIMITER_LIST, pbyBuffer[ ulLen - 1 ] ) )
         pbyBuffer[ ulLen - 1 ] =3D '\0';
   }

   return s_uiErrorLast;
}

/* NOTE: 0=3DA:, 1=3DB:, 2=3DC:, 3=3DD:, ... */

USHORT  hb_fsChDrv( BYTE nDrive )
{
   USHORT uiResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsChDrv(%d)", (int) nDrive));

#if defined(HB_FS_DRIVE_LETTER)

 #if defined( __WATCOMC__ )

   {
      /* 'unsigned int' _have to_ be used in Watcom
       */
      unsigned int uiSave;
      unsigned int uiTotal;

      /* 1 =3D A:, 2 =3D B:, 3 =3D C:, etc
       * _dos_*() functions don't set 'errno'
       */
      _dos_getdrive( &uiSave );

      _dos_setdrive( nDrive + 1, &uiTotal );
      _dos_getdrive( &uiTotal );
      if( ( nDrive + 1 ) =3D=3D uiTotal )
      {
         uiResult =3D 0;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D 0;
      }
      else
      {
         _dos_setdrive( uiSave, &uiTotal );
         uiResult =3D FS_ERROR;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;
      }
   }
 #else
   {
      USHORT uiSave =3D _getdrive();

      errno =3D 0;
      _chdrive( nDrive + 1 );
      if( ( nDrive + 1 ) =3D=3D _getdrive() )
      {
         uiResult =3D 0;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
      }
      else
      {
         _chdrive( uiSave );
         uiResult =3D FS_ERROR;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;
      }
   }
 #endif
#else

   uiResult =3D FS_ERROR;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return uiResult;
}

/* NOTE: 0=3DA:, 1=3DB:, 2=3DC:, 3=3DD:, ... */

/* TOFIX: This isn't fully compliant because CA-Cl*pper doesn't access
          the drive before checking. hb_fsIsDrv only returns TRUE
          if there is a disk in the drive. */

USHORT  hb_fsIsDrv( BYTE nDrive )
{
   USHORT uiResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsIsDrv(%d)", (int) nDrive));

#if defined(HB_FS_DRIVE_LETTER)

 #if defined( __WATCOMC__ )

   {
      /* 'unsigned int' _have to_ be used in Watcom
       */
      unsigned int uiSave;
      unsigned int uiTotal;

      /* 1=3D  A:, 2 =3D B:, 3 =3D C:, etc
       * _dos_*() functions don't set 'errno'
       */
      _dos_getdrive( &uiSave );

      s_uiErrorLast =3D 0;
      uiResult =3D 0;
      _dos_setdrive( nDrive + 1, &uiTotal );
      _dos_getdrive( &uiTotal );
      if( ( nDrive + 1 ) !=3D uiTotal )
      {
         s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;
         uiResult =3D FS_ERROR;
      }
      _dos_setdrive( uiSave, &uiTotal );
   }
 #else
   {
      USHORT uiSave =3D _getdrive();

      errno =3D 0;
      _chdrive( nDrive + 1 );
      if( ( nDrive + 1 ) =3D=3D _getdrive() )
      {
         uiResult =3D 0;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
      }
      else
      {
         uiResult =3D FS_ERROR;
         s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;
      }

      _chdrive( uiSave );
   }
 #endif

#else

   uiResult =3D FS_ERROR;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return uiResult;
}

BOOL    hb_fsIsDevice( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
   BOOL bResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsIsDevice(%p)", hFileHandle));

#if defined(HB_FS_DRIVE_LETTER)

   errno =3D 0;
   bResult =3D ( isatty( hFileHandle ) =3D=3D 0 );
   s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;

#else

   bResult =3D FALSE;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;
   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( hFileHandle );

#endif

   return bResult;
}

/* NOTE: 0=3DA:, 1=3DB:, 2=3DC:, 3=3DD:, ... */

BYTE    hb_fsCurDrv( void )
{
   USHORT uiResult;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsCurDrv()"));

#if defined(HB_FS_DRIVE_LETTER)

   {
      errno =3D 0;
      uiResult =3D _getdrive();
      #if defined(__DJGPP__)
         /* _getdrive() returned a drive number, base 0. */
      #else
      if( uiResult < 65 )
      {
         /* _getdrive() returned a drive number, base 1. */
         uiResult--;
      }
      else
      {
         /* _getdrive() returned a drive letter. */
         uiResult -=3D 65;
      }
      #endif
      s_uiErrorLast =3D errno;
   }

#elif defined( __WATCOMC__ )

   {
      /* 'unsigned int' _have to_ be used in Watcom
       */
      unsigned uiDrive;

      /* 1 =3D A:, 2 =3D B:, 3 =3D C:, etc
       * _dos_*() functions don't set 'errno'
       */
      _dos_getdrive( &uiDrive );
      s_uiErrorLast =3D 0;
      uiResult =3D ( USHORT ) uiDrive -1;
   }

#else

   uiResult =3D 0;
   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

#endif

   return ( BYTE ) uiResult; /* Return the drive number, base 0. */
}

/* TODO: Implement hb_fsExtOpen */

FHANDLE hb_fsExtOpen( BYTE * pFilename, BYTE * pDefExt,
                      USHORT uiFlags, BYTE * pPaths, PHB_ITEM pError )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsExtOpen(%s, %s, %hu, %p, %p)", (char*) =
pFilename, (char*) pDefExt, uiFlags, pPaths, pError));

   s_uiErrorLast =3D FS_ERROR;

   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( pFilename );
   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( pDefExt );
   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( uiFlags );
   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( pPaths );
   HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( pError );

   return s_uiErrorLast;
}

/* TOFIX: CA-Cl*pper will allow wildcards in the filename. This should =
be
          added to Harbour. [vszakats] */

BOOL hb_fsFile( BYTE * pFilename )
{
   BOOL bIsFile;

   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("hb_fsFile(%s)", (char*) pFilename));

/* TODO: Check if F_OK is defined in all compilers */
#if defined(OS_UNIX_COMPATIBLE)

   bIsFile =3D ( access( ( const char * ) pFilename, F_OK ) =3D=3D 0 );

#elif defined(__MPW__)
   {
      int hFileHandle;

      if( ( hFileHandle =3D open( pFilename, O_RDONLY ) ) >=3D 0 )
      {
         close( hFileHandle );
         bIsFile =3D TRUE;
      }
      else
         bIsFile =3D FALSE;
   }
#else

   bIsFile =3D ( access( ( const char * ) pFilename, 0 ) =3D=3D 0 );

#endif

   return bIsFile;
}

BOOL hb_fsEof( FHANDLE hFileHandle )
{
#if defined(__WIN32__)
   long curPos =3D SetFilePointer( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, 0, NULL, =
FILE_CURRENT );
   long endPos =3D SetFilePointer( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, 0, NULL, =
FILE_END );
   long newPos =3D SetFilePointer( ( HANDLE ) hFileHandle, curPos, NULL, =
FILE_BEGIN );
   if( newPos =3D=3D -1L )
   {
      errno =3D GetLastError();
      hb_fsSetError( errno );
   }
   else if( newPos !=3D curPos )
   {
      hb_fsSetError( FS_ERROR );
   }
   return curPos >=3D endPos;
#elif defined(__DJGPP__) || defined(__CYGWIN__) || =
defined(OS_UNIX_COMPATIBLE)
   long curPos =3D lseek( hFileHandle, 0L, SEEK_CUR );
   long endPos =3D lseek( hFileHandle, 0L, SEEK_END );
   long newPos =3D lseek( hFileHandle, curPos, SEEK_SET );
   if( newPos =3D=3D -1L )
   {
      hb_fsSetError( errno );
   }
   else if( newPos !=3D curPos )
   {
      hb_fsSetError( FS_ERROR );
   }
   return curPos >=3D endPos;
#else
   return eof( hFileHandle ) !=3D 0;
#endif
}

HB_FUNC( FEOF )
{
   hb_fsSetError( 0 );

   if( ISNUM( 1 ) )
   {
      hb_retl( hb_fsEof( hb_parni( 1 ) ) );
   }
   else
      hb_retl( FALSE );
}
*/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 22 13:39:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Tue May 22 12:39:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] What's new in Clipper ADS 6.0
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIIELNGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIKEMDGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Hi,

I saw this message on the Advantage Newsgroup:

Here's what we plan to be in the Clipper 6.0 RDD. This list may be a little
cryptic since it was for internal use so I hope it isn't too hard to read.

Bug fixes. Among these include:

  Skip is Incorrect in Parent WA when Relation is Set
  COUNT TO Returns Zero After User Opens an Empty Table and a Concurrent
  User Adds Records GPF in AOF code
  Skip -1, Skip +1, BOF and EOF behave improperly in a corner case
  Situation.
  Rollbacks from failed transactions will not rollback when using version
  5.5 in a corner case situation.
  RLock fails to retry automatically
  GPF Occurs When Trying to Open a File Through a Drive Letter Mapped to a
  Non-Shared Directory
  ADSDOSIP NetBIOS name conflicts when computer name is over 13 characters
  long.
  Fix for conditional index on "FOR !DELETED()" and/or "FOR DELETED()" then
  when an append in a transaction is rolled back it will add a key to the
  !DELETED() index and not add a key to the DELETED() index.
  Fixes bug in ADSDOSIP where files were not closed on the server after an
  app is not shut down cleanly.


Enhancements:

  Local drive-letter access for CA-Clipper, Clip-4-Win and FiveWin.
  160-bit encryption support
  Update Norton Guides.
  Support for AX_KeyGoto()
  Latest 16-bit comm DLLs for FiveWin/Clip-4-Win
  Update the version.
  Add the MAX_TIMEOUTS value in the ADS.INI. Every release we have had to do
  a Class 1 to allow the client to try longer to communicate to ADS for very
  slow networks. This should be configurable. To be consistent, it should be
  in the ADS.INI file. However, I don't think it would be easy to use the
  Windows directory for the location of this file. It will have to be in the
  application directory and we can use GetPrivateProfileNumber since it is a
  Windows API.
  Multicast support for NetWare IP discovery.
  Removing all references to "DOS" and "Clipper" in ADSDOSIP.EXE
  Have the latest comm DLLs ship with ADSDOSIP.EXE ( Include enhancement
  that allows IP address and port to be specified in ADS.INI file)
  The simplicity of having the Clipper client version match the server
  version
  Fix ADSDOSIP not working for 6.0 comm DLLs
  Ability to connect to Internet ADS (Internet ADS is AIS integrated into
  ADS)
  Support for connections without the need for a Semaphore Connection file
  will be available using ADSDOSIP.


Here is a list of ADS 6.0 features that are available to Clipper developers
regardless whether we provide a 6.0 client or not:

  ADS for Windows NT/2000 no longer requires a hardware key
  Add ability to configure whether Advantage Database Server for NetWare
  "user" names are the client computer name or the client's NetWare
connection
  name
  Add support for dynamic Advantage Optimized Filters (AOFs) when used with
  the Advantage Database Server.
  Applications will no longer need to constantly refresh filters in order to
  see updates made by other users.
  Optimize transaction processing file I/O to increase speed of
  transactions.
  Increase maximum number of Advantage Database Server worker threads to
  1024.
  Optimize AOF usage when very few (if any) records pass the filter
  condition.
  Improve Advantage Database Server error logging for bad filter
  expressions. If a filter expression cannot be parsed by the
  Advantage Database Server Expression Engine, that filter expression text
  will get logged in the Advantage Database Server error log file,
  ADS_ERR.DBF.
  Remove necessity for application developer to manually refresh an AOF
  after a transaction rollback. Any AOF updates will be   automatically
rolled
  back during a transaction rollback.

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

to CVS if everything works as expected.

 Antonio,

AL> This is the complete sample that GPFs.

  The reason of GPF isn't a memo field, but FOR condition in the index
  command. Conditional indexing isn't implemented yet.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 23 15:13:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Ignacio_Ortiz_de_Z=FA=F1iga?=)
Date: Wed May 23 14:13:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug on ADS Rdd
Message-ID: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEGENJCDAA.ignacio@ozs.com>

a FWH user has reported the following error with ADS RDD:

When he opens a file with the INDEX CLAUSE, the first tag of the index file
is selected but record pointer is on recno() 1 not at the beginning of the
file accord with the current tag.

function Main()

   rddRegister( "ADS", 2 )
   rddsetdefault( "ADS" )

   SET SERVER LOCAL
   SET FILETYPE TO CDX

   USE MSW NEW INDEX PATIENT
   Browse()
   quit

return nil

I someone needs the little database table I can send it also, but I think is
not necessary.

Regards,

Ignacio Ortiz de Zúñiga
Email: ignacio@ozs.com
Phone Email: ignaciosms@ozs.com
http://www.ozs.com

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 23 22:16:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed May 23 21:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug on ADS Rdd
In-Reply-To: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEGENJCDAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
References: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEGENJCDAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
Message-ID: <200105240111.f4O1BCc25476@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from Ignacio_Ortiz_de_Z=FA=F1iga <ignacio@ozs.com> on
Wed, 23 May 2001 20:13:17 +0200

>    USE MSW NEW INDEX PATIENT
>    Browse()

Isn't the problem simply that the user forgot to add a line with
DbGoTop() between the USE and Browse() lines? The Clipper documentation
doesn't indicate that one should expect the database to be at the top of
the index order when using USE ... INDEX ... and using OrdSetFocus()
certainly doesn't change the position, so why would USE ... INDEX ... do
it?
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 23 23:11:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Phil Barnett)
Date: Wed May 23 22:11:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Object DB released to GPL.
Message-ID: <3B0C355C.25039.FA5645B@localhost>

I was just contacted by Brian Marasca, author of ObjectDB, who 
wanted to know if I would like to distribute ObjectDB from The 
Oasis.

Of course, I told him yes.

I wonder if it has a place in Harbour?

He originally was going to release to public domain, but I asked 
him to go GPL instead. He really didn't want PD anyway and was 
happy to have an alternative that produced the result that GPL 
creates.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 00:06:07 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 23 23:06:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] RE: Im a Clipper 5.2 User
In-Reply-To: <20010524010035.11491.qmail@web5102.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEHNDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dear Friend,

Harbour is not just for Linux. It works perfectly on all Windows platforms,
including the DOS prompt of all Windows versions.

You can download a pre-build Harbour.exe from the Harbour web site. You
don't have to deal with any source code.

You'll need a C compiler, but you don't need any C knowledge. Just use the
ready batch file bld_b32.bat

You MUST download the BCC 5.5 compiler from Borland. It is FREE!!!

Please forward more questions to the Harbour User Lists, and/or the Harbour
Developer List.

You may find the answers to many questions in here:
http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html

Good Luck.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 01:55:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu May 24 00:55:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-23 21:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEHNDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEHODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-23 21:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * include/hbclass.ch
     ! Corrected few minor typos.

   * source/compiler/harbour.slx
   * source/macro/macro.slx
     - Commented few unused lines.

   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     % Rewrote NextToken() and NextExp().
     + Added NextIdentifier()
     ! Found that Clipper PP is not processing tokens read by NextToken()
and NextExp() so removed recursive support,
       and changed logic in ProcessLine() to linear process:
         #defines against all valid Identifiers - Expansion forces a rescan
from top.
         #[x]translates against all tokens - Expansion forces a rescan from
top of #defines.
         #[x]command against the first token - Expansion forces a rescan
from top of #defines.
     ! Corrected and refined many aspects of Interpreter mode.
     + Added ExecuteMethod() and support for OO syntax.
     + Added support for -I<includepaths...> command line switch.

   * contrib/dot/rp_run.ch
     + Added support for OO syntax.

   * contrib/dot/pp.txt
     * Updated documentation.

   /* PP Interpreter mode, is now capable of running code like this:
        //---------------------------//
        Function Main()
            LOCAL o := TTest():New()

            o:Increment()
            Alert( o:nVar )
        Return nil

        CLASS TTest
           VAR nVar
           METHOD New CONSTRUCTOR
           METHOD Increment()
        ENDCLASS

        METHOD New //CLASS TTest /* CLASS clause now optional */
           ::nVar := 0
        return Self

        METHOD Increment CLASS TTest // () No longer required
        Return (++::nVar)
        //---------------------------//
   */


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 02:11:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu May 24 01:11:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-23 21:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEHODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEHODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> 2001-05-23 21:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>

BTW, It seems we have many memory blocks allocated by Macro Compiler that
may not be released. Ryszard, Horacio, just run pp ppclass -r (where
ppclass.prg is the sample posted in my last ChangeLog), and view the
HB_TR_ERROR list...

FWIW, these were the last bug fixes I planned to implement for 0.37. I'll
defer the fixes I have for -W3 -W4 and the complete declaration of all
standard functions, and classes (forwarded by Luiz), till after 0.37.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 04:40:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu May 24 03:40:04 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Bug on ADS Rdd
In-Reply-To: <200105240111.f4O1BCc25476@smtp.parrett.net>
References: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEGENJCDAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
 <200105240111.f4O1BCc25476@smtp.parrett.net>
Message-ID: <149104400419.20010524004635@abacuslaw.com>

Ignacio and David:

Currently, at least, the INDEX clause preprocesses to dbSetIndex,
which is a compatibility func for ORDLISTADD()

     ORDLISTADD() is an order management function that adds the contents of
     an order bag, or a single order in an order bag, to the order list.
     This function lets you extend the order list without issuing a SET INDEX
     command that, first, clears all the active orders from the order list.

     Any orders already associated with the work area continue to be active.
     If the newly opened order bag contains the only order associated with
     the work area, it becomes the controlling order; otherwise, the
     controlling order remains unchanged.

     After the new orders are opened, the work area is positioned to the
     first logical record in the controlling order.

I've done the fix to match this--it's in the overall RDD layer, not RDDADS.
Will post soon.
 ---====---
 Brian Hays

DGH> ** Reply to message from Ignacio_Ortiz_de_Zúñiga <ignacio@ozs.com> on
DGH> Wed, 23 May 2001 20:13:17 +0200

>>    USE MSW NEW INDEX PATIENT
>>    Browse()

DGH> Isn't the problem simply that the user forgot to add a line with
DGH> DbGoTop() between the USE and Browse() lines? The Clipper documentation
DGH> doesn't indicate that one should expect the database to be at the top of
DGH> the index order when using USE ... INDEX ... and using OrdSetFocus()
DGH> certainly doesn't change the position, so why would USE ... INDEX ... do
DGH> it?
DGH> --
DGH> David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
DGH> Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 04:47:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu May 24 03:47:06 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug on ADS Rdd
In-Reply-To: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEGENJCDAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
References: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEGENJCDAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
Message-ID: <169104814034.20010524005329@abacuslaw.com>

Ignacio:

IOdZ> a FWH user has reported the following error with ADS RDD:
IOdZ> When he opens a file with the INDEX CLAUSE, the first tag of the index file
IOdZ> is selected but record pointer is on recno() 1 not at the beginning of the
IOdZ> file accord with the current tag.
...
IOdZ>    USE MSW NEW INDEX PATIENT

remember that ADS always opens structural indexes. In this case if
MSW.CDX exists, the current order will not be affected by adding more
orders because Patient.cdx would be the second bag opened.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

[Perhaps this is best discussed on the harbourtalk list?]

On Thu, May 24, 2001 at 10:37:30AM +0200, Patrick Mast wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > So, what sort of redesign of the harbour pages did you have in mind? Do we
> > all get a say?
>
> Offcourse!
> I want to make it clean and not too fancy.
> A proffesional clean design.
> 
> I will always maka a proposal if I have something ready.
> Any ideas are welcome! ;-)

It's not that I have "something ready", far from it. It's just that you said
that you were working on a redesign, which suggests there's already some
design under way.

I'd agree on the clean and not-fancy approach (plus totally valid HTML is
nice as well, see the buttons at the bottom of the pages on my own web
site).

As for idea, a couple of weeks back I was thinking about the possibility of
basing a new harbour web site around something like PHP-Nuke. That would
make for a useful and familiar layaway while, at the same time, allowing a
number of people to maintain the content (for example, for a couple of
months now I've been toying with the idea of writing a weekly summary of
what's been happening with harbour development so that those outside the
development list can get a feel that something *is* happening).

Perhaps those of us interested in helping update and/or maintain the web
site should get together on a non-develop list to throw a few ideas about?

> 
> > That doesn't really address the point. It's fine that it comes with source
> > but if it really has been placed under the GPL it can never be used to build
> > non-free applications. Was this the intention of the author?
> 
> What license would you prefer, Dave?

My preference has nothing to do with this, there's little chance that I'll
ever have a use for this software. The licence preference of the author of
the software in question is paramount here.

It's a simple question I'm asking: Is it really the intention of the author
of this software that nobody will ever be able to use this freed version in
non-free software?

--

FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 13:19:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu May 24 12:19:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Object DB released to GPL.
In-Reply-To: <3B0CE997.14005.41DAF1FB@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Thu, May 24, 2001 at 10:59:35AM -0400
References: <3B0CBC53.32258.11B499C1@localhost>; <20010524133248.O21127@hagbard.davep.org> <3B0CE997.14005.41DAF1FB@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010524161709.V21127@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, May 24, 2001 at 10:59:35AM -0400, midnight@the-oasis.net wrote:

> On 24 May 2001, at 13:32, Dave Pearson wrote:
> 
> > It's a simple question I'm asking: Is it really the intention of the
> > author of this software that nobody will ever be able to use this freed
> > version in non-free software?
> 
> I don't know. You'd have to ask him. I suspect he is open to any licensing
> style I suggest.

Can't say I know this bloke from Adam so I'm unlikely to be in a position to
ask or advise him on anything. I only ask about this because you said that
you persuaded him to use the GPL instead of going PD and I suspect that
using the GPL will have side-effects that you didn't intend (even more so
now that you say you don't know if he's really wants what the GPL intends).

For one thing, using the GPL will stop people who wish to use it in non-free
software (arguably the bulk of people who'd want to use a harbour port of
it, for example) from using the library. For another it could actually
promote a devaluation of the GPL in the eyes of the Xbase community: people
will either see the GPL as a pain or they'll simply ignore it and use the
library in non-free applications anyway (and the last thing I'm sure you, as
the head of harbour, a free software project, would want to do is promote
the idea of ignoring free software licences).

As the person who advised the software author in question to use the GPL you
might want to go back and double check with him that the requirements of the
GPL are really what he wanted. Advising people to use the GPL without
actually knowing if they want the ramifications of that licence can and will
cause many problems on many levels.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 14:57:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu May 24 13:57:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] New Web site
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIOENPGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
References: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIGENOGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com> <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIOENPGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <200105241751.f4OHpec01558@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Patrick Mast" <harbour@winfakt.com> on Thu,
24 May 2001 19:27:00 +0200

> Is it ok that I use FRAMES on the new web site?

Provided that they don't hide where one is on the site.

In other words, if my browser's address line always shows
"http://www.harbour-project.org/", even when I'm on the download page,
then frames are bad and should not be used, but if it shows
"http://www.harbour-project.org/download.html" (or whatever the actual
page is) when I'm on the download page, then frames are OK.

In fewer words, it must be possible to book mark any specific page on
the Harbour project web site.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 24 23:14:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Phil Barnett)
Date: Thu May 24 22:14:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Server Upgrade
Message-ID: <3B0D8772.11065.14CE0B15@localhost>

I am upgrading our server tonight. This will involve upgrading nearly 
everything that runs the automated portion of the web server. Potentially, it 
could disrupt mail, mailing lists, web sites, ftp sites or more.

Last night, like every Wednesday night, I created a total backup of the the 
potentially effected portion of the server. If the worst happens, this could 
mean a rollback to last night's version of everything.

I will send out a message when everything is done. If at that time, you find 
that something is amiss, please contact me immediately regarding the 
issue.

If you can't contact me by my normal email address, you can use my old 
email address, philb@iag.net.

Sorry for any inconveniences this may cause you. It will give us new 
capabilities.

We will get upgraded versions of:

Apache SSL (BenSSL)
SSI
PHP4
Perl and CGI
MySQL
Q-mail
proFTPD
DNS/BIND
Stunnel
FrontPage Server Extensions


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 25 02:10:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 25 01:10:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFNTX Bug (Alexander)
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIGENOGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEIHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Alexander,

Recent change must have broken DBFNTX badly!!!

Try this:

//-----------------------------//
Procedure Main

   USE Test

   INDEX ON First TO First

   ? RecNo(), FIELD->First

   REPLACE First WITH "John" // DBF/1020 Data type error !!!

   ? RecNo(), FIELD->First

   CLOSE

RETURN
//-----------------------------//

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 25 02:16:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 25 01:16:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFNTX Bug (Alexander)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEIHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEIHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

This is also true with DBFCDX. Which suggests the problem is with the RDD.

Just add:

   REQUEST DBFCDX
   RDDSetDefault( "DBFCDX" )

The error becomes: DBFCDX/1020 Data type error

> Alexander,
> 
> Recent change must have broken DBFNTX badly!!!
> 
> Try this:
> 
> //-----------------------------//
> Procedure Main
> 
>    USE Test
> 
>    INDEX ON First TO First
> 
>    ? RecNo(), FIELD->First
> 
>    REPLACE First WITH "John" // DBF/1020 Data type error !!!
> 
>    ? RecNo(), FIELD->First
> 
>    CLOSE
> 
> RETURN
> //-----------------------------//

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 25 05:27:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Fri May 25 04:27:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: DBFNTX Bug (Alexander)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEIHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEIHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <1512068338.20010525122025@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 25.05.2001 9:13, Ron Pinkas <Ron@Profit-Master.com> wrote:

RP> Alexander,
RP> Recent change must have broken DBFNTX badly!!!
RP> ...

 This is caused by incorrect operation in hvm.c :

         case HB_P_POPVARIABLE:
         {
            USHORT uiParams;

            /* Pops a value from the eval stack and uses it to set
             * a new value of a variable of unknown type.
             */
            uiParams = pCode[ w + 1 ] + ( pCode[ w + 2 ] * 256 );
            /* First try if passed symbol is a name of field
             * in a current workarea - if it is not a field (FAILURE)
             * then try the memvar variable (it will create PRIVATE
             * variable if this variable doesn't exist)
             */
            hb_stackDec();
            if( hb_rddFieldPut( ( hb_stackTopItem() ), pSymbols + uiParams ) == FAILURE )
               hb_memvarSetValue( pSymbols + uiParams, ( hb_stackTopItem() ) );
            hb_itemClear( ( hb_stackTopItem() ) );
            HB_TRACE(HB_TR_INFO, ("(hb_vmPopVariable)"));
            w += 3;
            break;
         }

  Any further stack operations in hb_rddFieldPut() and in functions,
  called from it, changes the first parameter's ( hb_stackTopItem() )
  value.
  As far as I remember, Ryszard confirmed it, but had not a chance to
  fix it yet.
  Before there was a trick in dbfntx's ntxPutValue(), which fixed this
  problem for dbfntx, but recently the function ntxPutValue() was
  removed.
  I don't sure, that I will have a time to fix it fast, because I
  leave my town today for a short vacation ( 1 week ).
  


Best regards,
 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 25 15:25:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 25 14:25:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: DBFNTX Bug (Alexander)
In-Reply-To: <1512068338.20010525122025@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEILDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Alexander,

>  This is caused by incorrect operation in hvm.c :
>
>          case HB_P_POPVARIABLE:
> ...

The sample test program, does NOT use HB_P_POPVARIABLE it uses
HB_P_POPFIELD.

Regardless, both call hb_rddFieldPut(), with the Field Name (pSymbols +
uiParams), and the item (hb_stackTopItem()) to PUT value of. So the problem
seems to be in hb_rddFieldPut().

I'll review and let you know, what I found...

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 25 16:21:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri May 25 15:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-25 12:20 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEILDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEIMDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-25 12:20 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     * Few corrections to NextToken() and CompileRule() to match Clipper
behavior regarding decimal point, and decimal numbers.

   * source/pp/ppcore.c
     - Removed unused variable as per compiler warning.

   * source/vm/hvm.c
     ! Fixed HB_P_POPFIELD and HB_P_POPVARIABLE to NOT pop top stack element
pre-maturely.
       Item is now pop only after assignment took place. This fixes problem
where the FieldPut routine had to use the stack,
       thus overriding the assigned item.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri May 25 16:35:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri May 25 15:35:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ADS relation gpf
Message-ID: <18554872602.20010525124120@abacuslaw.com>

I have received confirmation from a wonderfully responsive
Extended Systems regarding the problem I posted a few days ago.
It will be fixed in the 6.1 release.
The problem occurs when a table that WAS a child now wants to be the
parent. After clearing relations, an internal flag is not reset
correctly IF the new parent is at EOF when the new relations are set.

The workaround for now is to check for eof before setting relations, and
reposition on a valid record.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

>Hola Amigos,

>Espero que no sea una molestía pare ustedes recibir estos emails pero lo
que pasa es que estoy muy activo con FWH y Harbour

>BUG encontrado, genera un GPF !!!
>1) Cuando se declara el RDD de ADS en la función INIT FUNCTION no lo toma y
se queda al parecer con el RDD por defecto y después se cae en la
indexación. Osea, al parecer no se logra registrar el RDD en la función
INIT.

>#include "ads.ch"

>REQUEST _ADS

>FUNCTION MAIN

>  USE TEST EXCLUSIVE
>  INDEX ON FIRST TAG K1 TO TEST DESCENDING

>  ? "RESULTO :)"

>RETURN NIL

>INIT FUNCTION BUGDESC

>  rddRegister( "ADS", 1 )
>  rddsetdefault( "ADS" )

>  SET SERVER LOCAL
>  SET FILETYPE TO CDX


>Saludos
>Jorge Mason

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 26 03:08:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat May 26 02:08:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] HB_FEOF()
Message-ID: <2392860486.20010525231428@abacuslaw.com>

In libmisc there's a set of text file functions like NanForum's
fttext functions.  There's a function name collision with a
"extension" function in philes.c--HB_FEOF().

Since someone using the ft_f* functions only needs a global replace of
ft_ with hb_, should we keep hb_feof with the set, and change the one
in Philes.c (it's the only one with "hb_" in that file) ?
Should it become simply feof()?  Or HB_FIsEof() ?
  
 ---====---
 Brian Hays

I am proposing a creation of a new sub directory in CVS repository for
internet-related thingies like TCP/IP, XML, CGI etc.

My ideas are:

2) Create it under /rtl/

I myself prefer it to be under /rtl/ with consideration that Harbour is a 
reincarnation of Clipper, thus, has to have something new as far as RTL is
concerned. 

Remember that Clipper 5.3 has classes that 5.2 does not?

Just a thought.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat May 26 23:17:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat May 26 22:17:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] class gpf
Message-ID: <132165415094.20010526192343@abacuslaw.com>

JF:
I have a messagebar class that has an array of items with tooltips.
A certain syntax worked in 16bit FW code, but causes a gpf with
Harbour.
   In the msgBar:ShowTooltip() method...
   
        oItem := ::aItem[ ::nItem ]
This worked before, but blows now:
    Super:ShowToolTip( nTop , oItem:nLeft() )

If I save the value to a local nLeft and pass that to Super:, it
works:
    nLeft := oItem:nLeft()
    Super:ShowToolTip( nTop , nLeft )

The nTop was also originally a function call, but I had to store to a
local to pass that for it to work also.  It seems a method or function
call cannot be the parameter to this method?

 ---====---
 Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 01:16:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun May 27 00:16:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-26 21:10 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <132165415094.20010526192343@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEJCDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-26 21:10 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     ! Fixed support for '$' in NextToken() and NextExp()
     + Added nAtSkipStr() to exclude content of strings when searching for
';'
     ! Fixed Multi Line logic to use nAtSkipStr() instead of At()
     + Added infile C versions for NextToken() and NextIdentifier()
     + Added precompiled rules for FiveWin.ch (Harbour)
     + Added precompiled rules for RP_Run.ch.

   * source/compiler/genc.c
     + Added few #include files to generation of inline C.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 04:28:05 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Sun May 27 03:28:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] PP (To Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000501c0e67b$a7f52280$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIMEPLGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Antonio,

> good moorning! :-)
Good morning Sir! ;-)

> Does that means that you have an interactive dot
> prompt environment where you may create windows,
> dialogs and so on, on the run ?
No, but you can run this:
,---------------------
|Function Main()
|
|   local oWnd
|
|   DEFINE WINDOW oWnd FROM 3, 6 TO 20, 70 ;
|      TITLE "Welcome to " + FWDESCRIPTION COLOR "W/B"
|
|   @ 2, 2 SAY "Hello world!"
|
|   ACTIVATE WINDOW oWnd ;
|      ON RIGHT CLICK MsgInfo( "Right Click" ) ;
|      VALID MsgYesNo( "Are you sure?", "Do you want to exit?" )
|
|Return nil
`-----------------------------------

Without compiling. Just do "wfScript32.exe Tutor02.prg"


> Wow! I would love to see it :-)
I will upload it when it's more finished as now. ;-)

> (Well, you know that Ignacio's WDbu also does it
> using FiveScript, but he did not adapted it to 32
> bits yet...)

wonderful TScript class. But i triet to compile it with Harbour, but I could
not get it run... Now with Ron's PP engine I get some nice results!!

Hey, a Windows DOT interpereter, hmm, we can do that! ;-)

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0004_01C0E690.F7803EB0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Ron,

>      + Added precompiled rules for FiveWin.ch (Harbour)
>      + Added precompiled rules for RP_Run.ch.

This:
,--------
|#include "fivewin.ch"
|function TestMain()
|   local oWnd
|   DEFINE WINDOW oWnd FROM 3, 6 TO 20, 70 TITLE "test"
|   @ 2, 2 SAY "Hello world!"
|   ACTIVATE WINDOW oWnd
|return nil
`----------------
gives attached error.

If compile it with Harbour and let Harbour make a .PPO file and than run
that .PPO file with PP, PP runs it with no complains.
So it's in the preprocess that it gives the error.

Thanks!

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 07:22:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)

Subject: [Harbour] PP (To Ron)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEJFDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIGEPOGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Ron,

> Actually I think this should be possible, though I didn't try
> yet. I believe we just need to create the Windows Dot Prompt
> GUI, which I assume is what you did ???
No, no Dot. Just compile and run PRG files.


> Well just building pp with the FWH BuildH.bat produces PP.exe
> that runs FWH
> samples just fine. Patrick, I would prefer we don't rename it to
> wfScript32 though.
wfScript32 als has also other functions linked in.
OLE connections, FUNCky support, my own LIB's and functions, ...

I use wfScript (16bits) now for simple automated tasks.
wfScript32 is just the 32 bits enhanced version of wfScript.

wfScript 16 bits is based on Ignacio's FiveScript, while wfScript32 bits
will be based on your PP.prg.

wfScript also "Compiles" PRG files. "Compiling" translates the PRG file into
something the End-User can not change. It's for his own best! ;-))

> > > Wow! I would love to see it :-)
> > I will upload it when it's more finished as now. ;-)
> > > (Well, you know that Ignacio's WDbu also does it
> > > using FiveScript, but he did not adapted it to 32
> > > bits yet...)
> > Yes, but I think this is going to be further.
>
> FiveScript requires Clipper PP right?
Or Harbour's PP and only if you want to use #include statements.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 13:18:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Sun May 27 12:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] dbcmd.c ( probable type error )
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIOEPPGDAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
References: <000001c0e6a0$6b5bad60$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <200105271617.f4RGHV629565@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>

Hi,

Last CVS seem to include a bad type conversion in dbcmd.c at 
line 2444

source\rdd\dbcmd.c(2444) : error C2664: 'hb_itemGetNI' : cannot 
convert parameter 1 from 'struct _HB_ITEM ** ' to 'struct _HB_ITEM 
*'
        Types pointed to are unrelated; conversion requires 
reinterpret_cast, C-style cast or function-style cast

The line

      bFirst = ( pOrderInfo.itmResult->type & HB_IT_NUMERIC ) &&
                  hb_itemGetNI( &pOrderInfo.itmResult ) != 0;

should be

      bFirst = ( pOrderInfo.itmResult->type & HB_IT_NUMERIC ) &&
                  hb_itemGetNI( pOrderInfo.itmResult ) != 0;


Best regards,

J. Lefebvre,
Bruxelles,
Belgium


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 14:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Sun May 27 13:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ADS MemoBlock size?
In-Reply-To: <200105271617.f4RGHV629565@ev6.be.wanadoo.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIAEACGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Hi,

I want to create a database that uses Memofields.
When I set Set(_SET_MBLOCKSIZE,32) the FPT is 1.56Mb in size for 100 empty
records.

If I set Set(_SET_MBLOCKSIZE,33) the FPT is 3Kb in size for 100 empty
records.

I read in the source files that if the MemoBlockSize is se to less than 32
it is multiplied with 512.
This way we cannot set it to 16.

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

PS. Why do I read "SIxMemo" in the first bytes of the FPT file?


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 18:15:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun May 27 17:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-05-27 02:19 UTC-0800
Message-ID: <142233691350.20010527142139@abacuslaw.com>

2001-05-27 02:19 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

   * source/rdd/dbcmd.c
      * fixed ordListAdd pointer bug reported by JF

   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads.ch
      + added COMMIT command to call AdsWriteAllRecords
         (our dbCommitAll() loops through all workareas. AdsWriteAllRecords
         is an optimized single call to the server.)

   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads1.c
      * corrected commit to only flush current workarea
      * fixed DBOI_ORDERCOUNT parameter handling

   * contrib/rdd_ads/adsfunc.c
      + added AdsWriteAllRecords()  &  AdsGetNumIndexes()

   * contrib\rdd_ads\doc\en\readme.txt
      *  minor edits


 ---====---
 Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun May 27 18:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun May 27 17:26:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ADS MemoBlock size?
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIAEACGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
References: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIAEACGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <180234370727.20010527143259@abacuslaw.com>

Patrick:

This is correct behavior for FoxPro compatible files.
FPT files can have memo block sizes of 33 bytes or greater.
Good old FlexFile let us set block size to anything,
but some programs will fail to open a file with block
size set less than 33.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

PM> Hi,

PM> I want to create a database that uses Memofields.
PM> When I set Set(_SET_MBLOCKSIZE,32) the FPT is 1.56Mb in size for 100 empty
PM> records.

PM> If I set Set(_SET_MBLOCKSIZE,33) the FPT is 3Kb in size for 100 empty
PM> records.

PM> I read in the source files that if the MemoBlockSize is se to less than 32
PM> it is multiplied with 512.
PM> This way we cannot set it to 16.

PM> Regards,

PM> Patrick Mast
PM> www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

PM> PS. Why do I read "SIxMemo" in the first bytes of the FPT file?

PM> _______________________________________________
PM> Harbour mailing list
PM> Harbour@matrixlist.com
PM> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour

PM> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
PM> http://www.Harbour-Project.org
