From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 00:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun May 27 23:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FiveWin.ch errors (Antonio)
In-Reply-To: <003b01c0e6fd$9b12f880$53d4d7c8@luizguim>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEJHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Antonio,

When improving PP Error detection, it found the following 3 errors in
FiveWin.ch:

1. >>>Result #1 marked REPEATABLE but root #1 is not OPTIONAL!<<<

For:

REDEFINE ICON <oIcon> [ ID <nId> ]                                       ;
                      [ <resource: NAME, RESOURCE, RESNAME> <cResName> ] ;
                      [ <file: FILE, FILENAME, DISK> <cIcoFile> ]        ;
                      [ ON CLICK <uClick> ]                              ;
                      [ <of: OF, WINDOW, DIALOG> <oWnd> ]                ;
                      [ <update: UPDATE> ] [ WHEN <uWhen> ] =>           ;
           [ <oIcon> := ] TIcon():ReDefine( <nId>, <cResName>,           ;
           <cIcoFile>, <{uClick}>, <.update.>, <oWnd>, <{uWhen}> )

I believe you should be changed to:

   REDEFINE ICON [oIcon] ...

2. >>>Result #11 marked REPEATABLE but root #4 is not OPTIONAL!<<<

For:

@ <nRow>, <nCol> CHECKBOX [ <oCbx> VAR ] <lVar>                        ;
                 [ PROMPT <cCaption> ]                                 ;
                 [ <of:OF, WINDOW, DIALOG> <oWnd> ]                    ;
                 [ SIZE <nWidth>, <nHeight> ]                          ;
                 [ <help:HELPID, HELP ID> <nHelpId> ]                  ;
                 [ FONT <oFont> ]                                      ;
                 [ <change: ON CLICK, ON CHANGE> <uClick> ]            ;
                 [ VALID   <ValidFunc> ]                               ;
                 [ <color: COLOR, COLORS> <nClrFore> [,<nClrBack>] ]   ;
                 [ <design: DESIGN> ]                                  ;
                 [ <pixel: PIXEL> ]                                    ;
                 [ MESSAGE <cMsg> ]                                    ;
                 [ <update: UPDATE> ]                                  ;
                 [ WHEN <WhenFunc> ] =>                                ;
     [ <oCbx> := ] TCheckBox():New( <nRow>, <nCol>, <cCaption>,
;
                   [bSETGET(<lVar>)], <oWnd>, <nWidth>, <nHeight>,
<nHelpId>,    ;
                   [<{uClick}>], <oFont>, <{ValidFunc}>, <nClrFore>,
<nClrBack>, ;
                   <.design.>, <.pixel.>, <cMsg>, <.update.>, <{WhenFunc}> )

I believe it should be fixed to:

   @ <nRow>, <nCol> CHECKBOX <oCbx> [VAR <lVar>] ...


3. >>>Result #11 marked REPEATABLE but root #4 is not OPTIONAL!<<<

For:

@ <nRow>, <nCol> RADIO [ <oRadMenu> VAR ] <nVar>
                 [ <prm: PROMPT, ITEMS> <cItems,...> ]
                 [ <of: OF, WINDOW, DIALOG> <oWnd> ]
                 [ <help:HELPID, HELP ID> <nHelpId,...> ]
                 [ <change: ON CLICK, ON CHANGE> <uChange> ]
                 [ COLOR <nClrFore> [,<nClrBack>] ]
                 [ MESSAGE <cMsg> ]
                 [ <update: UPDATE> ]
                 [ WHEN <uWhen> ]
                 [ SIZE <nWidth>, <nHeight> ]
                 [ VALID <uValid> ]
                 [ <lDesign: DESIGN> ]
                 [ <lLook3d: 3D, _3D> ]
                 [ <lPixel: PIXEL> ] => ;
   <oRadMenu> := ] TRadMenu():New( <nRow>, <nCol>, {<cItems>}, ;
   [bSETGET(<nVar>)], <oWnd>, [{<nHelpId>}], <{uChange}>, ;
   <nClrFore>, <nClrBack>, <cMsg>, <.update.>, <{uWhen}>, ;
   <nWidth>, <nHeight>, <{uValid}>, <.lDesign.>, <.lLook3d.>, <.lPixel.> )

I believe it should be fixed to:

   @ <nRow>, <nCol> RADIO <oRadMenu> [VAR <nVar>]...

BTW PP auto corrects it, but I believe these should be fixed.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 01:36:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 28 00:36:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-27 21:20 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEJHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEJIDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-27 21:20 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     * Few minor corrections to NextExp()
     ! Fixed generation of compiled rules results to always have marker
place holders, even if no results exist.
     + Added TraceLog() message about repeatable results for non optional
markers.
     * Updated burned-in rules for FiveWin.ch with newly generated rules.
     + Added few #ifdef FW to better support compilation with
\fwh\samples\buildh.bat
     + Added #include "fwextern.ch" (#ifdef FW) to force link most FW
modules.

   /* PP, if built like this:

         BUILDH pp -dFW

      (note -dFW) will produce PP.exe which will run most \fwh\samples\*.prg

      Test like this:

         PP Tutor01 -R

      etc... :-)

   */

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 02:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Mon May 28 01:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ADS MemoBlock size?
In-Reply-To: <180234370727.20010527143259@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIKEAEGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Brian,

> This is correct behavior for FoxPro compatible files.
> FPT files can have memo block sizes of 33 bytes or greater.
> Good old FlexFile let us set block size to anything,
> but some programs will fail to open a file with block
> size set less than 33.
I'm used to work with the SIX driver and always set Memoblock to 16.
Is there a way to do this with ADS?

PS. Why do I read "SIxMemo" in the first bytes of the FPT file?

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 04:01:08 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Mon May 28 03:01:08 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] ADS MemoBlock size?
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIKEAEGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
References: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIKEAEGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <181268836196.20010528000724@abacuslaw.com>

Patrick:


PM> I'm used to work with the SIX driver and always set Memoblock to 16.
PM> Is there a way to do this with ADS?
Not according to their docs. You might try their newsgroups to see if
there's an undocumented trick for it.

PM> PS. Why do I read "SIxMemo" in the first bytes of the FPT file?
Many years ago the SIx folks and Extended Systems worked together, and
kept file level compatibility.  I guess they never had a reason to
change the headers.

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

I just noticed Luiz's contribs carry a set of ft_f* functions in PRG
code to parallel the NanForum C code.  Though it's not part of the
harbour tree, this will cause some confusion if we change the hb_f.c
funcs to ft* as was proposed the other day.

On a related note:
If no one complains, I will change the philes.c func HB_FEOF() to
HB_F_EOF() to avoid the collision with the set in libmisc\hb_f.c, and
leave the rest as is.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 04:34:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May 28 03:34:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FiveWin.ch errors (Antonio)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEJHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <000001c0e747$fe24e920$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron,

Many thanks for your suggestions.
Anyhow, 1 is ok, but 2 and 3 no.

> @ <nRow>, <nCol> CHECKBOX [ <oCbx> VAR ] <lVar>                        ;

A checkbox control usually just works directly on a logical variable:

   @ 2, 3 CHECKBOX lTest ...

but only if you want to access the control object, then you do:

   @ 2, 3 CHECKBOX oChk VAR lTest

Same goes for case 3.

Many thanks!

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 04:51:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 28 03:51:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FiveWin.ch errors (Antonio)
In-Reply-To: <000001c0e747$fe24e920$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEJMDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Antonio,

> > @ <nRow>, <nCol> CHECKBOX [ <oCbx> VAR ] <lVar>                        ;
>
> A checkbox control usually just works directly on a logical variable:
>
>    @ 2, 3 CHECKBOX lTest ...
>
> but only if you want to access the control object, then you do:
>
>    @ 2, 3 CHECKBOX oChk VAR lTest
>
> Same goes for case 3.

But then if lVar is NOT optional then shouldn't you remove the squares in
the result?

[bSETGET(<lVar>)] => bSETGET(<lVar>) // Because it can't be repeatable if
marker is NOT optional ???

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 05:00:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon May 28 04:00:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FiveWin.ch errors (Ron, Alexander)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEJMDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Ron, Alexander

> But then if lVar is NOT optional then shouldn't you remove the squares in
> the result?
> [bSETGET(<lVar>)] => bSETGET(<lVar>) 

You are right. Done! :-)  Many thanks!

Curiously enough, Clipper PP and Harbour PP never
complained about it... 

Could we add that kind of warnings to Harbour PP ?

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 05:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Mon May 28 04:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] dot (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <000401c0e74c$fc252f40$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIIEAJGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Antonio,


> I am playing a little with your dot contribution,
> and I wonder how could I use it from a FWH app.
> Is there a Class to use ?
Compile and link in the pp.prg.
But rename the Main() function to MainPP().

Than in your FW app:
MainPP("testdlg2.prg","-R")

Regards,

Patrick Mast

space conflicts.

> VO early versions (I don't know if latest ones also have it)

> then you could introduce a test and see the PP generated

> same purpouse ?

ProcessLine( "#command Test [OPT CLAUSE] <x> => MyTest( #<x>" ) // "Learn"
ne rule.
ProcessLine( "Test 7" ) // Process against all known rules => MyTest("7")

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 07:50:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 28 06:50:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-28 03:20 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <001701c0e761$ac758200$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEKADMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Antonio,

> Could you please explain a little what these
> parameters mean, and a little sample ?
>
> FUNCTION ProcessLine( sLine, nLine, sSource )

Please note it was just RENAMED PP_ProcessLine().

sLine is the line to process, can be a #directive new rule, or normal line
to match.

nLine and sSource are OPTIONAL parameters, used internally to record the
Line No, and Source file of the provided line.

Ron

Harbour!

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 18:51:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 28 17:51:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-28 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <200105282119.XAA16411@pyxis.wanadoo.be>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEKEDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-28 14:50 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     * Renamed PP_ProcessLine() to PP_PreProLine() and PP_ProcessFile() to
PP_PreProFile() to allow 10 chars uniqueness.
     * Changed STATIC ExecuteMethod() to PP_ExecMethod() and STATIC
ExecuteProcedure() to PP_ExecProcedure()
       to allow call from external modules, while preserving name space, and
10 chars uniqueness.
     * Removed STATIC from RP_*_Err() to allow calls from external modules.
     * Changed PP_CompileLine() to accept array of compiled procedures,
instead of using a static.
       This allows thread safety, and support calls from external modules.
     * Changed RP_Run_Err() to accept 2nd parameter the Compiled Procedures
Array, and 3rd parameter Module Name.
       This allows thread safety, and support calls from external modules.
     + Added PP_RunInit() to support initialization for Interpreter mode
from external modules.
     + Added #ifdef __HARBOUR_ #include "pp_harb.ch" to allow Clipper to
compile pp.prg.

   * contrib/dot/rp_run.ch
     * Changed ExecuteMethod() calls to PP_ExecMethod()

   + contrib/dot/pp_harb.ch
     + Added external file holding Harbour specific code that Clipper could
not compile.

   + contrib/dot/prgscrpt.prg
     + Added sample to demonstrate PP interpreter embedded in a small prg to
run prg driven scripts.


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 19:00:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 28 18:00:06 2001
Subject: [Harbour] dot (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIAEAOGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEKEDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Patrick,

> Is it possible to run a PRG from a variable instead of a Filename?
> Like:
>
> cRun:="Function Test{}"
> cRun+="MsgInfo('Hallo')"
> cRun+="RETURN NIL"
>
> PP_ProcessFile( cRun )

Yes, now you can, but not like above! Like this: (see
/contrib/dot/prgscrpt.prg)

//------------------------------------------------------------//
Procedure Main()

   LOCAL aCompiledProcs := {}, nProcId := 0, sPPed

   ErrorBlock( {|oErr| RP_Run_Err( oErr, aCompiledProcs ) } )

   PP_RunInit()

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Proc Test" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 1, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId ) // Line number
optional

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Alert( 'Hello from embedded PP' )" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 2, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId ) // Line number
optional

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "RETURN" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 3, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId ) // Line number
optional

   PP_ExecuteProcedure( aCompiledProcs[1] )

   // OR... :

   PP_RunInit()
   aCompiledProcs := {}; nProcId := 0

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Proc EmbeddedMain" )
   sPPed += ";" + PP_PreProLine( "Alert( EmbeddedTest() )" )
   sPPed += ";" + PP_PreProLine( "return " )
   sPPed += ";" + PP_PreProLine( "Proc EmbeddedTest" )
   sPPEd += ";" + PP_PreProLine( "return 'Hello Again'" )

   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 0, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId ) // Line number
optional
   PP_ExecuteProcedure( aCompiledProcs[1] ) // Will execute function calls
to internal or external functions.

return
//------------------------------------------------------------//

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 23:13:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Phil Barnett)
Date: Mon May 28 22:13:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Tear Lines
Message-ID: <3B12CD5C.20734.1478943E@localhost>

I have noticed that there are a lot of messages posted here without 
tear lines. It's not that big of a deal, but more likely that you were 
unaware. And, it's a matter of convenience for others who reply to 
you.

If you put a tear line at the top of your signature block, most reply 
mechanisms will strip the tear line and your signature before reply 
quoting.

A proper tear line at the top of your signature block is created by 
pressing <enter><hyphen><hyphen><space><enter>. This means 
a tear line must be left justified on it's own line and exactly three 
characters long.

Using a proper tear line saves the person who is replying to you the 
task of trimming your sig block from the bottom of every message 
that is replied to.

Look just below here to see a proper tear line...


-- 
              Phil Barnett  mailto:midnight@the-oasis.net
                       WWW  http://www.the-oasis.net/
                  FTP Site  ftp://ftp.the-oasis.net

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon May 28 23:16:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon May 28 22:16:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-28 19:10 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHICEBKGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEKGDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-28 19:10 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     * Modified PP_PreProLine() to handle multi-line lines (;) as primary
line.
     * Improved PP_RunInit() accept aProcedure as parameter. Now it can auto
handle setup of RP_Run_Err() and reset aProcedures to {}
       + Added loading of std.ch

   * contrib/dot/prgscrpt.prg
     * Simplified samples, and added a simpler inline form sample.

   /*
     PP_RunInit( aCompiledProcs )

     // Note the return value from PP_ExecProcedure() and no Procedure
declaration in this 1st. sample...
     Alert( PP_ExecProcedure( ;
              PP_CompileLine( ;
                PP_PreProLine( "Private cVar := 'Hi there'; ? cVar; Return
'Returned from embedded script!'" ), ;
                               0, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )[1] ) )
   */

Runner into /tests/ppdotrun.prg.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 01:22:25 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Andrzej P. Wozniak)
Date: Tue May 29 00:22:25 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Tear Lines
References: <3B12CD5C.20734.1478943E@localhost>
Message-ID: <05d001c0e7f6$dcd82de0$500db33e@chello.pl>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Phil Barnett" <midnight@the-oasis.net>
To: <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Sent: Tuesday, May 29, 2001 4:12 AM
Subject: [Harbour] Tear Lines


[...]
> Using a proper tear line saves the person who is replying to you the
> task of trimming your sig block from the bottom of every message
> that is replied to.

There is no such a feature implemented in Outlook Express and MS Outlook :-(

> Look just below here to see a proper tear line...

It is impossible to do it in Outlook Express (and maybe MS Outlook) without
any external program. Outlook Express can insert proper tear line "-- "
(automagically only when posting to newsgroups), but then it trims all the
trailing spaces. It is as known bug as missing signs ">" when quotinq
Quoted-Printable coded messages.
And the bugs are still in MSIE/MSOE v.6 :-(

BTW. MS Outlook uses improper "RE: " in subject when replying; The Bat uses
improper "Re[n]: " (it seems to be configured, Brian?)

-- 
Regards from the Harbour mirror in Poland
Andrzej P. Wozniak
alias@polnet.cc   harbour@harbour.pl.eu.org




From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 03:14:02 2001

OO system.

Added MethodName() and modified ProcName() so as the returned 
class name is the correct one regarding the inheritance.

Changed __ObjGetMsgList() to be able to return either All 
message, Class message only or Pure message. 

Added EXPORT: as an alias to EXPORTED: for more class(y) 
compatibility

Recursion now allowed/controlled from hb_arrayClone (by Ron) 
resolve a problem (gpf) with __clsNew

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 04:14:07 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 03:14:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Tear Lines
In-Reply-To: <3B12CD5C.20734.1478943E@localhost>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Mon, May 28, 2001 at 10:12:44PM -0400

On Mon, May 28, 2001 at 10:12:44PM -0400, Phil Barnett wrote:

> A proper tear line at the top of your signature block is created by
> pressing <enter><hyphen><hyphen><space><enter>. This means a tear line
> must be left justified on it's own line and exactly three characters long.

And then LookOut Express will helpfully strip the trailing space before
sending the message. Good old Microsoft.

Personally I think incorrect sig-sep usage is the least of the email style
crimes committed on the list. Top-replying and over-quoting would seem to be
a much bigger problem.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 04:14:45 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 03:14:45 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Object DB released ???
In-Reply-To: <200105282109.XAA16006@pyxis.wanadoo.be>; from jfl@wanadoo.be on Mon, May 28, 2001 at 11:09:58PM +0200
References: <3B0CBC53.32258.11B499C1@localhost> <200105241732.f4OHWMc31868@smtp.parrett.net> <200105282109.XAA16006@pyxis.wanadoo.be>
Message-ID: <20010529073631.C28090@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, May 28, 2001 at 11:09:58PM +0200, JF Lefebvre wrote:

> It's clear it should be usable in any commercial app otherwise I don't see
> the interest of such a product. The autors wanted to publish it to the
> Oasis as Public Domain ? Why not ?

Note that code under the GPL *can* be used as part of a "commercial"
application. You can sell code that is under the GPL. You generally need a
different model of selling but code under the GPL can still be "commercial".
Perhaps you mean non-free.

As for public domain. Public domain is obviously the ultimate form of free,
but it also has significant problems if you actually want to control the
types of freedoms people receive. Not to mention the fact that AFAIK the
concept of public domain doesn't even exist in some countries (Germany
springs to mind here, although I could be wrong).

Presumably the author of ObjectDB would like to allow people to make use of
the library at no-cost ("free as in beer") and it would seem from what Phil
has said that he'd like to allow people to work with and enhance the source
code ("free as in freedom"). What isn't clear is what form he'd like this
freedom to take.

The GPL would be perfect on one hand because it would appear to give him the
freedom to allow other people to make derived works while forcing them to
keep the derived works as free software. The downside, for people who want
to write non-free software with it, is that it would require that your
applications be licenced with a GPL compatible free software licence.

As I said before, the LGPL wouldn't work for exactly the same reason that it
wouldn't work for the harbour RTL and VM.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 04:27:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 03:27:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Tear Lines
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIGEBNGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>; from harbour@winfakt.com on Tue, May 29, 2001 at 08:13:45AM +0200
References: <3B12CD5C.20734.1478943E@localhost> <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIGEBNGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <20010529082654.I28090@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 29, 2001 at 08:13:45AM +0200, Patrick Mast wrote:
> Phil,
> 
> > I have noticed that there are a lot of messages posted here without 
> > tear lines. It's not that big of a deal, but more likely that you were 
> > unaware. And, it's a matter of convenience for others who reply to 
> > you.
>
> So, what exactly does the "Tear Line" do?
> It does do nothing with me? ;-)

In the message from Phil that you're replying to he documented the main use
of a signature separator (I've never seen anyone call them a "tear line",
you'll usually see them called a "signature separator", a "sig-sep" or a
"sigsep", another common name is "signature dashes" or the "sigdash").

See <URL:http://learn.to/sign> for useful hints about creating signatures
for news and mail. <URL:http://www.cse.sc.edu/~gopalan/Unix/signatures.html>
is probably also worth a read.

<URL:http://www.math.fu-berlin.de/~guckes/afw/> is obviously the ultimate
document regarding signatures on Usenet.

> Regards,
> 
> Patrick Mast
> www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net) 
> _______________________________________________
> Harbour mailing list
> Harbour@matrixlist.com
> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour
> 
> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
> http://www.Harbour-Project.org

If you'd had a sigsep I wouldn't have needed to snip all of the above (which
I didn't anyway, I'm quoting to show what I'd need to snip) by hand. If
you've got a well written MUA it'll use my sigsep to snip my signature for
you leaving you with the actual content of my email to work on.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 05:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Tue May 29 04:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] pp (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEKHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <002e01c0e81b$b1231000$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron,

I am reviewing your prgscrpt.prg sample.

Why don't you create a simple Class TPreprocessor ?

It may turn the code much simpler and cleaner,
and it may become the perfect choice to include
it into the Harbour's RTL.

Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 06:06:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Tue May 29 05:06:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] pp (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <002e01c0e81b$b1231000$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <002f01c0e81e$1157bf00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

Ron,

First try, and it works!!! :-)

#include "hbclass.ch"

function Main()

   local oPP := TPreprocessor():New()

   Alert( oPP:Translate( "@ 2, 2 SAY 'Hello'" ) )

return nil

CLASS TPreProcessor

   DATA   aCompiledProcs
   DATA   nProcID

   METHOD New()
   METHOD Translate( cCode )

ENDCLASS

METHOD New() CLASS TPreprocessor

   ::aCompiledProcs = {}
   ::nProcID        = 0

   PP_RunInit( ::aCompiledProcs )

return Self

METHOD Translate( cCode ) CLASS TPreprocessor

   local nProcID := ::nProcID
   local cResult

   cResult = PP_PreProLine( cCode, 0, ::aCompiledProcs, nil, @nProcId )
   ::nProcID = nProcID

return cResult

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 06:24:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Tue May 29 05:24:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] pp (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <002f01c0e81e$1157bf00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <003901c0e820$7036a200$0f2aa8c0@antonio>

a little step...

Procedure Main()

   local oPP := TPreprocessor():New()

   oPP:AddRule( "#command TEST <x> => <x>" )

   Alert( oPP:Translate( "TEST 123" ) )

return

CLASS TPreProcessor

   DATA   aCompiledProcs
   DATA   nProcID

   METHOD New()
   METHOD AddRule( cRule )
   METHOD Translate( cCode )

ENDCLASS

METHOD New() CLASS TPreprocessor

   ::aCompiledProcs = {}
   ::nProcID        = 0

   PP_RunInit( ::aCompiledProcs )

return Self

METHOD AddRule( cRule ) CLASS TPreprocessor

   if SubStr( LTrim( cRule ), 1, 1 ) != "#"
      Alert( "error on rule definition" )
      return nil
   endif

return ::Translate( cRule )

METHOD Translate( cCode ) CLASS TPreprocessor

   local nProcID := ::nProcID
   local cResult

   cResult = PP_PreProLine( cCode, 0, ::aCompiledProcs, nil, @nProcId )
   ::nProcID = nProcID

return cResult

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 10:30:10 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 09:30:10 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FiveScript for Harbour is completely finish
In-Reply-To: <001101c0e83d$fa5caac0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Tue, May 29, 2001 at 02:50:45PM +0200
References: <20010529124559.D28090@hagbard.davep.org> <001101c0e83d$fa5caac0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010529141053.I28090@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 29, 2001 at 02:50:45PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Can I remind everyone about the desire to not promote non-free 
> > software on a free software web site?
> 
> Why such desire ?

Because harbour is a free software project. You yourself agreed a long time
ago that it would be better if the harbour web site wasn't used to promote
non-free software but, instead, we only had links to 3rd party sites that
supported harbour and that they could, obviously, do all the promotion they
liked on their own sites.

Harbour should be seen to be neutral regarding non-free software. A number
of people, you included, agreed with this a long time ago.

> What does it means a "free software web site" ?

Surely you know what "free software" means now? The harbour web site is a
web site for harbour. Harbour is free software. The purpose of the harbour
web site is to promote harbour and the idea of free software.

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 10:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 09:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] FiveScript for Harbour is completely finish
In-Reply-To: <001401c0e83e$e90e0380$0f2aa8c0@antonio>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Tue, May 29, 2001 at 02:57:26PM +0200
References: <20010529124559.D28090@hagbard.davep.org> <001401c0e83e$e90e0380$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <20010529143954.K28090@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 29, 2001 at 02:57:26PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> Besides my previous comments, 
> 
> Harbour used FTP belongs to Patrick Mast,
> and he is free (free as freedom, not as a free beer) 
> to place there what he may want (even a link to somewhere else...)

The last time I looked the ftp and web space used by the Harbour project was
provided by Phil Barnett, not Patrick Mast. But, obviously, that's an aside
to your question.

Now, while it is true that the owner of the machine is free to do whatever
they wish there's also a duty to the project as a whole to not misrepresent
harbour and harbour development in general. There's also a duty to follow
the stated wishes of the developers and to keep the web site in the spirit
of free software (remember, we're not just talking "Open Source" here, we're
talking full-on "free software").

Personally I've never seen Patrick or Phil as the sort of people who would
force something on the harbour project so I'm not sure I really follow your
question. Both Patrick and Phil strike me as polite, reasonable people who
would never show such a lack of consideration.

> How may that affect to an open source development ?

I don't know, how might it affect a free software development? I'm not at
all sure I understand your question. Perhaps you could be a little more
clear about your concern? In exactly what sort of circumstances can you
imagine Patrick or Phil forcing non-free software onto a free software web
site? I just can't see that myself.

--

Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

Ignacio,

> I am glad to say that FiveScript for Harbour is completely finish and is
> working really nice, even better than in Clipper, since there is
> no need to use tricky software due the limitations of Clipper macro
> evaluator.
Hey, thats Great!
Now we have 2 choices! Ron's PP and your FiveScript.

Ron's PP can do this:
Function Test()
LOCAL cMacro:="MsgInfo('Test')"
&(cMacro)
RETURN NIL

Is this possible with FiveSCript?

FiveScript can Test a source code on syntax errors. Ron, Is this possible
with PP?
Please, I'm not starting a competition here, I'm just asking. ;-)

> BTW the speed is almost the same of Clipper in our tests. :-))
Great!

Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-28 19:10 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEKGDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIOECMGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Ron,

> 2001-05-28 19:10 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
>    * contrib/dot/pp.prg
First tests looks good! ;-)

There is a little typo in prgscript.prg at line 19. The 2nd parameter should
be 1 instead of 2.

What does the nProcID parameter do in the PP_CompileLine()?

If there is a error in the line we want to Preprocess or Compile, the alert
box says the line nr from the PP programme instead of the line number of the
script.

How can we know if a script line has a error?
If we know a line in a script has and error we can stop the
Preprocess/Compile process.

Thanks Ron!

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

No it isn't, it's recognition that people have do and say unfair and unkind
things about harbour and about those 3rd party developers who seek to help
and support harbour. It's also recognition of the fact that I've spent a lot
of time working on setting the record straight and ensuring that harbour and
3rd party developers are portrayed on the best possible light in public
places such as <URL:news:comp.lang.clipper>.

Saying that a fact is an insult is really odd.

> I demand that you retract from the above.

How can I retract the truth? How can I retract the work I've done to point
out that there is no conspiracy?

Oddly enough your attempt to say that my work against such accusations is an
"insult" plays right into their hands. Most odd.

Function Test()
LOCAL cMacro:="MsgInfo('Test')"
&(cMacro)
RETURN NIL

FiveScript can Test a source code on syntax errors. Ron, Is this possible
with PP?

surprised to find that I do have so much control over your working day, I
doubt that I really do.

Since posting the *single* email on the subject of the parent thread at
14:39 this afternoon I've installed Kylix, found a problem, fixed the
problem with it, written some code, answered a couple of support calls,
tracked down the email address of the Labour party candidate for my
constituency (having moved to a new area) and composed an email to him to
ask where he stands on RIP and on our current government's overuse of
Microsoft software (including the growing number of sites that reject your
browser if it's not a Microsoft browser), written more code, write and
posted <20010529143954.K28090@hagbard.davep.org> in response to your
questions about use of free software web sites, replied to the insults that
came back in response to my reasonable answers and questions and still had
time to make a coffee every so often.

I find it hard to believe that I'm better at managing my time than you are
so I can only conclude that this is yet another attempt at an insult. And
all because I commented on a subject that you yourself care about.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 15:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 14:30:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] conspiracy
In-Reply-To: <01211200105292231168107694@ANDIJAHJA.ORG>; from andijahja@cbn.net.id on Tue, May 29, 2001 at 10:31:20PM +0700
References: <000801c0e84f$0a1ff1e0$0f2aa8c0@antonio> <01211200105292231168107694@ANDIJAHJA.ORG>
Message-ID: <20010529172034.R28090@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 29, 2001 at 10:31:20PM +0700, Andi Jahja wrote:

> There are more than 200 GB Clipper thingies on the Oasis. Some of them are
> demos.
> 
> I am not very sure if Phil can be categorized as having been doing
> conspiracy ?

The Oasis <URL:http://www.the-oasis.net/> isn't the web site of a free
software project that claims to adhere to the principles of and has the
backing and endorsement of the Free Software Foundation. Drawing a parallel
between The Oasis and <URL:http://www.harbour-project.org/> makes no sense
as they serve very different purposes. Such a comparison is an exercise in
comparing apples and oranges.

> I am lost now ;-((((((

In the early days of harbour a good number of people kept calling into
question Antonio's motivations regarding starting the harbour project,
myself included. I've long since satisfied myself that Antonio and the
FiveTech crew in general are as committed to free software, as far as
harbour is concerned, as anyone else is. Because of this I've made a point
of always tackling the "conspiracy" when it crops up, and it does crop up
from time to time. There was just such a thread on comp.lang.clipper earlier
this year.

The odd thing is that every so often I get attacked and insulted by Antonio
because I care about Harbour and I care about FiveWin, especially FiveWin
for Harbour. I've got no use for the latter product but I think it's
existence, hopefully along with the existence of other free and non-free 3rd
party products, will be a vindication of the principles of free software and
I think it will unquestionably demonstrate that a band of people with very
different goals can pull together and make something happen.

Sadly, the attacks, like those we've seen today, actually suggest there is a
hidden agenda. This makes it harder for people like myself who want to
demonstrate to those who would claim that there is a "conspiracy" that
harbour is free in all senses and that the existence of non-free support,
*any* non-free support, is in keeping with that freedom, that it isn't
indicative of some hidden motive or hidden agenda.

But, hey, I'm not the one claiming that "talking all day" is easy. <shrug>

-- 
The Harbour Project: A free software Clipper compatible compiler
Home Page..........: http://www.harbour-project.org/
FAQ................: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/harbour.html
My harbour page....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 15:38:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue May 29 14:38:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] conspiracy
In-Reply-To: <002601c0e868$778324a0$020aa8c0@pacbell.net>; from awross@pacbell.net on Tue, May 29, 2001 at 10:54:54AM -0700
References: <01212200105292243158179531@ANDIJAHJA.ORG> <001101c0e859$8944e160$0f2aa8c0@antonio> <20010529181644.Y28090@hagbard.davep.org> <002601c0e868$778324a0$020aa8c0@pacbell.net>
Message-ID: <20010529193720.C28090@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, May 29, 2001 at 10:54:54AM -0700, Andrew W. Ross wrote:

> In Dave's defense, not that he needs it, I completely understood what he
> was saying. I too don't want the Harbour web site mucked up with a bunch
> of third party ads and demos. A simple link and a description will
> suffice. Once you make the jump, the details will follow on the vendors
> site.
> 
> KISS and you won't have vendor wars.

Well, I wouldn't go quite so far as to say "mucked up" <g> but, yes, that's
what I'm talking about. Various vendors can have all the demos and all the
advertising they like on their own web sites, the harbour site shouldn't be
in the business of hosting non-free software. There is, however, obviously
no harm in alphabetically (so there's no accusation of favouritism) listing
and pointing to the sites of non-free product vendors if it's done simply
and cleanly.

A number of people "signed up" to this principle a long time ago and that's
what I was reiterating in <20010529124559.D28090@hagbard.davep.org>.

--

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 16:43:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Tue May 29 15:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Dot (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <002f01c0e81e$1157bf00$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHICEDDGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Ron,

This does not work:

   nProcId := 0
   PP_RunInit( aCompiledProcs )

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Proc Test" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 1, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Alert( 'Hello from embedded PP' )" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 2, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "/*Alert( 'Hello from embedded PP' )" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 3, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Alert( 'Hello from embedded PP' )" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 4, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "Alert( 'Hello from embedded PP' )*/" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 5, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )

   sPPed := PP_PreProLine( "RETURN" )
   PP_CompileLine( sPPed, 6, aCompiledProcs, NIL, @nProcId )

   PP_ExecProcedure( aCompiledProcs[1] )

Notice the /* in line 3 and */ in line 5


Wat I wanted to do is this:
"Compile" a *.prg like this:
,---------------
|cCompiled:=""
|FOR F=1 TO LineCount(cFile)
|  cCompiled+=PP_PreProLine( cLine(cFile,f) )+";"
|NEXT
|MemoWrite(cCompiled)
`--------------------
Than I could run this "Compiled" file like this:
,--------------
|nProcId := 0
|PP_RunInit( aCompiledProcs )
|PP_CompileLine( MemoRead(cCompiledFile) , 0, aCompiledProcs, NIL,
@nProcId )
|xRetu:=PP_ExecProcedure( aCompiledProcs[1] )
`------------------

This:
,-------
|Function Test()
|MsgInfo("test")
|RETURN NIL
`------------
would be saved like this:
,---------
|PP_PROC Test;MsgInfo("test");PP_SetReturn( NIL )
`--------------

But when a .PRG has a "remarked" block, it does not work.

Thanks!

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue May 29 23:10:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian)
Date: Tue May 29 22:10:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] What's new in 0.37?
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIEEBOGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
References: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIEEBOGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <18036475599.20010529191806@abacuslaw.com>

Patrick:

PM> Can we start the WhatsNew for release 0.37

PM> - Fixed and improved NTX support
PM> - Improved and fixed OOP
PM> - More enhanced DOT prompt
PM> - Fixed and improved ADS support

  * added support for HB_TR_FLUSH Environment variable
            SET HB_TR_FLUSH=1
         ...Will cause all HB_TRACE calls to flush to disk (when
         redirecting to file) so you can trace right up to a line
         that gpfs and not lose buffered output.

 ---===--- 

 Brian




From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 05:07:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 30 04:07:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ntxGoCold problem (Alexander)
In-Reply-To: <18036475599.20010529191806@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCELHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Hi Alexander,

Try this:

//--------------------------------------------------------------------------
---------//
External OrdListClear, OrdListAdd

Procedure Main
   LOCAL cBlock

   USE TEST

    _FIELD->First := 'John' // Uncomment produces -> ntxGoCold: Cannot find
current key:

   cBlock := "{|| OrdListClear(), OrdListAdd( 'First' ), _FIELD->First :=
'John' }"

   Eval( &cBlock ) // Error DBF/1020  Data type error
RETURN
//--------------------------------------------------------------------------
---------//

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 05:44:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 30 04:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-30 01:30 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCELHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIELHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-05-30 01:30 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * contrib/dot/pp.prg
     + Added PP_PreProText( cText [, acLines ] ) returns the pre-process
text and optional file asLines with pre=processed lines.
     + Added PP_RunText( cText, [bPreProcess], [aParmas] ) returns the
return value of executed code. bPreProcess defaults to .T.
     * Enhanced PP_Run( cFile [, aParams] ) to accept optional Array with
Parameters.
     ! Minor correction in NextExp().

   * contrib/dot/prgscrpt.prg
     * Rewrote sample to demonstrate new simpler wrapper functions:


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 05:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 30 04:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Dot (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHICEDDGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMELHDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Patrick,

> This does not work:
> ...

It is not supposed to work that way. You see, each pre-processing and or
compilation unit, MUST be complete.

To address this issue and to far simplify such tasks I added new
PP_PreProText() and PP_RunText()

Here is the new PRGScrpt.prg (I hope you have as much fun as I did):

//----------------------------------------------------//
Procedure Main( sMsg )

   LOCAL sText, sPPed

   sText := "/* Sample Script for embedded PP "   + ';'
   sText += " have fun... */"                     + ';'
   sText += ""                                    + ';'
   sText += "Procedure Test( cMacroVar, xValue )" + ';'
   sText += ""                                    + ';'
   sText += "   Local cVar := 'Hi There'"         + ';'
   sText += ""                                    + ';'
   sText += "   &cMacroVar := xValue"             + ';'
   sText += ""                                    + ';'
   sText += "   ? cVar, &cMacroVar"               + ';'
   sText += ""                                    + ';'
   sText += "   WHILE Inkey() == 0 // WAIT"       + ';'
   sText += "   ENDDO"                            + ';'
   sText += ""                                    + ';'
   sText += "RETURN LastKey()"

   Alert( PP_RunText( sText, .T., { "Private_1", 1000 } ) )

   //OR ...

   sPPed := PP_PreProText( sText )
   Alert( PP_RunText( sPPed, .F., { "Private_2", 2000 } ) )

   // Now let's have some real fun...
   IF sMsg == "Recursively running self"
      Alert( "Let's STOP this madness..." )
      RETURN
   ELSE
      PP_Run( "prgscrpt.prg", { "Recursively running self" } )
   ENDIF

return
//----------------------------------------------------//

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 06:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)

Ron,

How your preprocessor behaves if I add a new rule
that already is defined ? Will it replace it ?

thanks!

Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 06:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 30 05:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TPreprocessor
In-Reply-To: <002c01c0e8e9$2ae441c0$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKELJDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Antonio,

> How your preprocessor behaves if I add a new rule
> that already is defined ? Will it replace it ?

Just like in Clipper, it just ads it as the last rule. Clipper tests rules
Last In First Out (LIFO) so the last rule defined, supercedes any previous
rule, but if it does not match, the previous rule is checked, and so on,
until a match is found or all rules exhausted.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 09:07:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Wed May 30 08:07:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] pp question (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <004201c0e8fa$35a44540$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIKEDNGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Antonio, Ron,

The TPreProcessor class does not Preprocess like we know it. It preprocesses
lines for the PP intrepereter.

Try to preprocess this line in wpp.exe:
,-----
|PROCEDURE Test()
`---------
The result is:
,---------
|PP_PROC Test
`-----------

The preprocessor output from harbour is:
,------
|PROCEDURE Test()
`---------

Can the TPerProcess class be modified so it returns a "Harbour alike"
Preprocess output?

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 09:38:03 2001

Patrick,

As far as I see it, Ron should have separated the
preprocessor itself from the scripting pp feature.

The preprocessor should not know anything regarding
a further execution of a scripting engine.

That way, we keep a better structurated code, easier
to maintain and use.

Just my opinion,

> The TPreProcessor class does not Preprocess like we know it. It 
> preprocesses lines for the PP intrepereter.

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 12:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 30 11:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] pp question (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <004c01c0e904$daed4e20$0f2aa8c0@antonio>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCELODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Antonio, Patrick,

> Patrick,
>
> As far as I see it, Ron should have separated the
> preprocessor itself from the scripting pp feature.
>
> The preprocessor should not know anything regarding
> a further execution of a scripting engine.
>
> That way, we keep a better structurated code, easier
> to maintain and use.
>
> Just my opinion,
>
> > The TPreProcessor class does not Preprocess like we know it. It
> > preprocesses lines for the PP intrepereter.
>
> Antonio

It is completely separated. It's simply a matter of what rules are loaded
:-)

We need to add few more methods to TpreProcessor like: ::ResetRules(),
::LoadStd(), ::LoadRun() ::LoadClass() and maybe even ::LoadFW() and
::LoadC4W()

::New() should accept optional logicals, one for each of these like:
bLoadStd, bLoadRun, bLoadClass, bLoadFW, bLoadC4W. Only bLoadStd should
default to .T.

Also need to add ::PreProLine, ::PreProText(), ::and PreProFile() .

::Translate should use PP_PreProText() instead of PP_PreProLine(), it's
safer, as it supports all kinds of comments.

We should also add TInterpreter() that utilizes TPreProcessor().

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 12:50:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast)
Date: Wed May 30 11:50:06 2001
Subject: [Harbour] PreProcess.exe
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCELODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIOEEDGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>

Hi,

Ok, I have enhanced Antonio's TPrePro class, wich is based on Ron's PP.prg.
It has a new Method now:

TranslateFile( cFile, [lWritePPO], [cPPOExt], [lWasteNoSpace] )
  => cPreprocessed

         cFile = The file to preprocess
     lWritePPO = .T. if you want a output file from the preprocessed
       cPPOExt = The extention for the output file
lWasteNoSpaces = If set to .T. all empty lines and spaced will NOT
                 be included in the preprocessed output

The source and compiled version of this is at:
http://www.FiveWin.be.kz/files/preprocess.zip
(530Kb)

I also simplified the other methods of the class.

Let me know how it works ok? ;-))

PS. Antonio: should we not upload this to a contrib dir?

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

Antonio,

> Ron,
>
> On wpp.exe, if I write a #include "test.ch"
> (an existing file with some #commands),
>
> does the preprocessor add those rules ?
>

Yes it does, but subsequent lines would cause error, because of an orphan
"#line ..." directive.

I fixed it, can you try again now?

I would suggest a button to reset rules. It's action should call
PP_ResetRules()

Maybe you could also add Checkbox controls for 'Load-STD', 'Load-Run',
'Load-Class', and 'Load-FW'. If John will send his C4W[h] include file, I
can also add LoadC4W()

IF Reset Rules is Clicked you should call PP_ResetRules() or PP_InitStd()
(if Load-STD is checked) and then call each PP_LoadXXX() as per Checkbox
controls.

If *any* Checkbox Control is Clicked, must perform same as above.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 13:21:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed May 30 12:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Keyboard mapping problem (David)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIELODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCELODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIELODMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <200105301616.f4UGG2432167@smtp.parrett.net>

** Reply to message from "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com> on Wed,
30 May 2001 08:44:40 -0700

> With current CVS, BC55, W32, under WinMe, if CAPS LOCK is ON, *all* keys
> behave as if SHIFT is used. Press 7 you get '&' press 8, you get '*', etc...

Must be something that Microsoft changed in Windows ME. In order to
find out what it is, you need to edit the gtwin.c source, uncomment the
#define HB_DEBUG_KEYBOARD line near the top, then do an incremental
rebuild. Then build inkeytst.prg and run it with the SKIP parameter with
the output redirected to a file on ME and, if you have one, on another
Windows OS. Run the same sequence of keystrokes on both systems, then
compare the contents of the redirected files.

If you don't have easy access to another Windows OS, then just do the
ME test and send an email with the sequence of keys that you pressed and
attach the redirected file and I'll do a comparison on NT.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 13:26:01 2001

Sure, I already proposed such split few days ago:

--------------------------------------------------
Also after the recent changes, allowing PP to be used as support LIB for run
time manipulation of scripts, I wonder if you/others think it might be a
good idea to add the PP backbone to standard RTL LIBs.

If this will be the case, it will take me just few minutes to:

 1. Extract needed piece and add it as pplib.prg under source/rtl.
 2. Update the make files
 3. Move the remaining (small) Main procedure, which provides DOT, PP, or
Runner into /tests/ppdotrun.prg.
 4. Move /contib/dot/prgscrpt.prg to /tests/prgscrpt.prg.
---------------------------------------------------

I would leave the contib/dot/pp.prg as is, for those that want the self
contained files, as well as for Clipper applications, and I suppose your
TPreProcessor (modified by Patrick) will go to RTL pplib as well.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 14:17:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed May 30 13:17:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-05-30 09:05 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <NCBBJKNMIDPJNLJCHCHIKEEHGEAA.harbour@winfakt.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEMCDMAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Patrick,

> What happens if for a reason FIVEWIN.CH changes?
> Is this not a heavy maintenance job, synchronise all CH files?

Not at all, the rules generation is automated :-)

Here is what *anyone* can do:

1. CD \FWH\include
2. PP FiveWin.ch -U -CCH
3. Open generated FiveWin.cch
4. Rename InitRules() to InitFWRules()
5. Rename InitResults to InitFWResults()
6. Remove 3 lines with aXXXXRules := {} and 3 lines with aXXXXResults := {}
7. Override in PP.prg resulting InitFWRules() and InitFWResults()

Takes, probably 2 minutes, and I could even simplify these, to dispose of
steps 4-6.

Ron

A new Harbour License, based on the license used for Guile 1.4, is in
the process of being adapted. At this time, most source modules have
been converted to the new license, but permission to change the
license.txt file is still needed from the following Harbour developers:

  Felipe G. Coury <fcoury@flexsys-ci.com>
  Jf. Lefebvre <jfl@mafact.com> and Ra. Cuylen <rac@mafact.com>
  Jon Berg <jmberg@pnh10.med.navy.mil>

29 May 2001 08:50:02 +0200

A new keyboard input mode, HB_INKEY_EXTENDED, has been added. This
provides a standardized way of being able to distinguish all non-state
keys. The new include file hbinkey.ch provides the key mappings for this
new mode, using manifest constants such as HB_KP_ALT_INS. This new
keyboard input mode has only been implemented for GTWIN, but it can be
added to other GT modules without making any changes at the GTAPI level.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed May 30 15:10:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian)
Date: Wed May 30 14:10:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Copy To bug (Harrier)
Message-ID: <1745427424.20010530111841@abacuslaw.com>

Harrier,

COPY NEXT 1 TO (cTempFile)
does not start on the current record as it should (it goes top).

A workaround is to add the REST clause, but it shouldn't be needed;
using NEXT should always start at current.

 ---===---
 Brian

> Harrier,
> 
> COPY NEXT 1 TO (cTempFile)
> does not start on the current record as it should (it goes top).
> 
> A workaround is to add the REST clause, but it shouldn't be needed;
> using NEXT should always start at current.
>

Hi,

I think that it is a good idea to have a page on the Harbour-Project web
site where we provide links to all sort of Harbour Sample Applications.

It is in the intrest of Harbour that people can see and feel applications
that are written in Harbour.

Everyone is welcome to conribute sample applications.

I vote for YES! ;-)

Regards,

Patrick Mast

APIs

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu May 31 02:46:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu May 31 01:46:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-05-30 10:49 UTC-0800
Message-ID: <1894657937.20010530225139@abacuslaw.com>

2001-05-30 10:49 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

   * source/rdd/dbcmd.c
      * Harrier's fix to NEXT clause in COPY TO command
         Thanks, Harrier!

   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads1.c
      * corrected commit to only flush current workarea

   * source/rtl/philes.c
      * changed HB_FEOF() to HB_F_EOF to avoid collision with the
         HB_FEOF() in libmisc/hb_f.c

  

-- 
  ---====---
  Brian Hays

** Reply to message from Marek Paliwoda <paliwoda@inetia.pl> on Thu, 31
May 2001 20:47:17 +0200

> Is there a function similar to hb_osNewLine() which returns
> platform dependent path delimiter and path list separator ?

Manifest constants are currently set up in include/hbsetup.h, but they
aren't made available to Harbour programs anywhere. Functions to do that
could be added after build 37 is released.
